RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) has been delivered as archived Windows executable files masquerading as PDF documents.(Citation: Unit42 Redaman January 2019)

RTM.name: Spearphishing Attachment
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) has been delivered via spearphishing attachments disguised as PDF documents.(Citation: Unit42 Redaman January 2019)

RTM.name: Software Discovery
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can scan victim drives to look for specific banking software on the machine to determine next actions.(Citation: ESET RTM Feb 2017)

RTM.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can search for specific strings within browser tabs using a Dynamic Data Exchange mechanism.(Citation: ESET RTM Feb 2017)

RTM.name: Native API
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can use the FindNextUrlCacheEntryA and FindFirstUrlCacheEntryA functions to search for specific strings within browser history.(Citation: ESET RTM Feb 2017)

Smoke Loader.name: Process Hollowing
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) spawns a new copy of c:\windows\syswow64\explorer.exe and then replaces the executable code in memory with malware.(Citation: Malwarebytes SmokeLoader 2016)(Citation: Microsoft Dofoil 2018)

Smoke Loader.name: Scheduled Task
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) launches a scheduled task.(Citation: Talos Smoke Loader July 2018)

Smoke Loader.name: File and Directory Discovery
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) recursively searches through directories for files.(Citation: Talos Smoke Loader July 2018)

Smoke Loader.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) deobfuscates its code.(Citation: Talos Smoke Loader July 2018)

Smoke Loader.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) adds a Registry Run key for persistence and adds a script in the Startup folder to deploy the payload.(Citation: Malwarebytes SmokeLoader 2016)

Smoke Loader.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) downloads a new version of itself once it has installed. It also downloads additional plugins.(Citation: Malwarebytes SmokeLoader 2016)

Smoke Loader.name: Local Email Collection
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) searches through Outlook files and directories (e.g., inbox, sent, templates, drafts, archives, etc.).(Citation: Talos Smoke Loader July 2018)

Smoke Loader.name: Credentials In Files
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) searches for files named logins.json to parse for credentials.(Citation: Talos Smoke Loader July 2018)

Smoke Loader.name: Process Injection
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) injects into the Internet Explorer process.(Citation: Talos Smoke Loader July 2018)

Smoke Loader.name: Web Protocols
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) uses HTTP for C2.(Citation: Malwarebytes SmokeLoader 2016)

Smoke Loader.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) uses a simple one-byte XOR method to obfuscate values in the malware.(Citation: Malwarebytes SmokeLoader 2016)(Citation: Talos Smoke Loader July 2018)

Smoke Loader.name: Visual Basic
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) adds a Visual Basic script in the Startup folder to deploy the payload.(Citation: Malwarebytes SmokeLoader 2016)

Smoke Loader.name: System Checks
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) scans processes to perform anti-VM checks. (Citation: Talos Smoke Loader July 2018)

Smoke Loader.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) searches for credentials stored from web browsers.(Citation: Talos Smoke Loader July 2018)

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: Standard Encoding
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: Some [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) samples use standard Base64 + bzip2, and some use standard Base64 + reverse XOR + RSA-2048 to decrypt data received from C2 servers.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: Some [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) samples contain a publicly available Web browser password recovery tool.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: Process Injection
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) injects itself into explorer.exe.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: Process Discovery
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects information about running processes.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects the current username from the victim.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: Archive Collected Data
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) writes collected data to a temporary file in an encrypted form before exfiltration to a C2 server.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: File Deletion
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) contains a cleanup module that removes traces of itself from the victim.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: Email Account
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects address book information from Outlook.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: File and Directory Discovery
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects information about available drives, default browser, desktop file list, My Documents, Internet history, program files, and root of available drives. It also searches for ICS-related software files.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects information about the Internet adapter configuration.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) adds Registry Run keys to achieve persistence.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: System Information Discovery
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects information about the OS and computer name.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Kazuar.name: Web Protocols
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) uses HTTP and HTTPS to communicate with the C2 server. [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can also act as a webserver and listen for inbound HTTP requests through an exposed API.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Application Window Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information about opened windows.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Bidirectional Communication
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) has used compromised WordPress blogs as C2 servers.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) is obfuscated using the open source ConfuserEx protector. [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) also obfuscates the name of created files/folders/mutexes and encrypts debug messages written to log files using the Rijndael cipher.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information on users.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
Kazuar.description: If running in a Windows environment, [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) saves a DLL to disk that is injected into the explorer.exe process to execute the payload. [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can also be configured to inject and execute within specific processes.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: File Deletion
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can delete files.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Shortcut Modification
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) adds a .lnk file to the Windows startup folder.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Scheduled Transfer
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can sleep for a specific time and be set to communicate at specific intervals.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Local Account
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information on local groups and members on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Fallback Channels
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can accept multiple URLs for C2 servers.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Video Capture
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) captures images from the webcam.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Screen Capture
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) captures screenshots of the victim’s screen.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Process Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) obtains a list of running processes through WMI querying and the ps command.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: System Information Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information on the system and local drives.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information about network adapters.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Windows Service
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can install itself as a new service.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) adds a sub-key under several Registry run keys.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: File and Directory Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) finds a specified directory, lists the files and metadata about those files.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Standard Encoding
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) encodes communications to the C2 server in Base64.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) downloads additional plug-ins to load on the victim’s machine, including the ability to upgrade and replace its own binary.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Local Groups
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information about local groups and members.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Data from Local System
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) uploads files from a specified directory to the C2 server.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Unix Shell
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) uses /bin/bash to execute commands on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Local Data Staging
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) stages command output and collected data in files before exfiltration.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Data Destruction
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can overwrite files with random data before deleting them.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) obtains a list of running processes through WMI querying.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: File Transfer Protocols
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) uses FTP and FTPS to communicate with the C2 server.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Kazuar.name: Windows Command Shell
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) uses cmd.exe to execute commands on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)

Cherry Picker.name: File Deletion
Cherry Picker.description: Recent versions of [Cherry Picker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0107) delete files and registry keys created by the malware.(Citation: Trustwave Cherry Picker)

Cherry Picker.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted/Obfuscated Non-C2 Protocol
Cherry Picker.description: [Cherry Picker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0107) exfiltrates files over FTP.(Citation: Trustwave Cherry Picker)

Cherry Picker.name: AppInit DLLs
Cherry Picker.description: Some variants of [Cherry Picker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0107) use AppInit_DLLs to achieve persistence by creating the following Registry key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows "AppInit_DLLs"="pserver32.dll"(Citation: Trustwave Cherry Picker)

USBStealer.name: File Deletion
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) has several commands to delete files associated with the malware from the victim.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)

USBStealer.name: Data from Removable Media
USBStealer.description: Once a removable media device is inserted back into the first victim, [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) collects data from it that was exfiltrated from a second victim.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)(Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy)

USBStealer.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
USBStealer.description: Most strings in [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) are encrypted using 3DES and XOR and reversed.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)

USBStealer.name: File and Directory Discovery
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) searches victim drives for files matching certain extensions (“.skr”,“.pkr” or “.key”) or names.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)(Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy)

USBStealer.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) mimics a legitimate Russian program called USB Disk Security.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)

USBStealer.name: Replication Through Removable Media
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) drops itself onto removable media and relies on Autorun to execute the malicious file when a user opens the removable media on another system.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)

USBStealer.name: Exfiltration over USB
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) exfiltrates collected files via removable media from air-gapped victims.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)

USBStealer.name: Local Data Staging
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) collects files matching certain criteria from the victim and stores them in a local directory for later exfiltration.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)(Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy)

USBStealer.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) registers itself under a Registry Run key with the name "USB Disk Security."(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)

USBStealer.name: Automated Collection
USBStealer.description: For all non-removable drives on a victim, [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) executes automated collection of certain files for later exfiltration.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)

USBStealer.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) monitors victims for insertion of removable drives. When dropped onto a second victim, it also enumerates drives connected to the system.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)

USBStealer.name: Communication Through Removable Media
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) drops commands for a second victim onto a removable media drive inserted into the first victim, and commands are executed when the drive is inserted into the second victim.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)

USBStealer.name: Timestomp
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) sets the timestamps of its dropper files to the last-access and last-write timestamps of a standard Windows library chosen on the system.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)

USBStealer.name: Automated Exfiltration
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) automatically exfiltrates collected files via removable media when an infected device is connected to the second victim after receiving commands from the first victim.(Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014)

H1N1.name: Symmetric Cryptography
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) encrypts C2 traffic using an RC4 key.(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 2)

H1N1.name: Software Packing
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) uses a custom packing algorithm.(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 1)

H1N1.name: Disable or Modify Tools
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) kills and disables services for Windows Security Center, and Windows Defender.(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 2)

H1N1.name: Windows Command Shell
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) kills and disables services by using cmd.exe.(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 2)

H1N1.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) dumps usernames and passwords from Firefox, Internet Explorer, and Outlook.(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 2)

H1N1.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) contains a command to download and execute a file from a remotely hosted URL using WinINet HTTP requests.(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 2)

H1N1.name: Taint Shared Content
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) has functionality to copy itself to network shares.(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 2)

H1N1.name: Data Encoding
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) obfuscates C2 traffic with an altered version of base64.(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 2)

H1N1.name: Replication Through Removable Media
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) has functionality to copy itself to removable media.(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 2)

H1N1.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) uses multiple techniques to obfuscate strings, including XOR.(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 1)

H1N1.name: Inhibit System Recovery
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) disable recovery options and deletes shadow copies from the victim.(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 2)

H1N1.name: Bypass User Access Control
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) bypasses user access control by using a DLL hijacking vulnerability in the Windows Update Standalone Installer (wusa.exe).(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 2)

H1N1.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) kills and disables services for Windows Firewall.(Citation: Cisco H1N1 Part 2)

Lurid.name: Archive Collected Data
Lurid.description: [Lurid](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0010) can compress data before sending it.(Citation: Villeneuve 2011)

TURNEDUP.name: Screen Capture
TURNEDUP.description: [TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of taking screenshots.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)

TURNEDUP.name: Asynchronous Procedure Call
TURNEDUP.description: [TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of injecting code into the APC queue of a created [Rundll32](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1085) process as part of an "Early Bird injection."(Citation: CyberBit Early Bird Apr 2018)

TURNEDUP.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
TURNEDUP.description: [TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of writing to a Registry Run key to establish.(Citation: CyberBit Early Bird Apr 2018)

TURNEDUP.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
TURNEDUP.description: [TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of downloading additional files.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)

TURNEDUP.name: System Information Discovery
TURNEDUP.description: [TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of gathering system information.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)

TURNEDUP.name: Windows Command Shell
TURNEDUP.description: [TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of creating a reverse shell.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)

Reaver.name: Query Registry
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) queries the Registry to determine the correct Startup path to use for persistence.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) encrypts some of its files with XOR.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: Control Panel
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) drops and executes a malicious CPL file as its payload.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: File Deletion
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) deletes the original dropped file from the victim.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
Reaver.description: Some [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) variants use raw TCP for C2.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) collects the victim's username.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) creates a shortcut file and saves it in a Startup folder to establish persistence.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Reaver.description: Some [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) variants use raw TCP for C2.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) collects the victim's IP address.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: Windows Service
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) installs itself as a new service.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: Archive via Custom Method
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) encrypts collected data with an incremental XOR key prior to exfiltration.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: System Information Discovery
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) collects system information from the victim, including CPU speed, computer name, volume serial number, ANSI code page, OEM code page identifier for the OS, Microsoft Windows version, and memory information.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: Shortcut Modification
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) creates a shortcut file and saves it in a Startup folder to establish persistence.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

Reaver.name: Web Protocols
Reaver.description: Some [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) variants use HTTP for C2.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)

RemoteCMD.name: Service Execution
RemoteCMD.description: [RemoteCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0166) can execute commands remotely by creating a new service on the remote system.(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

RemoteCMD.name: Scheduled Task
RemoteCMD.description: [RemoteCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0166) can execute commands remotely by creating a new schedule task on the remote system(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

RemoteCMD.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
RemoteCMD.description: [RemoteCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0166) copies a file over to the remote system before execution.(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

OnionDuke.name: Web Protocols
OnionDuke.description: [OnionDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0052) uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2.(Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)

OnionDuke.name: One-Way Communication
OnionDuke.description: [OnionDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0052) uses Twitter as a backup C2.(Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)

OnionDuke.name: OS Credential Dumping
OnionDuke.description: [OnionDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0052) steals credentials from its victims.(Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)

SslMM.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
SslMM.description: To establish persistence, [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an “Office Start,” “Yahoo Talk,” “MSN Gaming Z0ne,” or “MSN Talk” shortcut.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

SslMM.name: System Information Discovery
SslMM.description: [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) sends information to its hard-coded C2, including OS version, service pack information, processor speed, system name, and OS install date.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

SslMM.name: Shortcut Modification
SslMM.description: To establish persistence, [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an “Office Start,” “Yahoo Talk,” “MSN Gaming Z0ne,” or “MSN Talk” shortcut.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

SslMM.name: Keylogging
SslMM.description: [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) creates a new thread implementing a keylogging facility using Windows Keyboard Accelerators.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

SslMM.name: System Owner/User Discovery
SslMM.description: [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) sends the logged-on username to its hard-coded C2.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

SslMM.name: Access Token Manipulation
SslMM.description: [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) contains a feature to manipulate process privileges and tokens.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

SslMM.name: Disable or Modify Tools
SslMM.description: [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) identifies and kills anti-malware processes.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

SslMM.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
SslMM.description: To establish persistence, [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an “Office Start,” “Yahoo Talk,” “MSN Gaming Z0ne,” or “MSN Talk” shortcut.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

SslMM.name: Fallback Channels
SslMM.description: [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) has a hard-coded primary and backup C2 string.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

JHUHUGIT.name: Component Object Model Hijacking
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has used COM hijacking to establish persistence by hijacking a class named MMDeviceEnumerator and also by registering the payload as a Shell Icon Overlay handler COM object ({3543619C-D563-43f7-95EA-4DA7E1CC396A}).(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)(Citation: Talos Seduploader Oct 2017)

JHUHUGIT.name: Process Injection
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) performs code injection injecting its own functions to browser processes.(Citation: F-Secure Sofacy 2015)(Citation: Unit 42 Sofacy Feb 2018)

JHUHUGIT.name: File Deletion
JHUHUGIT.description: The [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) dropper can delete itself from the victim. Another [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant has the capability to delete specified files.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)(Citation: Unit 42 Sofacy Feb 2018)

JHUHUGIT.name: Clipboard Data
JHUHUGIT.description: A [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant accesses a screenshot saved in the clipboard and converts it to a JPG image.(Citation: Unit 42 Playbook Dec 2017)

JHUHUGIT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has used a Registry Run key to establish persistence by executing JavaScript code within the rundll32.exe process.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)

JHUHUGIT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
JHUHUGIT.description: A [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant gathers network interface card information.(Citation: Unit 42 Playbook Dec 2017)

JHUHUGIT.name: System Information Discovery
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) obtains a build identifier as well as victim hard drive information from Windows registry key HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Disk\Enum. Another [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant gathers the victim storage volume serial number and the storage device name.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)(Citation: Unit 42 Sofacy Feb 2018)

JHUHUGIT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) can retrieve an additional payload from its C2 server.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)(Citation: Unit 42 Sofacy Feb 2018) [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has a command to download files to the victim’s machine.(Citation: Talos Seduploader Oct 2017)

JHUHUGIT.name: Rundll32
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) is executed using rundll32.exe.(Citation: F-Secure Sofacy 2015)(Citation: Talos Seduploader Oct 2017)

JHUHUGIT.name: Screen Capture
JHUHUGIT.description: A [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant takes screenshots by simulating the user pressing the "Take Screenshot" key (VK_SCREENSHOT), accessing the screenshot saved in the clipboard, and converting it to a JPG image.(Citation: Unit 42 Playbook Dec 2017)(Citation: Talos Seduploader Oct 2017)

JHUHUGIT.name: Scheduled Task
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has registered itself as a scheduled task to run each time the current user logs in.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)(Citation: ESET Sednit July 2015)

JHUHUGIT.name: Windows Service
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has registered itself as a service to establish persistence.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)

JHUHUGIT.name: Web Protocols
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variants have communicated with C2 servers over HTTP and HTTPS.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)(Citation: Unit 42 Sofacy Feb 2018)(Citation: Unit 42 Playbook Dec 2017)

JHUHUGIT.name: Windows Command Shell
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) uses a .bat file to execute a .dll.(Citation: Talos Seduploader Oct 2017)

JHUHUGIT.name: Logon Script (Windows)
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has registered a Windows shell script under the Registry key HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript to establish persistence.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)(Citation: Talos Seduploader Oct 2017)

JHUHUGIT.name: Standard Encoding
JHUHUGIT.description: A [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant encodes C2 POST data base64.(Citation: Unit 42 Playbook Dec 2017)

JHUHUGIT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
JHUHUGIT.description: Many strings in [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) are obfuscated with a XOR algorithm.(Citation: F-Secure Sofacy 2015)(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)(Citation: Talos Seduploader Oct 2017)

JHUHUGIT.name: Fallback Channels
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) tests if it can reach its C2 server by first attempting a direct connection, and if it fails, obtaining proxy settings and sending the connection through a proxy, and finally injecting code into a running browser if the proxy method fails.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)

JHUHUGIT.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has exploited CVE-2015-1701 and CVE-2015-2387 to escalate privileges.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)(Citation: ESET Sednit July 2015)

JHUHUGIT.name: Process Discovery
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) obtains a list of running processes on the victim.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1)(Citation: Unit 42 Sofacy Feb 2018)

Dok.name: Install Root Certificate
Dok.description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) installs a root certificate to aid in man-in-the-middle actions.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

Dok.name: Multi-hop Proxy
Dok.description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) downloads and installs Tor via homebrew.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

Dok.name: Plist Modification
Dok.description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) persists via a plist login item.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

Dok.name: GUI Input Capture
Dok.description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) prompts the user for credentials.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

Dok.name: AppleScript
Dok.description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) uses AppleScript to create a login item for persistence.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

Dok.name: Launch Agent
Dok.description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) persists via a Launch Agent.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

NanHaiShu.name: Mshta
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) uses mshta.exe to load its program and files.(Citation: fsecure NanHaiShu July 2016)

NanHaiShu.name: File Deletion
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) launches a script to delete their original decoy file to cover tracks.(Citation: fsecure NanHaiShu July 2016)

NanHaiShu.name: Disable or Modify Tools
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) can change Internet Explorer settings to reduce warnings about malware activity.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

NanHaiShu.name: System Information Discovery
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) can gather the victim computer name and serial number.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

NanHaiShu.name: System Owner/User Discovery
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) collects the username from the victim.(Citation: fsecure NanHaiShu July 2016)

NanHaiShu.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) encodes files in Base64.(Citation: fsecure NanHaiShu July 2016)

NanHaiShu.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) modifies the %regrun% Registry to point itself to an autostart mechanism.(Citation: fsecure NanHaiShu July 2016)

NanHaiShu.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) can download additional files from URLs.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

NanHaiShu.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) can gather information about the victim proxy server.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

NanHaiShu.name: Visual Basic
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) executes additional VBScript code on the victim's machine.(Citation: fsecure NanHaiShu July 2016)

NanHaiShu.name: DNS
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) uses DNS for the C2 communications.(Citation: fsecure NanHaiShu July 2016)

NanHaiShu.name: JavaScript/JScript
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) executes additional Jscript code on the victim's machine.(Citation: fsecure NanHaiShu July 2016)

POWERSTATS.name: File Deletion
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can delete all files on the C:\, D:\, E:\ and, F:\ drives using [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) Remove-Item commands.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Uncommonly Used Port
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has used ports 8060 and 8888 for C2.(Citation: Unit 42 MuddyWater Nov 2017)

POWERSTATS.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can deobfuscate the main backdoor code.(Citation: ClearSky MuddyWater Nov 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Mshta
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can use Mshta.exe to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) uses character replacement, [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) environment variables, and XOR encoding to obfuscate code. [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223)'s backdoor code is a multi-layer obfuscated, encoded, and compressed blob. (Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)(Citation: ClearSky MuddyWater Nov 2018) [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has used PowerShell code with custom string obfuscation (Citation: TrendMicro POWERSTATS V3 June 2019)

POWERSTATS.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can use WMI queries to retrieve data from compromised hosts.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)(Citation: ClearSky MuddyWater Nov 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Screen Capture
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can retrieve screenshots from compromised hosts.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)(Citation: TrendMicro POWERSTATS V3 June 2019)

POWERSTATS.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can use DDE to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: System Information Discovery
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can retrieve OS name/architecture and computer/domain name information from compromised hosts.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)(Citation: TrendMicro POWERSTATS V3 June 2019)

POWERSTATS.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can retrieve IP, network adapter configuration information, and domain from compromised hosts.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)(Citation: TrendMicro POWERSTATS V3 June 2019)

POWERSTATS.name: Visual Basic
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can use VBScript (VBE) code for execution.(Citation: ClearSky MuddyWater Nov 2018)(Citation: TrendMicro POWERSTATS V3 June 2019)

POWERSTATS.name: Scheduled Transfer
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can sleep for a given number of seconds.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Security Software Discovery
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has detected security tools.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Local Account
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can retrieve usernames from compromised hosts.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: PowerShell
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) uses PowerShell for obfuscation and execution.(Citation: Unit 42 MuddyWater Nov 2017)(Citation: ClearSky MuddyWater Nov 2018)(Citation: TrendMicro POWERSTATS V3 June 2019)

POWERSTATS.name: Scheduled Task
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has established persistence through a scheduled task using the command ”C:\Windows\system32\schtasks.exe” /Create /F /SC DAILY /ST 12:00 /TN MicrosoftEdge /TR “c:\Windows\system32\wscript.exe C:\Windows\temp\Windows.vbe”.(Citation: ClearSky MuddyWater Nov 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: External Proxy
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has connected to C2 servers through proxies.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has encrypted C2 traffic with RSA.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Component Object Model
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can use DCOM (targeting the 127.0.0.1 loopback address) to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Masquerade Task or Service
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has created a scheduled task named "MicrosoftEdge" to establish persistence.(Citation: ClearSky MuddyWater Nov 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can retrieve and execute additional [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) payloads from the C2 server.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Commonly Used Port
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has used port 80 for C2.(Citation: Unit 42 MuddyWater Nov 2017)

POWERSTATS.name: Standard Encoding
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) encoded C2 traffic with base64.(Citation: Unit 42 MuddyWater Nov 2017)

POWERSTATS.name: Disable or Modify Tools
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can disable Microsoft Office Protected View by changing Registry keys.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Data from Local System
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can upload files from compromised hosts.(Citation: FireEye MuddyWater Mar 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: JavaScript/JScript
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can use JavaScript code for execution.(Citation: ClearSky MuddyWater Nov 2018)

POWERSTATS.name: Process Discovery
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has used get_tasklist to discover processes on the compromised host.(Citation: TrendMicro POWERSTATS V3 June 2019)

POWERSTATS.name: System Owner/User Discovery
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has the ability to identify the username on the compromised host.(Citation: TrendMicro POWERSTATS V3 June 2019)

POWERSTATS.name: Binary Padding
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has used useless code blocks to counter analysis.(Citation: TrendMicro POWERSTATS V3 June 2019)

PoisonIvy.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) can inject a malicious DLL into a process.(Citation: FireEye Poison Ivy)(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

PoisonIvy.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can upload files.(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

PoisonIvy.name: Modify Registry
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a Registry subkey that registers a new system device.(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

PoisonIvy.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates run key Registry entries pointing to a malicious executable dropped to disk.(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

PoisonIvy.name: Rootkit
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) starts a rootkit from a malicious file dropped to disk.(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

PoisonIvy.name: Symmetric Cryptography
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) uses the Camellia cipher to encrypt communications.(Citation: FireEye Poison Ivy)

PoisonIvy.name: Local Data Staging
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) stages collected data in a text file.(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

PoisonIvy.name: Keylogging
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) contains a keylogger.(Citation: FireEye Poison Ivy)(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

PoisonIvy.name: Uncommonly Used Port
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) opens a backdoor on TCP ports 6868 and 7777.(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

PoisonIvy.name: Data from Local System
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can steal system information.(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

PoisonIvy.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) hides any strings related to its own indicators of compromise.(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

PoisonIvy.name: Windows Command Shell
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can open a command-line interface.(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

PoisonIvy.name: Application Window Discovery
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) captures window titles.(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

PoisonIvy.name: Windows Service
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a Registry subkey that registers a new service. [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) also creates a Registry entry modifying the Logical Disk Manager service to point to a malicious DLL dropped to disk.(Citation: Symantec Darkmoon Aug 2005)

Daserf.name: Code Signing
Daserf.description: Some [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) samples were signed with a stolen digital certificate.(Citation: Symantec Tick Apr 2016)

Daserf.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) can download remote files.(Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017)(Citation: Secureworks BRONZE BUTLER Oct 2017)

Daserf.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses RC4 encryption to obfuscate HTTP traffic.(Citation: Secureworks BRONZE BUTLER Oct 2017)

Daserf.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Daserf.description: Analysis of [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) has shown that it regularly undergoes technical improvements to evade anti-virus detection.(Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017)

Daserf.name: Steganography
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) can use steganography to hide malicious code downloaded to the victim.(Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017)

Daserf.name: Archive Collected Data
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) hides collected data in password-protected .rar archives.(Citation: Symantec Tick Apr 2016)

Daserf.name: Web Protocols
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses HTTP for C2.(Citation: Secureworks BRONZE BUTLER Oct 2017)

Daserf.name: Screen Capture
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) can take screenshots.(Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017)(Citation: Secureworks BRONZE BUTLER Oct 2017)

Daserf.name: Software Packing
Daserf.description: A version of [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses the MPRESS packer.(Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017)

Daserf.name: LSASS Memory
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) leverages [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) and [Windows Credential Editor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0005) to steal credentials.(Citation: Symantec Tick Apr 2016)

Daserf.name: Archive via Utility
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) hides collected data in password-protected .rar archives.(Citation: Symantec Tick Apr 2016)

Daserf.name: Windows Command Shell
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) can execute shell commands.(Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017)(Citation: Secureworks BRONZE BUTLER Oct 2017)

Daserf.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses file and folder names related to legitimate programs in order to blend in, such as HP, Intel, Adobe, and perflogs.(Citation: Symantec Tick Apr 2016)

Daserf.name: Keylogging
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) can log keystrokes.(Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017)(Citation: Secureworks BRONZE BUTLER Oct 2017)

Daserf.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses encrypted Windows APIs and also encrypts data using the alternative base64+RC4 or the Caesar cipher.(Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017)

Daserf.name: Standard Encoding
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses custom base64 encoding to obfuscate HTTP traffic.(Citation: Secureworks BRONZE BUTLER Oct 2017)

PowerDuke.name: System Information Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has commands to get information about the victim's name, build, version, serial number, and memory usage.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: Process Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to list the victim's processes.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: NTFS File Attributes
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) hides many of its backdoor payloads in an alternate data stream (ADS).(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to download a file.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) achieves persistence by using various Registry Run keys.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to get the victim's domain and NetBIOS name.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: Application Window Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to get text of the current foreground window.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: Rundll32
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) uses rundll32.exe to load.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: System Owner/User Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has commands to get the current user's name and SID.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: Windows Command Shell
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) runs cmd.exe /c and sends the output to its C2.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: File Deletion
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to write random data across a file and delete it.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: File and Directory Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has commands to get the current directory name as well as the size of a file. It also has commands to obtain information about logical drives, drive type, and free space.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: Commonly Used Port
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) connects over 443 for C2.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: System Time Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has commands to get the time the machine was built, the time, and the time zone.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: Data Destruction
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to write random data across a file and delete it.(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

PowerDuke.name: Steganography
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) uses steganography to hide backdoors in PNG files, which are also encrypted using the Tiny Encryption Algorithm (TEA).(Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)

Sykipot.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may use ipconfig /all to gather system network configuration details.(Citation: AlienVault Sykipot 2011)

Sykipot.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) injects itself into running instances of outlook.exe, iexplore.exe, or firefox.exe.(Citation: AlienVault Sykipot 2011)

Sykipot.name: Keylogging
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) contains keylogging functionality to steal passwords.(Citation: Alienvault Sykipot DOD Smart Cards)

Sykipot.name: Process Discovery
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may gather a list of running processes by running tasklist /v.(Citation: AlienVault Sykipot 2011)

Sykipot.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may use netstat -ano to display active network connections.(Citation: AlienVault Sykipot 2011)

Sykipot.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) uses SSL for encrypting C2 communications.(Citation: Blasco 2013)

Sykipot.name: Two-Factor Authentication Interception
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) is known to contain functionality that enables targeting of smart card technologies to proxy authentication for connections to restricted network resources using detected hardware tokens.(Citation: Alienvault Sykipot DOD Smart Cards)

Sykipot.name: Remote System Discovery
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may use net view /domain to display hostnames of available systems on a network.(Citation: AlienVault Sykipot 2011)

Sykipot.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) has been known to establish persistence by adding programs to the Run Registry key.(Citation: Blasco 2013)

Sykipot.name: Domain Account
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may use net group "domain admins" /domain to display accounts in the "domain admins" permissions group and net localgroup "administrators" to list local system administrator group membership.(Citation: AlienVault Sykipot 2011)

Sykipot.name: System Service Discovery
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may use net start to display running services.(Citation: AlienVault Sykipot 2011)

WINERACK.name: Application Window Discovery
WINERACK.description: [WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can enumerate active windows.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

WINERACK.name: Process Discovery
WINERACK.description: [WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can enumerate processes.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

WINERACK.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
WINERACK.description: [WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can create a reverse shell that utilizes statically-linked Wine cmd.exe code to emulate Windows command prompt commands.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

WINERACK.name: System Information Discovery
WINERACK.description: [WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can gather information about the host.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

WINERACK.name: File and Directory Discovery
WINERACK.description: [WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can enumerate files and directories.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

WINERACK.name: System Owner/User Discovery
WINERACK.description: [WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can gather information on the victim username.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

WINERACK.name: System Service Discovery
WINERACK.description: [WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can enumerate services.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

MobileOrder.name: System Information Discovery
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) has a command to upload to its C2 server victim mobile device information, including IMEI, IMSI, SIM card serial number, phone number, Android version, and other information.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

MobileOrder.name: Uncommonly Used Port
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) communicates with its C2 server over TCP port 3728.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

MobileOrder.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) uses AES to encrypt C2 communications.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

MobileOrder.name: Data from Local System
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) exfiltrates data collected from the victim mobile device.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

MobileOrder.name: Browser Bookmark Discovery
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) has a command to upload to its C2 server victim browser bookmarks.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

MobileOrder.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) exfiltrates data to its C2 server over the same protocol as C2 communications.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

MobileOrder.name: Process Discovery
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) has a command to upload information about all running processes to its C2 server.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

MobileOrder.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) has a command to download a file from the C2 server to the victim mobile device's SD card.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

MobileOrder.name: File and Directory Discovery
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) has a command to upload to its C2 server information about files on the victim mobile device, including SD card size, installed app list, SMS content, contacts, and calling history.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

Psylo.name: Web Protocols
Psylo.description: [Psylo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0078) uses HTTPS for C2.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

Psylo.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Psylo.description: [Psylo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0078) has a command to download a file to the system from its C2 server.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

Psylo.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Psylo.description: [Psylo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0078) exfiltrates data to its C2 server over the same protocol as C2 communications.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

Psylo.name: File and Directory Discovery
Psylo.description: [Psylo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0078) has commands to enumerate all storage devices and to find all files that start with a particular string.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

Psylo.name: Timestomp
Psylo.description: [Psylo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0078) has a command to conduct timestomping by setting a specified file’s timestamps to match those of a system file in the System32 directory.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

Pisloader.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) establishes persistence via a Registry Run key.(Citation: Palo Alto DNS Requests)

Pisloader.name: Standard Encoding
Pisloader.description: Responses from the [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) C2 server are base32-encoded.(Citation: Palo Alto DNS Requests)

Pisloader.name: DNS
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) uses DNS as its C2 protocol.(Citation: Palo Alto DNS Requests)

Pisloader.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) has a command to upload a file to the victim machine.(Citation: Palo Alto DNS Requests)

Pisloader.name: Windows Command Shell
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) uses cmd.exe to set the Registry Run key value. It also has a command to spawn a command shell.(Citation: Palo Alto DNS Requests)

Pisloader.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) has a command to collect the victim's IP address.(Citation: Palo Alto DNS Requests)

Pisloader.name: File and Directory Discovery
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) has commands to list drives on the victim machine and to list file information for a given directory.(Citation: Palo Alto DNS Requests)

Pisloader.name: System Information Discovery
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) has a command to collect victim system information, including the system name and OS version.(Citation: Palo Alto DNS Requests)

Pisloader.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) obfuscates files by splitting strings into smaller sub-strings and including "garbage" strings that are never used. The malware also uses return-oriented programming (ROP) technique and single-byte XOR to obfuscate data.(Citation: Palo Alto DNS Requests)

Volgmer.name: Query Registry
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) checks the system for certain Registry keys.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)

Volgmer.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) uses a custom binary protocol to beacon back to its C2 server. It has also used XOR for encrypting communications.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)

Volgmer.name: Modify Registry
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) stores the encoded configuration file in the Registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\WMI\Security.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)(Citation: Symantec Volgmer Aug 2014)

Volgmer.name: Native API
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) executes payloads using the Windows API call CreateProcessW().(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)

Volgmer.name: System Service Discovery
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) queries the system to identify existing services.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)

Volgmer.name: Windows Command Shell
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can execute commands on the victim's machine.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)

Volgmer.name: Commonly Used Port
Volgmer.description: Some [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variants use ports 8080 and 8000 for C2.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)(Citation: Symantec Volgmer Aug 2014)

Volgmer.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
Volgmer.description: Some [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variants use SSL to encrypt C2 communications.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)

Volgmer.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can gather the IP address from the victim's machine.(Citation: Symantec Volgmer Aug 2014)

Volgmer.name: System Information Discovery
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can gather system information, the computer name, OS version, drive and serial information from the victim's machine.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)(Citation: Symantec Volgmer Aug 2014)

Volgmer.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) uses a simple XOR cipher to encrypt traffic and files.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)

Volgmer.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Volgmer.description: A [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variant is encoded using a simple XOR cipher.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)

Volgmer.name: File and Directory Discovery
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can list directories on a victim.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)

Volgmer.name: Process Discovery
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can gather a list of processes.(Citation: Symantec Volgmer Aug 2014)

Volgmer.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can download remote files and additional payloads to the victim's machine.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)(Citation: Symantec Volgmer Aug 2014)

Volgmer.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Volgmer.description: Some [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variants use port 8088 for C2.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)(Citation: Symantec Volgmer Aug 2014)

Volgmer.name: File Deletion
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can delete files and itself after infection to avoid analysis.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)

Volgmer.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) deobfuscates its strings and APIs once its executed.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)

Volgmer.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can gather information about TCP connection state.(Citation: Symantec Volgmer Aug 2014)

Volgmer.name: Masquerade Task or Service
Volgmer.description: Some [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variants add new services with display names generated by a list of hard-coded strings such as Application, Background, Security, and Windows, presumably as a way to masquerade as a legitimate service.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)(Citation: Symantec Volgmer Aug 2014)

Volgmer.name: Windows Service
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) installs a copy of itself in a randomly selected service, then overwrites the ServiceDLL entry in the service's Registry entry. Some [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variants also install .dll files as services with names generated by a list of hard-coded strings.(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)(Citation: US-CERT Volgmer 2 Nov 2017)(Citation: Symantec Volgmer Aug 2014)

FELIXROOT.name: Web Protocols
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) uses HTTP and HTTPS to communicate with the C2 server.(Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Query Registry
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) queries the Registry for specific keys for potential privilege escalation and proxy information. [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) has also used WMI to query the Windows Registry.(Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) encrypts strings in the backdoor using a custom XOR algorithm.(Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) uses WMI to query the Windows Registry.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) collects information about the network including the IP address and DHCP server.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Commonly Used Port
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) uses Port Numbers 443, 8443, and 8080 for C2 communications.(Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: System Time Discovery
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) gathers the time zone information from the victim’s machine.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: File Deletion
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) deletes the .LNK file from the startup directory as well as the dropper components.(Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) collects the username from the victim’s machine.(Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: System Information Discovery
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) collects the victim’s computer name, processor architecture, OS version, volume serial number, and system type.(Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) adds a shortcut file to the startup folder for persistence.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Rundll32
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) uses Rundll32 for executing the dropper program.(Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Shortcut Modification
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) creates a .LNK file for persistence.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Process Discovery
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) collects a list of running processes.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Modify Registry
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) deletes the Registry key HKCU\Software\Classes\Applications\rundll32.exe\shell\open.(Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Windows Command Shell
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) executes batch scripts on the victim’s machine, and can launch a reverse shell for command execution.(Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Archive Collected Data
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) encrypts collected data with AES and Base64 and then sends it to the C2 server.(Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) downloads and uploads files to and from the victim’s machine.(Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

FELIXROOT.name: Security Software Discovery
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) checks for installed security software like antivirus and firewall.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

adbupd.name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
adbupd.description: [adbupd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0202) can use a WMI script to achieve persistence.(Citation: Microsoft PLATINUM April 2016)

adbupd.name: Windows Command Shell
adbupd.description: [adbupd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0202) can run a copy of cmd.exe.(Citation: Microsoft PLATINUM April 2016)

adbupd.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
adbupd.description: [adbupd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0202) contains a copy of the OpenSSL library to encrypt C2 traffic.(Citation: Microsoft PLATINUM April 2016)

RIPTIDE.name: Symmetric Cryptography
RIPTIDE.description: [APT12](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0005) has used the [RIPTIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0003) RAT, which communicates over HTTP with a payload encrypted with RC4.(Citation: Moran 2014)

RIPTIDE.name: Web Protocols
RIPTIDE.description: [APT12](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0005) has used [RIPTIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0003), a RAT that uses HTTP to communicate.(Citation: Moran 2014)

RIPTIDE.name: Commonly Used Port
RIPTIDE.description: [RIPTIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0003) is a RAT that communicates with HTTP.(Citation: Moran 2014)

CallMe.name: Symmetric Cryptography
CallMe.description: [CallMe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0077) uses AES to encrypt C2 traffic.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

CallMe.name: Unix Shell
CallMe.description: [CallMe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0077) has the capability to create a reverse shell on victims.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

CallMe.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
CallMe.description: [CallMe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0077) exfiltrates data to its C2 server over the same protocol as C2 communications.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

CallMe.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
CallMe.description: [CallMe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0077) has the capability to download a file to the victim from the C2 server.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

TYPEFRAME.name: File Deletion
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can delete files off the system.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: System Information Discovery
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can gather the disk volume information.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Proxy
TYPEFRAME.description: A [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variant can force the compromised system to function as a proxy server.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Commonly Used Port
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variants can use ports 443, 8443, and 8080 for communications.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Malicious File
TYPEFRAME.description: A Word document delivering [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) prompts the user to enable macro execution.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Visual Basic
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) has used a malicious Word document for delivery with VBA macros for execution.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can open the Windows Firewall on the victim’s machine to allow incoming connections.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
TYPEFRAME.description: A [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variant uses fake TLS to communicate with the C2 server.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can upload and download files to the victim’s machine.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: File and Directory Discovery
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can search directories for files on the victim’s machine.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Modify Registry
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can install encrypted configuration data under the Registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\ShellCompatibility\Applications\laxhost.dll and HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\PrintConfigs.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Uncommonly Used Port
TYPEFRAME.description: A [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variant can use port 127 for communications.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
TYPEFRAME.description: APIs and strings in some [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variants are RC4 encrypted. Another variant is encoded with XOR.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
TYPEFRAME.description: One [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variant decrypts an archive using an RC4 key, then decompresses and installs the decrypted malicious DLL module.
