Another variant decodes the embedded file by XORing it with the value "0x35".(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Windows Command Shell
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can uninstall malware components using a batch script.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018) [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can execute commands using a shell.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Windows Service
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variants can add malicious DLL modules as new services.[TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can also delete services from the victim’s machine.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

TYPEFRAME.name: Non-Standard Port
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) has used ports 443, 8080, and 8443 with a FakeTLS method.(Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)

MirageFox.name: System Information Discovery
MirageFox.description: [MirageFox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0280) can collect CPU and architecture information from the victim’s machine.(Citation: APT15 Intezer June 2018)

MirageFox.name: Commonly Used Port
MirageFox.description: [MirageFox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0280) uses port 80 for C2.(Citation: APT15 Intezer June 2018)

MirageFox.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
MirageFox.description: [MirageFox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0280) has a function for decrypting data containing C2 configuration information.(Citation: APT15 Intezer June 2018)

MirageFox.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
MirageFox.description: [MirageFox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0280) is likely loaded via DLL hijacking into a legitimate McAfee binary.(Citation: APT15 Intezer June 2018)

MirageFox.name: System Owner/User Discovery
MirageFox.description: [MirageFox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0280) can gather the username from the victim’s machine.(Citation: APT15 Intezer June 2018)

MirageFox.name: Windows Command Shell
MirageFox.description: [MirageFox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0280) has the capability to execute commands using cmd.exe.(Citation: APT15 Intezer June 2018)

Net Crawler.name: LSASS Memory
Net Crawler.description: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) uses credential dumpers such as [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) and [Windows Credential Editor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0005) to extract cached credentials from Windows systems.(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

Net Crawler.name: Password Cracking
Net Crawler.description: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) uses a list of known credentials gathered through credential dumping to guess passwords to accounts as it spreads throughout a network.(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

Net Crawler.name: Service Execution
Net Crawler.description: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) uses [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to perform remote service manipulation to execute a copy of itself as part of lateral movement.(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

Net Crawler.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
Net Crawler.description: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) uses Windows admin shares to establish authenticated sessions to remote systems over SMB as part of lateral movement.(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

4H RAT.name: System Information Discovery
4H RAT.description: [4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) sends an OS version identifier in its beacons.(Citation: CrowdStrike Putter Panda)

4H RAT.name: Symmetric Cryptography
4H RAT.description: [4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) obfuscates C2 communication using a 1-byte XOR with the key 0xBE.(Citation: CrowdStrike Putter Panda)

4H RAT.name: Web Protocols
4H RAT.description: [4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) uses HTTP for command and control.(Citation: CrowdStrike Putter Panda)

4H RAT.name: Process Discovery
4H RAT.description: [4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) has the capability to obtain a listing of running processes (including loaded modules).(Citation: CrowdStrike Putter Panda)

4H RAT.name: Windows Command Shell
4H RAT.description: [4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) has the capability to create a remote shell.(Citation: CrowdStrike Putter Panda)

4H RAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
4H RAT.description: [4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) has the capability to obtain file and directory listings.(Citation: CrowdStrike Putter Panda)

RedLeaves.name: System Owner/User Discovery
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can obtain information about the logged on user both locally and for Remote Desktop sessions.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)

RedLeaves.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can communicate to its C2 over TCP using a custom binary protocol.(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)

RedLeaves.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) is launched through use of DLL search order hijacking to load a malicious dll.(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)

RedLeaves.name: File Deletion
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can delete specified files.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)

RedLeaves.name: System Information Discovery
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can gather extended system information including the hostname, OS version number, platform, memory information, time elapsed since system startup, and CPU information.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)(Citation: Accenture Hogfish April 2018)

RedLeaves.name: Symmetric Cryptography
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) has encrypted C2 traffic with RC4, previously using keys of 88888888 and babybear.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)

RedLeaves.name: Screen Capture
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can capture screenshots.(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)(Citation: Accenture Hogfish April 2018)

RedLeaves.name: File and Directory Discovery
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can enumerate and search for files and directories.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)

RedLeaves.name: Windows Command Shell
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can receive and execute commands with cmd.exe. It can also provide a reverse shell.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)

RedLeaves.name: Web Protocols
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can communicate to its C2 over HTTP and HTTPS if directed.(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)(Citation: Accenture Hogfish April 2018)

RedLeaves.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can gather browser usernames and passwords.(Citation: Accenture Hogfish April 2018)

RedLeaves.name: Uncommonly Used Port
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can use port 995 for C2.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)

RedLeaves.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) attempts to add a shortcut file in the Startup folder to achieve persistence. If this fails, it attempts to add Registry Run keys.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)(Citation: Accenture Hogfish April 2018)

RedLeaves.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) is capable of downloading a file from a specified URL.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)

RedLeaves.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
RedLeaves.description: A [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) configuration file is encrypted with a simple XOR key, 0x53.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)

RedLeaves.name: Shortcut Modification
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) attempts to add a shortcut file in the Startup folder to achieve persistence.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)(Citation: Accenture Hogfish April 2018)

RedLeaves.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can obtain information about network parameters.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)

RedLeaves.name: Commonly Used Port
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) uses a specific port of 443 and can also use ports 53 and 80 for C2. One [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) variant uses HTTP over port 443 to connect to its C2 server.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)(Citation: Accenture Hogfish April 2018)

RedLeaves.name: System Network Connections Discovery
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can enumerate drives and Remote Desktop sessions.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)

RedLeaves.name: Non-Standard Port
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can use HTTP over non-standard ports, such as 995, for C2.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)

PLAINTEE.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) uses a custom UDP protocol to communicate.(Citation: Rancor Unit42 June 2018)

PLAINTEE.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) uses the ipconfig /all command to gather the victim’s IP address.(Citation: Rancor Unit42 June 2018)

PLAINTEE.name: Modify Registry
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) uses reg add to add a Registry Run key for persistence.(Citation: Rancor Unit42 June 2018)

PLAINTEE.name: Process Discovery
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) performs the tasklist command to list running processes.(Citation: Rancor Unit42 June 2018)

PLAINTEE.name: Bypass User Access Control
PLAINTEE.description: An older variant of [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) performs UAC bypass.(Citation: Rancor Unit42 June 2018)

PLAINTEE.name: Symmetric Cryptography
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) encodes C2 beacons using XOR.(Citation: Rancor Unit42 June 2018)

PLAINTEE.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) gains persistence by adding the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce.(Citation: Rancor Unit42 June 2018)

PLAINTEE.name: System Information Discovery
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) collects general system enumeration data about the infected machine and checks the OS version.(Citation: Rancor Unit42 June 2018)

PLAINTEE.name: Windows Command Shell
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) uses cmd.exe to execute commands on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Rancor Unit42 June 2018)

PLAINTEE.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) has downloaded and executed additional plugins.(Citation: Rancor Unit42 June 2018)

POWRUNER.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect network configuration data by running ipconfig /all on a victim.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: PowerShell
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) is written in PowerShell.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: File and Directory Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may enumerate user directories on a victim.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Query Registry
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may query the Registry by running reg query on a victim.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Process Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect process information by running tasklist on a victim.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Domain Account
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect user account information by running net user /domain or a series of other commands on a victim.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Web Protocols
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) can use HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)(Citation: FireEye APT34 Webinar Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: System Network Connections Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect active network connections by running netstat -an on a victim.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Scheduled Task
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) persists through a scheduled task that executes it every minute.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Screen Capture
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) can capture a screenshot from a victim.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: System Owner/User Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect information about the currently logged in user by running whoami on a victim.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Domain Groups
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect domain group information by running net group /domain or a series of other commands on a victim.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may use WMI when collecting information about a victim.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Windows Command Shell
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) can execute commands from its C2 server.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) can download or upload files from its C2 server.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Security Software Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect information on the victim's anti-virus software.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Standard Encoding
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) can use base64 encoded C2 communications.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: System Information Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect information about the system by running hostname and systeminfo on a victim.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: DNS
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) can use DNS for C2 communications.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)(Citation: FireEye APT34 Webinar Dec 2017)

POWRUNER.name: Local Groups
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect local group information by running net localgroup administrators or a series of other commands on a victim.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)

KOMPROGO.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
KOMPROGO.description: [KOMPROGO](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0156) is capable of running WMI queries.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

KOMPROGO.name: Windows Command Shell
KOMPROGO.description: [KOMPROGO](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0156) is capable of creating a reverse shell.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

KOMPROGO.name: System Information Discovery
KOMPROGO.description: [KOMPROGO](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0156) is capable of retrieving information about the infected system.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

Misdat.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) network traffic communicates over a raw socket.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Misdat.name: Standard Encoding
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) network traffic is Base64-encoded plaintext.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Misdat.name: File and Directory Discovery
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is capable of running commands to obtain a list of files and directories, as well as enumerating logical drives.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Misdat.name: Indicator Removal on Host
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is capable of deleting Registry keys used for persistence.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Misdat.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is capable of downloading files from the C2.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Misdat.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) network traffic communicates over a raw socket.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Misdat.name: Timestomp
Misdat.description: Many [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) samples were programmed using Borland Delphi, which will mangle the default PE compile timestamp of a file.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Misdat.name: Windows Command Shell
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is capable of providing shell functionality to the attacker to execute commands.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Misdat.name: System Information Discovery
Misdat.description: The initial beacon packet for [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) contains the operating system version of the victim.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Misdat.name: Commonly Used Port
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) network traffic communicates over common ports like 80, 443, or 1433.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Misdat.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) saves itself as a file named msdtc.exe, which is also the name of the legitimate Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator service binary.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)(Citation: Microsoft DTC)

Misdat.name: File Deletion
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is capable of deleting the backdoor file.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

GravityRAT.name: Windows Command Shell
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) executes commands remotely on the infected host.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) has been delivered via Word documents using DDE for execution.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: Web Protocols
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) uses HTTP for C2.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
GravityRAT.description: The author of [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) submitted samples to VirusTotal for testing, showing that the author modified the code to try to hide the DDE object in a different part of the document.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: Data from Removable Media
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) steals files based on an extension list if a USB drive is connected to the system.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: Scheduled Task
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) creates a scheduled task to ensure it is re-executed everyday.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) collects various information via WMI requests, including CPU information in the Win32_Processor entry (Processor ID, Name, Manufacturer and the clock speed).(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: System Service Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) has a feature to list the available services on the system.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) collects the victim username along with other account information (account type, description, full name, SID and status).(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: Uncommonly Used Port
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) uses port 46769 for C2.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: Data from Local System
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) steals files with the following extensions: .docx, .doc, .pptx, .ppt, .xlsx, .xls, .rtf, and .pdf.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: Process Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) lists the running processes on the system.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) collects the victim IP address, MAC address, as well as the victim account domain name.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) collects the volumes mapped on the system, and also steals files with the following extensions: .docx, .doc, .pptx, .ppt, .xlsx, .xls, .rtf, and .pdf.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: System Information Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) collects the MAC address, computer name, and CPU information.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: System Time Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) can obtain the date and time of a system.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) supports file encryption (AES with the key "lolomycin2017").(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: System Network Connections Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) uses the netstat command to find open ports on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: System Checks
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) uses WMI to check the BIOS and manufacturer information for strings like "VMWare", "Virtual", and "XEN" and another WMI request to get the current temperature of the hardware to determine if it's a virtual machine environment. (Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

GravityRAT.name: Non-Standard Port
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) has used HTTP over a non-standard port, such as TCP port 46769.(Citation: Talos GravityRAT)

BS2005.name: Standard Encoding
BS2005.description: [BS2005](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0014) uses Base64 encoding for communication in the message body of an HTTP request.(Citation: Villeneuve et al 2014)

HAPPYWORK.name: System Owner/User Discovery
HAPPYWORK.description: can collect the victim user name.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

HAPPYWORK.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
HAPPYWORK.description: can download and execute a second-stage payload.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

HAPPYWORK.name: System Information Discovery
HAPPYWORK.description: can collect system information, including computer name, system manufacturer, IsDebuggerPresent state, and execution path.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

HDoor.name: Disable or Modify Tools
HDoor.description: [HDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0061) kills anti-virus found on the victim.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

HDoor.name: Network Service Scanning
HDoor.description: [HDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0061) scans to identify open ports on the victim.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

Prikormka.name: Keylogging
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) contains a keylogger module that collects keystrokes and the titles of foreground windows.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) gathers logins and passwords stored in applications on the victims, including Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, and several other browsers.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Prikormka.description: Some resources in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) are encrypted with a simple XOR operation or encoded with Base64.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Archive Collected Data
Prikormka.description: After collecting documents from removable media, [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) compresses the collected files, and encrypts it with Blowfish.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Standard Encoding
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) encodes C2 traffic with Base64.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Data from Removable Media
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) contains a module that collects documents with certain extensions from removable media or fixed drives connected via USB.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Indicator Removal on Host
Prikormka.description: After encrypting its own log files, the log encryption module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) deletes the original, unencrypted files from the host.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) adds itself to a Registry Run key with the name guidVGA or guidVSA.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Local Data Staging
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) creates a directory, %USERPROFILE%\AppData\Local\SKC\, which is used to store collected log files.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) uses DLL search order hijacking for persistence by saving itself as ntshrui.dll to the Windows directory so it will load before the legitimate ntshrui.dll saved in the System32 subdirectory.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information from the victim about its IP addresses and MAC addresses.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: File and Directory Discovery
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information about the paths, size, and creation time of files with specific file extensions, but not the actual content of the file.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) encrypts some C2 traffic with the Blowfish cipher.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Security Software Discovery
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information from the victim about installed anti-virus software.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Rundll32
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) uses rundll32.exe to load its DLL.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Screen Capture
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) contains a module that captures screenshots of the victim's desktop.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: System Information Discovery
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information from the victim about Windows OS version, computer name, battery info, and physical memory.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information on available printers and disk drives.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information from the victim about the current user name.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

Prikormka.name: Credentials from Password Stores
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects passwords stored in applications installed on the victim.(Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)

SHOTPUT.name: Process Discovery
SHOTPUT.description: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) has a command to obtain a process listing.(Citation: Palo Alto CVE-2015-3113 July 2015)

SHOTPUT.name: Remote System Discovery
SHOTPUT.description: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) has a command to list all servers in the domain, as well as one to locate domain controllers on a domain.(Citation: Palo Alto CVE-2015-3113 July 2015)

SHOTPUT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
SHOTPUT.description: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) is obscured using XOR encoding and appended to a valid GIF file.(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Wolf)(Citation: Palo Alto CVE-2015-3113 July 2015)

SHOTPUT.name: File and Directory Discovery
SHOTPUT.description: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) has a command to obtain a directory listing.(Citation: Palo Alto CVE-2015-3113 July 2015)

SHOTPUT.name: Local Account
SHOTPUT.description: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) has a command to retrieve information about connected users.(Citation: Palo Alto CVE-2015-3113 July 2015)

SHOTPUT.name: System Network Connections Discovery
SHOTPUT.description: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) uses [netstat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0104) to list TCP connection status.(Citation: Palo Alto CVE-2015-3113 July 2015)

Nidiran.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Nidiran.description: [Nidiran](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0118) uses RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.(Citation: Symantec Suckfly May 2016)

Nidiran.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Nidiran.description: [Nidiran](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0118) can download and execute files.(Citation: Symantec Backdoor.Nidiran)

Nidiran.name: Masquerade Task or Service
Nidiran.description: [Nidiran](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0118) can create a new service named msamger (Microsoft Security Accounts Manager), which mimics the legitimate Microsoft database by the same name.(Citation: Symantec Backdoor.Nidiran)(Citation: Microsoft SAM)

Nidiran.name: Windows Service
Nidiran.description: [Nidiran](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0118) can create a new service named msamger (Microsoft Security Accounts Manager).(Citation: Symantec Backdoor.Nidiran)

Nidiran.name: Commonly Used Port
Nidiran.description: [Nidiran](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0118) communicates with its C2 domain over ports 443 and 8443.(Citation: Symantec Suckfly May 2016)

SPACESHIP.name: Exfiltration over USB
SPACESHIP.description: [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) copies staged data to removable drives when they are inserted into the system.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

SPACESHIP.name: Local Data Staging
SPACESHIP.description: [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) identifies files with certain extensions and copies them to a directory in the user's profile.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

SPACESHIP.name: File and Directory Discovery
SPACESHIP.description: [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) identifies files and directories for collection by searching for specific file extensions or file modification time.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

SPACESHIP.name: Archive via Custom Method
SPACESHIP.description: Data [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) copies to the staging area is compressed with zlib. Bytes are rotated by four positions and XOR'ed with 0x23.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

SPACESHIP.name: Shortcut Modification
SPACESHIP.description: [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the current user's Startup folder.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

SPACESHIP.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
SPACESHIP.description: [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the current user's Startup folder.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

InnaputRAT.name: Windows Service
InnaputRAT.description: Some [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) variants create a new Windows service to establish persistence.(Citation: ASERT InnaputRAT April 2018)

InnaputRAT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) uses an 8-byte XOR key to obfuscate API names and other strings contained in the payload.(Citation: ASERT InnaputRAT April 2018)

InnaputRAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) enumerates directories and obtains file attributes on a system.(Citation: ASERT InnaputRAT April 2018)

InnaputRAT.name: System Information Discovery
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) gathers volume drive information and system information.(Citation: ASERT InnaputRAT April 2018)

InnaputRAT.name: Windows Command Shell
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) launches a shell to execute commands on the victim’s machine.(Citation: ASERT InnaputRAT April 2018)

InnaputRAT.name: File Deletion
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) has a command to delete files.(Citation: ASERT InnaputRAT April 2018)

InnaputRAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
InnaputRAT.description: Some [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) variants establish persistence by modifying the Registry key HKU\\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run:%appdata%\NeutralApp\NeutralApp.exe.(Citation: ASERT InnaputRAT April 2018)

InnaputRAT.name: Uncommonly Used Port
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) uses port 52100 and 5876 for C2 communications.(Citation: ASERT InnaputRAT April 2018)

InnaputRAT.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) variants have attempted to appear legitimate by using the file names SafeApp.exe and NeutralApp.exe.(Citation: ASERT InnaputRAT April 2018)

InnaputRAT.name: Native API
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) uses the API call ShellExecuteW for execution.(Citation: ASERT InnaputRAT April 2018)

InnaputRAT.name: Masquerade Task or Service
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) variants have attempted to appear legitimate by adding a new service named OfficeUpdateService.(Citation: ASERT InnaputRAT April 2018)

HARDRAIN.name: Proxy
HARDRAIN.description: [HARDRAIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0246) uses the command cmd.exe /c netsh firewall add portopening TCP 443 "adp" and makes the victim machine function as a proxy server.(Citation: US-CERT HARDRAIN March 2018)

HARDRAIN.name: Windows Command Shell
HARDRAIN.description: [HARDRAIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0246) uses cmd.exe to execute netshcommands.(Citation: US-CERT HARDRAIN March 2018)

HARDRAIN.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
HARDRAIN.description: [HARDRAIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0246) opens the Windows Firewall to modify incoming connections.(Citation: US-CERT HARDRAIN March 2018)

HARDRAIN.name: Protocol Impersonation
HARDRAIN.description: [HARDRAIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0246) uses FakeTLS to communicate with its C2 server.(Citation: US-CERT HARDRAIN March 2018)

HARDRAIN.name: Commonly Used Port
HARDRAIN.description: [HARDRAIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0246) binds and listens on port 443.(Citation: US-CERT HARDRAIN March 2018)

HARDRAIN.name: Non-Standard Port
HARDRAIN.description: [HARDRAIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0246) binds and listens on port 443 with a FakeTLS method.(Citation: US-CERT HARDRAIN March 2018)

SEASHARPEE.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
SEASHARPEE.description: [SEASHARPEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0185) can download remote files onto victims.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Webinar Dec 2017)

SEASHARPEE.name: Windows Command Shell
SEASHARPEE.description: [SEASHARPEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0185) can execute commands on victims.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Webinar Dec 2017)

SEASHARPEE.name: Web Shell
SEASHARPEE.description: [SEASHARPEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0185) is a Web shell.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Webinar Dec 2017)

SEASHARPEE.name: Timestomp
SEASHARPEE.description: [SEASHARPEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0185) can timestomp files on victims using a Web shell.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Webinar Dec 2017)

Trojan.Karagany.name: Process Discovery
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can use tasklist to collect a list of running tasks.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Trojan.Karagany.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can create a link to itself in the Startup folder to automatically start itself upon system restart.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Trojan.Karagany.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can upload, download, and execute files on the victim.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Trojan.Karagany.name: Software Packing
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) samples sometimes use common binary packers such as UPX and Aspack on top of a custom Delphi binary packer.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Trojan.Karagany.name: OS Credential Dumping
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can dump passwords and save them into \ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\pwds.txt.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Trojan.Karagany.name: Local Data Staging
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can create a directory (C:\ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\gl) to use as a temporary directory for uploading files.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

Trojan.Karagany.name: Screen Capture
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can take a desktop screenshot and save the file into \ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\shot.png.(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)

NETEAGLE.name: Process Discovery
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) can send process listings over the C2 channel.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

NETEAGLE.name: Windows Command Shell
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) allows adversaries to execute shell commands on the infected host.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

NETEAGLE.name: Symmetric Cryptography
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will decrypt resources it downloads with HTTP requests by using RC4 with the key "ScoutEagle."(Citation: FireEye APT30)

NETEAGLE.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) is capable of reading files over the C2 channel.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

NETEAGLE.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
NETEAGLE.description: If [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) does not detect a proxy configured on the infected machine, it will send beacons via UDP/6000. Also, after retrieving a C2 IP address and Port Number, [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will initiate a TCP connection to this socket. The ensuing connection is a plaintext C2 channel in which commands are specified by DWORDs.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

NETEAGLE.name: Web Protocols
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will attempt to detect if the infected host is configured to a proxy. If so, [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will send beacons via an HTTP POST request. [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will also use HTTP to download resources that contain an IP address and Port Number pair to connect to for further C2.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

NETEAGLE.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
NETEAGLE.description: The "SCOUT" variant of [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) achieves persistence by adding itself to the HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run Registry key.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

NETEAGLE.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
NETEAGLE.description: If [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) does not detect a proxy configured on the infected machine, it will send beacons via UDP/6000. Also, after retrieving a C2 IP address and Port Number, [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will initiate a TCP connection to this socket. The ensuing connection is a plaintext C2 channel in which commands are specified by DWORDs.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

NETEAGLE.name: Fallback Channels
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will attempt to detect if the infected host is configured to a proxy. If so, [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will send beacons via an HTTP POST request; otherwise it will send beacons via UDP/6000.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

NETEAGLE.name: File and Directory Discovery
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) allows adversaries to enumerate and modify the infected host's file system. It supports searching for directories, creating directories, listing directory contents, reading and writing to files, retrieving file attributes, and retrieving volume information.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

NETEAGLE.name: Dynamic Resolution
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) can use HTTP to download resources that contain an IP address and port number pair to connect to for C2.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

NETEAGLE.name: Application Layer Protocol
NETEAGLE.description: Adversaries can also use [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) to establish an RDP connection with a controller over TCP/7519.

ZLib.name: Windows Command Shell
ZLib.description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) has the ability to execute shell commands.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

ZLib.name: System Information Discovery
ZLib.description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) has the ability to enumerate system information.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

ZLib.name: Screen Capture
ZLib.description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) has the ability to obtain screenshots of the compromised system.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

ZLib.name: Archive via Library
ZLib.description: The [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) backdoor compresses communications using the standard Zlib compression library.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

ZLib.name: File and Directory Discovery
ZLib.description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) has the ability to enumerate files and drives.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

ZLib.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
ZLib.description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) has the ability to download files.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

ZLib.name: Web Protocols
ZLib.description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) communicates over HTTP for C2.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

ZLib.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
ZLib.description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) mimics the resource version information of legitimate Realtek Semiconductor, Nvidia, or Synaptics modules.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

ZLib.name: Windows Service
ZLib.description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) creates Registry keys to allow itself to run as various services.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

ZLib.name: System Service Discovery
ZLib.description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) has the ability to discover and manipulate Windows services.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Orz.name: Regsvr32
Orz.description: Some [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) versions have an embedded DLL known as MockDll that uses [Process Hollowing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/012) and regsvr32 to execute another payload.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

Orz.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Orz.description: [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) can gather victim proxy information.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

Orz.name: Process Discovery
Orz.description: [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) can gather a process list from the victim.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

Orz.name: Indicator Removal on Host
Orz.description: [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) can overwrite Registry settings to reduce its visibility on the victim.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

Orz.name: File and Directory Discovery
Orz.description: [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) can gather victim drive information.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

Orz.name: Windows Command Shell
Orz.description: [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) can execute shell commands.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017) [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) can execute commands with JavaScript.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

Orz.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Orz.description: Some [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) strings are base64 encoded, such as the embedded DLL known as MockDll.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

Orz.name: Process Hollowing
Orz.description: Some [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) versions have an embedded DLL known as MockDll that uses process hollowing and [Regsvr32](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1117) to execute another payload.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

Orz.name: System Information Discovery
Orz.description: [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) can gather the victim OS version and whether it is 64 or 32 bit.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

Orz.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Orz.description: [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) can download files onto the victim.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

Orz.name: Bidirectional Communication
Orz.description: [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) has used Technet and Pastebin web pages for command and control.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

Orz.name: Software Discovery
Orz.description: [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) can gather the victim's Internet Explorer version.(Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017)

PlugX.name: Native API
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) can use the Windows API function CreateProcess to execute another process.(Citation: Lastline PlugX Analysis)

PlugX.name: Process Discovery
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) has a module to list the processes running on a machine.(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: Keylogging
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) has a module for capturing keystrokes per process including window titles.(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) decompresses and decrypts itself using the Microsoft API call RtlDecompressBuffer.(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: DLL Side-Loading
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) has used DLL side-loading to evade anti-virus.(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Fox Part 2)(Citation: Dell TG-3390)(Citation: Stewart 2014)(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)(Citation: Palo Alto PlugX June 2017)

PlugX.name: Multiband Communication
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) can be configured to use multiple network protocols to avoid network-based detection.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

PlugX.name: File and Directory Discovery
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) has a module to enumerate drives and find files recursively.(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: Web Protocols
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) can be configured to use HTTP for command and control.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

PlugX.name: Windows Command Shell
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) allows actors to spawn a reverse shell on a victim.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: Screen Capture
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) allows the operator to capture screenshots.(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: Modify Registry
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) has a module to create, delete, or modify Registry keys.(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: Commonly Used Port
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) has beaconed to its C2 over port 443.(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: Query Registry
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) can enumerate and query for information contained within the Windows Registry.(Citation: Lastline PlugX Analysis)(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) has a module to download and execute files on the compromised machine.(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: Dead Drop Resolver
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) uses Pastebin to store C2 addresses.(Citation: Palo Alto PlugX June 2017)

PlugX.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) can be configured to use raw TCP or UDP for command and control.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

PlugX.name: Masquerade Task or Service
PlugX.description: In one instance, [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) added [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) as a service with a display name of "Corel Writing Tools Utility."(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)

PlugX.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) can be configured to use raw TCP or UDP for command and control.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

PlugX.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) adds Run key entries in the Registry to establish persistence.(Citation: Lastline PlugX Analysis)(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: Network Share Discovery
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) has a module to enumerate network shares.(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: System Network Connections Discovery
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) has a module for enumerating TCP and UDP network connections and associated processes using the netstat command.(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)

PlugX.name: System Checks
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) checks if VMware tools is running in the background by searching for any process named "vmtoolsd". (Citation: Unit42 PlugX June 2017)

PlugX.name: DNS
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) can be configured to use DNS for command and control.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

PlugX.name: Windows Service
PlugX.description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) can be added as a service to establish persistence. [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) also has a module to change service configurations as well as start, control, and delete services.(Citation: CIRCL PlugX March 2013)(Citation: Lastline PlugX Analysis)(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

PlugX.name: MSBuild
PlugX.description: A version of [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) loads as shellcode within a .NET Framework project using msbuild.exe, presumably to bypass application control techniques.(Citation: Palo Alto PlugX June 2017)

Remsec.name: System Information Discovery
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can obtain the OS version information, computer name, processor architecture, machine role, and OS edition.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: File Deletion
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is capable of deleting files on the victim. It also securely removes itself after collecting and exfiltrating data.(Citation: Symantec Remsec IOCs)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Full Report)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is capable of using ICMP, TCP, and UDP for C2.(Citation: Symantec Remsec IOCs)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Full Report)

Remsec.name: Web Protocols
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is capable of using HTTP and HTTPS for C2.(Citation: Symantec Remsec IOCs)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Full Report)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Exfiltration over USB
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) contains a module to move data from airgapped networks to Internet-connected systems by using a removable USB device.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Full Report)

Remsec.name: Keylogging
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) contains a keylogger component.(Citation: Symantec Remsec IOCs)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Network Service Scanning
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) has a plugin that can perform ARP scanning as well as port scanning.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted/Obfuscated Non-C2 Protocol
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can exfiltrate data via a DNS tunnel or email, separately from its C2 channel.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Full Report)

Remsec.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125)'s network loader encrypts C2 traffic with RSA and RC6.(Citation: Symantec Remsec IOCs)

Remsec.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Remsec.description: The [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) loader implements itself with the name Security Support Provider, a legitimate Windows function. Various [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) .exe files mimic legitimate file names used by Microsoft, Symantec, Kaspersky, Hewlett-Packard, and VMWare. [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) also disguised malicious modules using similar filenames as custom network encryption software on victims.(Citation: Symantec Remsec IOCs)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Full Report)

Remsec.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can perform DLL injection.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is capable of using ICMP, TCP, and UDP for C2.(Citation: Symantec Remsec IOCs)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Full Report)

Remsec.name: Data from Removable Media
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) has a package that collects documents from any inserted USB sticks.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can obtain a list of active connections and open ports.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Remsec.description: Some data in [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is encrypted using RC5 in CBC mode, AES-CBC with a hardcoded key, RC4, or Salsa20. Some data is also base64-encoded.(Citation: Symantec Remsec IOCs)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can obtain information about the current user.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Security Software Discovery
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) has a plugin to detect active drivers of some security products.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Remsec.description: A [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) module has a default C2 port of 13000.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Security Account Manager
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can dump the SAM database.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) contains a network loader to receive executable modules from remote attackers and run them on the local victim. It can also upload and download files over HTTP and HTTPS.(Citation: Symantec Remsec IOCs)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) has a plugin to drop and execute vulnerable Outpost Sandbox or avast! Virtualization drivers in order to gain kernel mode privileges.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can add or remove applications or ports on the Windows firewall or disable it entirely.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: File and Directory Discovery
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is capable of listing contents of folders on the victim. [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) also searches for custom network encryption software on victims.(Citation: Symantec Remsec IOCs)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Full Report)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Process Discovery
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can obtain a process list from the victim.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Password Filter DLL
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) harvests plain-text credentials as a password filter registered on domain controllers.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Full Report)

Remsec.name: Remote System Discovery
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can ping or traceroute a remote host.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Scheduled Task/Job
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) schedules the execution one of its modules by creating a new scheduler task.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Local Account
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can obtain a list of users.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can obtain information about network configuration, including the routing table, ARP cache, and DNS cache.(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: DNS
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is capable of using DNS for C2.(Citation: Symantec Remsec IOCs)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Full Report)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Remsec.name: Mail Protocols
Remsec.description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is capable of using SMTP for C2.(Citation: Symantec Remsec IOCs)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Full Report)(Citation: Kaspersky ProjectSauron Technical Analysis)

Gold Dragon.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) collects the endpoint victim's username and uses it as a basis for downloading additional components from the C2 server.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: Windows Command Shell
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) uses cmd.exe to execute commands for discovery.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) establishes persistence in the Startup folder.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: File Deletion
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) deletes one of its files, 2.hwp, from the endpoint after establishing persistence.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) can download additional components from the C2 server.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: Disable or Modify Tools
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) terminates anti-malware processes if they’re found running on the system.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: Process Discovery
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) checks the running processes on the victim’s machine.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: Query Registry
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) enumerates registry keys with the command regkeyenum and obtains information for the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: System Information Discovery
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) collects endpoint information using the systeminfo command.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: Security Software Discovery
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) checks for anti-malware products and processes.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: Web Protocols
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) uses HTTP for communication to the control servers.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: Archive Collected Data
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) encrypts data using Base64 before being sent to the command and control server.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: Local Data Staging
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) stores information gathered from the endpoint in a file named 1.hwp.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Gold Dragon.name: File and Directory Discovery
Gold Dragon.description: [Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) lists the directories for Desktop, program files, and the user’s recently accessed files.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

yty.name: Scheduled Task
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) establishes persistence by creating a scheduled task with the command SchTasks /Create /SC DAILY /TN BigData /TR “ + path_file + “/ST 09:30“.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: Remote System Discovery
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) uses the net view command for discovery.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: Binary Padding
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) contains junk code in its binary, likely to confuse malware analysts.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: System Information Discovery
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) gathers the computer name, the serial number of the main disk volume, CPU information, Microsoft Windows version, and runs the command systeminfo.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: System Owner/User Discovery
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) collects the victim’s username.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: File and Directory Discovery
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) gathers information on victim’s drives and has a plugin for document listing.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) runs ipconfig /all and collects the domain name.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: Data from Local System
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) collects files with the following extensions: .ppt, .pptx, .pdf, .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .docm, .rtf, .inp, .xlsm, .csv, .odt, .pps, .vcf and sends them back to the C2 server.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: Software Packing
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) packs a plugin with UPX.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: Keylogging
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) uses a keylogger plugin to gather keystrokes.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: Screen Capture
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) collects screenshots of the victim machine.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: Bidirectional Communication
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) communicates to the C2 server by retrieving a Google Doc.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: Process Discovery
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) gets an output of running processes using the tasklist command.(Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

yty.name: System Checks
yty.description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) has some basic anti-sandbox detection that tries to detect Virtual PC, Sandboxie, and VMware. (Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)

VERMIN.name: Software Packing
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) is initially packed.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: Audio Capture
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) can perform audio capture.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: File Deletion
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) can delete files on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) can download and upload files to the victim's machine.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: Archive Collected Data
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) encrypts the collected files using 3-DES.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: Automated Collection
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) saves each collected file with the automatically generated format {0:dd-MM-yyyy}.txt .(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: Security Software Discovery
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) uses WMI to check for anti-virus software installed on the system.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: System Information Discovery
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) collects the OS name, machine name, and architecture information.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: Process Discovery
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) can get a list of the processes and running tasks on the system.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: Web Protocols
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) uses HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) decrypts code, strings, and commands to use once it's on the victim's machine.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: Screen Capture
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) can perform screen captures of the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: Clipboard Data
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) collects data stored in the clipboard.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) gathers the local IP address.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: System Owner/User Discovery
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) gathers the username from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) is obfuscated using the obfuscation tool called ConfuserEx.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

VERMIN.name: Keylogging
VERMIN.description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) collects keystrokes from the victim machine.(Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)

ZeroT.name: System Information Discovery
ZeroT.description: [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) gathers the victim's computer name, Windows version, and system language, and then sends it to its C2 server.(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

ZeroT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
ZeroT.description: [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) gathers the victim's IP address and domain information, and then sends it to its C2 server.(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

ZeroT.name: Bypass User Access Control
ZeroT.description: Many [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) samples can perform UAC bypass by using eventvwr.exe to execute a malicious file.(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

ZeroT.name: Windows Service
ZeroT.description: [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) can add a new service to ensure [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) persists on the system when delivered as another payload onto the system.(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

ZeroT.name: Steganography
ZeroT.description: [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) has retrieved stage 2 payloads as Bitmap images that use Least Significant Bit (LSB) steganography.(Citation: Proofpoint TA459 April 2017)(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

ZeroT.name: Web Protocols
ZeroT.description: [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) has used HTTP for C2.(Citation: Proofpoint TA459 April 2017)(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

ZeroT.name: Binary Padding
ZeroT.description: [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) has obfuscated DLLs and functions using dummy API calls inserted between real instructions.(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

ZeroT.name: Software Packing
ZeroT.description: Some [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) DLL files have been packed with UPX.(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

ZeroT.name: DLL Side-Loading
ZeroT.description: [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) has used DLL side-loading to load malicious payloads.(Citation: Proofpoint TA459 April 2017)(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

ZeroT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
ZeroT.description: [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) has encrypted its payload with RC4.(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

ZeroT.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
ZeroT.description: [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) shellcode decrypts and decompresses its RC4-encrypted payload.(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

ZeroT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
ZeroT.description: [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) can download additional payloads onto the victim.(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

ZeroT.name: Symmetric Cryptography
ZeroT.description: [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) has used RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.(Citation: Proofpoint TA459 April 2017)(Citation: Proofpoint ZeroT Feb 2017)

RunningRAT.name: Archive Collected Data
RunningRAT.description: [RunningRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0253) contains code to compress files.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

RunningRAT.name: Windows Command Shell
RunningRAT.description: [RunningRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0253) uses a batch file to kill a security program task and then attempts to remove itself.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

RunningRAT.name: File Deletion
RunningRAT.description: [RunningRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0253) contains code to delete files from the victim’s machine.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

RunningRAT.name: Keylogging
RunningRAT.description: [RunningRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0253) captures keystrokes and sends them back to the C2 server.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

RunningRAT.name: Clipboard Data
RunningRAT.description: [RunningRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0253) contains code to open and copy data from the clipboard.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

RunningRAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
RunningRAT.description: [RunningRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0253) adds itself to the Registry key Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to establish persistence upon reboot.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

RunningRAT.name: System Information Discovery
RunningRAT.description: [RunningRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0253) gathers the OS version, logical drives information, processor information, and volume information.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

RunningRAT.name: Disable or Modify Tools
RunningRAT.description: [RunningRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0253) kills antimalware running process.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

RunningRAT.name: Clear Windows Event Logs
RunningRAT.description: [RunningRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0253) contains code to clear event logs.(Citation: McAfee Gold Dragon)

Rover.name: Screen Capture
Rover.description: [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) takes screenshots of the compromised system's desktop and saves them to C:\system\screenshot.bmp for exfiltration every 60 minutes.(Citation: Palo Alto Rover)

Rover.name: Modify Registry
Rover.description: [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) has functionality to remove Registry Run key persistence as a cleanup procedure.(Citation: Palo Alto Rover)

Rover.name: Keylogging
Rover.description: [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) has keylogging functionality.(Citation: Palo Alto Rover)

Rover.name: Data from Removable Media
Rover.description: [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) searches for files on attached removable drives based on a predefined list of file extensions every five seconds.(Citation: Palo Alto Rover)

Rover.name: Local Data Staging
Rover.description: [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) copies files from removable drives to C:\system.(Citation: Palo Alto Rover)

Rover.name: Automated Collection
Rover.description: [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) automatically collects files from the local system and removable drives based on a predefined list of file extensions on a regular timeframe.(Citation: Palo Alto Rover)

Rover.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Rover.description: [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) persists by creating a Registry entry in HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\.(Citation: Palo Alto Rover)

Rover.name: Automated Exfiltration
Rover.description: [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) automatically searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions and sends them to the command and control server every 60 minutes. [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) also automatically sends keylogger files and screenshots to the C2 server on a regular timeframe.(Citation: Palo Alto Rover)

Rover.name: Data from Local System
Rover.description: [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions.(Citation: Palo Alto Rover)

Rover.name: File and Directory Discovery
Rover.description: [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) automatically searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions.(Citation: Palo Alto Rover)

DownPaper.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
DownPaper.description: [DownPaper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0186) uses PowerShell to add a Registry Run key in order to establish persistence.(Citation: ClearSky Charming Kitten Dec 2017)

DownPaper.name: PowerShell
DownPaper.description: [DownPaper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0186) uses PowerShell for execution.(Citation: ClearSky Charming Kitten Dec 2017)

DownPaper.name: Web Protocols
DownPaper.description: [DownPaper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0186) communicates to its C2 server over HTTP.(Citation: ClearSky Charming Kitten Dec 2017)

DownPaper.name: System Owner/User Discovery
