DownPaper.description: [DownPaper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0186) collects the victim username and sends it to the C2 server.(Citation: ClearSky Charming Kitten Dec 2017)

DownPaper.name: Query Registry
DownPaper.description: [DownPaper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0186) searches and reads the value of the Windows Update Registry Run key.(Citation: ClearSky Charming Kitten Dec 2017)

DownPaper.name: Windows Command Shell
DownPaper.description: [DownPaper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0186) uses the command line.(Citation: ClearSky Charming Kitten Dec 2017)

DownPaper.name: System Information Discovery
DownPaper.description: [DownPaper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0186) collects the victim host name and serial number, and then sends the information to the C2 server.(Citation: ClearSky Charming Kitten Dec 2017)

Flame.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) can use MS10-061 to exploit a print spooler vulnerability in a remote system with a shared printer in order to move laterally.(Citation: Kaspersky Flame)(Citation: Kaspersky Flame Functionality)

Flame.name: Exfiltration Over Bluetooth
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) has a module named BeetleJuice that contains Bluetooth functionality that may be used in different ways, including transmitting encoded information from the infected system over the Bluetooth protocol, acting as a Bluetooth beacon, and identifying other Bluetooth devices in the vicinity.(Citation: Symantec Beetlejuice)

Flame.name: Rundll32
Flame.description: Rundll32.exe is used as a way of executing [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) at the command-line.(Citation: Crysys Skywiper)

Flame.name: Local Account
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) can create backdoor accounts with login “HelpAssistant” on domain connected systems if appropriate rights are available.(Citation: Kaspersky Flame)(Citation: Kaspersky Flame Functionality)

Flame.name: Audio Capture
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) can record audio using any existing hardware recording devices.(Citation: Kaspersky Flame)(Citation: Kaspersky Flame Functionality)

Flame.name: Security Software Discovery
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) identifies security software such as antivirus through the Security module.(Citation: Kaspersky Flame)(Citation: Kaspersky Flame Functionality)

Flame.name: Screen Capture
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) can take regular screenshots when certain applications are open that are sent to the command and control server.(Citation: Kaspersky Flame)

Flame.name: Replication Through Removable Media
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) contains modules to infect USB sticks and spread laterally to other Windows systems the stick is plugged into using Autorun functionality.(Citation: Kaspersky Flame)

Flame.name: Authentication Package
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) can use Windows Authentication Packages for persistence.(Citation: Crysys Skywiper)

Dyre.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) injects into other processes to load modules.(Citation: Symantec Dyre June 2015)

Dyre.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has a command to download and executes additional files.(Citation: Symantec Dyre June 2015)

Dyre.name: Windows Service
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) registers itself as a service by adding several Registry keys.(Citation: Symantec Dyre June 2015)

Dyre.name: Web Protocols
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) uses HTTPS for C2 communications.(Citation: Symantec Dyre June 2015)(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

Dyre.name: System Checks
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) can detect sandbox analysis environments by inspecting the process list and Registry.(Citation: Symantec Dyre June 2015)(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

Dyre.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) decrypts resources needed for targeting the victim.(Citation: Symantec Dyre June 2015)(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

Dyre.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has the ability to identify the users on a compromised host.(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

Dyre.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has the ability to identify network settings on a compromised host.(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

Dyre.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has the ability to send information staged on a compromised host externally to C2.(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

Dyre.name: Software Discovery
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has the ability to identify installed programs on a compromised host.(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

Dyre.name: Software Packing
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has been delivered with encrypted resources and must be unpacked for execution.(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

Dyre.name: Local Data Staging
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has the ability to create files in a TEMP folder to act as a database to store information.(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

Dyre.name: System Service Discovery
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has the ability to identify running services on a compromised host.(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

Dyre.name: Scheduled Task
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has the ability to achieve persistence by adding a new task in the task scheduler to run every minute.(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

Dyre.name: System Information Discovery
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has the ability to identify the computer name, OS version, and hardware configuration on a compromised host.(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

Dyre.name: Process Injection
Dyre.description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has the ability to directly inject its code into the web browser process.(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)

QUADAGENT.name: File Deletion
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) has a command to delete its Registry key and scheduled task.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: Modify Registry
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) modifies an HKCU Registry key to store a session identifier unique to the compromised system as well as a pre-shared key used for encrypting and decrypting C2 communications.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: Windows Command Shell
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) uses cmd.exe to execute scripts and commands on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) uses AES and a preshared key to decrypt the custom Base64 routine used to encode strings and scripts.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: Scheduled Task
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) creates a scheduled task to maintain persistence on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) gathers the current domain the victim system belongs to.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: PowerShell
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) uses PowerShell scripts for execution.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: Web Protocols
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) uses HTTPS and HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: Standard Encoding
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) encodes C2 communications with base64.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: Fallback Channels
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) uses multiple protocols (HTTPS, HTTP, DNS) for its C2 server as fallback channels if communication with one is unsuccessful.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) was likely obfuscated using Invoke-Obfuscation.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)(Citation: GitHub Invoke-Obfuscation)

QUADAGENT.name: Query Registry
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) checks if a value exists within a Registry key in the HKCU hive whose name is the same as the scheduled task it has created.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) gathers the victim username.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) used the PowerShell filenames Office365DCOMCheck.ps1 and SystemDiskClean.ps1.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

QUADAGENT.name: DNS
QUADAGENT.description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) uses DNS for C2 communications.(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)

Wiarp.name: Commonly Used Port
Wiarp.description: [Wiarp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0206) connects to external C2 infrastructure over the HTTP port.(Citation: Symantec Wiarp May 2012)

Wiarp.name: Windows Service
Wiarp.description: [Wiarp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0206) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can create a service.(Citation: Symantec Wiarp May 2012)

Wiarp.name: Process Injection
Wiarp.description: [Wiarp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0206) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can inject files into running processes.(Citation: Symantec Wiarp May 2012)

Wiarp.name: Windows Command Shell
Wiarp.description: [Wiarp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0206) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can open a command line interface.(Citation: Symantec Wiarp May 2012)

Wiarp.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Wiarp.description: [Wiarp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0206) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can download files.(Citation: Symantec Wiarp May 2012)

China Chopper.name: Windows Command Shell
China Chopper.description: [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020)'s server component is capable of opening a command terminal.(Citation: SecureWorks BRONZE UNION June 2017)(Citation: Lee 2013)(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)

China Chopper.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
China Chopper.description: [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020)'s server component can download remote files.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)(Citation: Lee 2013)(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)

China Chopper.name: File and Directory Discovery
China Chopper.description: [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020)'s server component can list directory contents.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

China Chopper.name: Web Protocols
China Chopper.description: [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020)'s server component executes code sent via HTTP POST commands.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

China Chopper.name: Web Shell
China Chopper.description: [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020)'s server component is a Web Shell payload.(Citation: Lee 2013)

China Chopper.name: Data from Local System
China Chopper.description: [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020)'s server component can upload local files.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)(Citation: Lee 2013)(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)

China Chopper.name: Network Service Scanning
China Chopper.description: [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020)'s server component can spider authentication portals.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

China Chopper.name: Password Guessing
China Chopper.description: [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020)'s server component can perform brute force password guessing against authentication portals.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

China Chopper.name: Software Packing
China Chopper.description: [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020)'s client component is packed with UPX.(Citation: Lee 2013)

China Chopper.name: Timestomp
China Chopper.description: [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020)'s server component can change the timestamp of files.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)(Citation: Lee 2013)(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)

Kasidet.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Kasidet.description: [Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) has the ability to change firewall settings to allow a plug-in to be downloaded.(Citation: Zscaler Kasidet)

Kasidet.name: Security Software Discovery
Kasidet.description: [Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) has the ability to identify any anti-virus installed on the infected system.(Citation: Zscaler Kasidet)

Kasidet.name: Windows Command Shell
Kasidet.description: [Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) can execute commands using cmd.exe.(Citation: Zscaler Kasidet)

Kasidet.name: Screen Capture
Kasidet.description: [Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) has the ability to initiate keylogging and screen captures.(Citation: Zscaler Kasidet)

Kasidet.name: File and Directory Discovery
Kasidet.description: [Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) has the ability to search for a given filename on a victim.(Citation: Zscaler Kasidet)

Kasidet.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Kasidet.description: [Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) has the ability to download and execute additional files.(Citation: Zscaler Kasidet)

Kasidet.name: System Information Discovery
Kasidet.description: [Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) has the ability to obtain a victim's system name and operating system version.(Citation: Zscaler Kasidet)

Kasidet.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Kasidet.description: [Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) creates a Registry Run key to establish persistence.(Citation: Zscaler Kasidet)(Citation: Microsoft Kasidet)

Kasidet.name: Keylogging
Kasidet.description: [Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) has the ability to initiate keylogging.(Citation: Zscaler Kasidet)

Kasidet.name: Process Discovery
Kasidet.description: [Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) has the ability to search for a given process name in processes currently running in the system.(Citation: Zscaler Kasidet)

PHOREAL.name: Windows Command Shell
PHOREAL.description: [PHOREAL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0158) is capable of creating reverse shell.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

PHOREAL.name: Modify Registry
PHOREAL.description: [PHOREAL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0158) is capable of manipulating the Registry.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

PHOREAL.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
PHOREAL.description: [PHOREAL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0158) communicates via ICMP for C2.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

PHOREAL.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
PHOREAL.description: [PHOREAL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0158) communicates via ICMP for C2.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Shared Modules
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) can load a DLL using the LoadLibrary API.(Citation: FireEye Know Your Enemy FIN8 Aug 2016)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) can download additional files and payloads to compromised hosts.(Citation: FireEye Know Your Enemy FIN8 Aug 2016)(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) has been observed using a Registry Run key.(Citation: FireEye Know Your Enemy FIN8 Aug 2016)(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Rundll32
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) can load a DLL using Rundll32.(Citation: FireEye Know Your Enemy FIN8 Aug 2016)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) mimics filenames from %SYSTEM%\System32 to hide DLLs in %WINDIR% and/or %TEMP%.(Citation: FireEye Know Your Enemy FIN8 Aug 2016)(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Web Protocols
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) enables remote interaction and can obtain additional code over HTTPS GET and POST requests.(Citation: FireEye Fin8 May 2016)(Citation: FireEye Know Your Enemy FIN8 Aug 2016)(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: AppCert DLLs
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) can establish using a AppCertDLLs Registry key.(Citation: FireEye Know Your Enemy FIN8 Aug 2016)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: File Deletion
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) can delete files written to disk.(Citation: FireEye Know Your Enemy FIN8 Aug 2016)(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Archive via Utility
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) has Gzipped information and saved it to a random temp file before exfil.(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Security Software Discovery
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) can gather AVs registered in the system.(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: System Information Discovery
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) can gather system information such as computer names.(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Local Account
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) can gather user names.(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: PowerShell
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) has used [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) scripts.(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) has used [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) to decode base64-encoded assembly.(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) has hashed most its code's functions and encrypted payloads with base64 and XOR.(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Local Data Staging
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) has saved information to a random temp file before exfil.(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

PUNCHBUGGY.name: Python
PUNCHBUGGY.description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) has used python scripts.(Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)

TDTESS.name: Timestomp
TDTESS.description: After creating a new service for persistence, [TDTESS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0164) sets the file creation time for the service to the creation time of the victim's legitimate svchost.exe file.(Citation: ClearSky Wilted Tulip July 2017)

TDTESS.name: Windows Command Shell
TDTESS.description: [TDTESS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0164) provides a reverse shell on the victim.(Citation: ClearSky Wilted Tulip July 2017)

TDTESS.name: File Deletion
TDTESS.description: [TDTESS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0164) creates then deletes log files during installation of itself as a service.(Citation: ClearSky Wilted Tulip July 2017)

TDTESS.name: Windows Service
TDTESS.description: If running as administrator, [TDTESS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0164) installs itself as a new service named bmwappushservice to establish persistence.(Citation: ClearSky Wilted Tulip July 2017)

TDTESS.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
TDTESS.description: [TDTESS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0164) has a command to download and execute an additional file.(Citation: ClearSky Wilted Tulip July 2017)

StreamEx.name: Modify Registry
StreamEx.description: [StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) has the ability to modify the Registry.(Citation: Cylance Shell Crew Feb 2017)

StreamEx.name: File and Directory Discovery
StreamEx.description: [StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) has the ability to enumerate drive types.(Citation: Cylance Shell Crew Feb 2017)

StreamEx.name: Rundll32
StreamEx.description: [StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) uses rundll32 to call an exported function.(Citation: Cylance Shell Crew Feb 2017)

StreamEx.name: Security Software Discovery
StreamEx.description: [StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) has the ability to scan for security tools such as firewalls and antivirus tools.(Citation: Cylance Shell Crew Feb 2017)

StreamEx.name: Windows Command Shell
StreamEx.description: [StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) has the ability to remotely execute commands.(Citation: Cylance Shell Crew Feb 2017)

StreamEx.name: System Information Discovery
StreamEx.description: [StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) has the ability to enumerate system information.(Citation: Cylance Shell Crew Feb 2017)

StreamEx.name: Process Discovery
StreamEx.description: [StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) has the ability to enumerate processes.(Citation: Cylance Shell Crew Feb 2017)

StreamEx.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
StreamEx.description: [StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) obfuscates some commands by using statically programmed fragments of strings when starting a DLL. It also uses a one-byte xor against 0x91 to encode configuration data.(Citation: Cylance Shell Crew Feb 2017)

StreamEx.name: Windows Service
StreamEx.description: [StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) establishes persistence by installing a new service pointing to its DLL and setting the service to auto-start.(Citation: Cylance Shell Crew Feb 2017)

ROKRAT.name: Screen Capture
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) captures screenshots of the infected system using the gdi32 library.(Citation: Talos ROKRAT)(Citation: Talos ROKRAT 2)(Citation: Securelist ScarCruft May 2019)(Citation: NCCGroup RokRat Nov 2018)

ROKRAT.name: Security Software Discovery
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) checks for debugging tools.(Citation: Talos Group123)(Citation: NCCGroup RokRat Nov 2018)

ROKRAT.name: System Information Discovery
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) gathers the computer name and checks the OS version to ensure it doesn’t run on a Windows XP or Windows Server 2003 systems.(Citation: Talos ROKRAT)(Citation: Talos ROKRAT 2)(Citation: Securelist ScarCruft May 2019)(Citation: NCCGroup RokRat Nov 2018)

ROKRAT.name: Query Registry
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) accesses the HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\mssmbios\Data\SMBiosData Registry key to obtain the System manufacturer value to identify the machine type.(Citation: Talos Group123)

ROKRAT.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) sends collected files back over same C2 channel.(Citation: Talos ROKRAT)

ROKRAT.name: Bidirectional Communication
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) leverages legitimate social networking sites and cloud platforms (Twitter, Yandex, and Mediafire) for C2 communications.(Citation: Talos ROKRAT)(Citation: Securelist ScarCruft May 2019)

ROKRAT.name: Web Protocols
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) use HTTPS for all command and control communication methods.(Citation: Talos ROKRAT)(Citation: NCCGroup RokRat Nov 2018)

ROKRAT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) retrieves additional malicious payloads from the C2 server.(Citation: Talos ROKRAT)(Citation: NCCGroup RokRat Nov 2018)

ROKRAT.name: Process Discovery
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) lists the current running processes on the system.(Citation: Talos ROKRAT)(Citation: NCCGroup RokRat Nov 2018)

ROKRAT.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) steals credentials stored in Web browsers by querying the sqlite database.(Citation: Talos Group123)

ROKRAT.name: Keylogging
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) uses a keylogger to capture keystrokes and location of where the user is typing.(Citation: Talos ROKRAT)

ROKRAT.name: System Checks
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) checks for sandboxing libraries.(Citation: Talos Group123)(Citation: NCCGroup RokRat Nov 2018)

ROKRAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) has the ability to gather a list of files and directories on the infected system.(Citation: Securelist ScarCruft May 2019)(Citation: NCCGroup RokRat Nov 2018)

ROKRAT.name: Audio Capture
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) has a audio capture and eavesdropping module.(Citation: Securelist ScarCruft May 2019)

ROKRAT.name: Credentials from Password Stores
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) steals credentials by leveraging the Windows Vault mechanism.(Citation: Talos Group123)

ROKRAT.name: File Deletion
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) can request to delete files.(Citation: NCCGroup RokRat Nov 2018)

ROKRAT.name: Data from Local System
ROKRAT.description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) can request to upload collected host data and additional files.(Citation: NCCGroup RokRat Nov 2018)

Unknown Logger.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Unknown Logger.description: [Unknown Logger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0130) can obtain information about the victim usernames.(Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon)

Unknown Logger.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
Unknown Logger.description: [Unknown Logger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0130) is capable of stealing usernames and passwords from browsers on the victim machine.(Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon)

Unknown Logger.name: Keylogging
Unknown Logger.description: [Unknown Logger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0130) is capable of recording keystrokes.(Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon)

Unknown Logger.name: Replication Through Removable Media
Unknown Logger.description: [Unknown Logger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0130) is capable of spreading to USB devices.(Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon)

Unknown Logger.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Unknown Logger.description: [Unknown Logger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0130) can obtain information about the victim's IP address.(Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon)

Unknown Logger.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Unknown Logger.description: [Unknown Logger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0130) is capable of downloading remote files.(Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon)

Unknown Logger.name: System Information Discovery
Unknown Logger.description: [Unknown Logger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0130) can obtain information about the victim computer name, physical memory, country, and date.(Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon)

Unknown Logger.name: Disable or Modify Tools
Unknown Logger.description: [Unknown Logger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0130) has functionality to disable security tools, including Kaspersky, BitDefender, and MalwareBytes.(Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon)

LOWBALL.name: Commonly Used Port
LOWBALL.description: [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) command and control occurs via HTTPS over port 443.(Citation: FireEye admin@338)

LOWBALL.name: Web Protocols
LOWBALL.description: [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) command and control occurs via HTTPS over port 443.(Citation: FireEye admin@338)

LOWBALL.name: Bidirectional Communication
LOWBALL.description: [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) uses the Dropbox cloud storage service for command and control.(Citation: FireEye admin@338)

LOWBALL.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
LOWBALL.description: [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) uses the Dropbox API to request two files, one of which is the same file as the one dropped by the malicious email attachment. This is most likely meant to be a mechanism to update the compromised host with a new version of the [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware.(Citation: FireEye admin@338)

RARSTONE.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
RARSTONE.description: After decrypting itself in memory, [RARSTONE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0055) downloads a DLL file from its C2 server and loads it in the memory space of a hidden Internet Explorer process. This “downloaded” file is actually not dropped onto the system.(Citation: Camba RARSTONE)

RARSTONE.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
RARSTONE.description: [RARSTONE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0055) uses SSL to encrypt its communication with its C2 server.(Citation: Aquino RARSTONE)

RARSTONE.name: File and Directory Discovery
RARSTONE.description: [RARSTONE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0055) obtains installer properties from Uninstall Registry Key entries to obtain information about installed applications and how to uninstall certain applications.(Citation: Camba RARSTONE)

RARSTONE.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
RARSTONE.description: [RARSTONE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0055) downloads its backdoor component from a C2 server and loads it directly into memory.(Citation: Aquino RARSTONE)

jRAT.name: Video Capture
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) has the capability to capture video from a webcam.(Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: File Deletion
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) has a function to delete files from the victim’s machine.(Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)

jRAT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283)’s Java payload is encrypted with AES.(Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018) Additionally, backdoor files are encrypted using DES as a stream cipher. Later variants of [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) also incorporated AV evasion methods such as Java bytecode obfuscation via the commercial Allatori obfuscation tool.(Citation: Symantec Frutas Feb 2013)

jRAT.name: Security Software Discovery
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can list security software, such as by using WMIC to identify anti-virus products installed on the victim’s machine and to obtain firewall details.(Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can download and execute files.(Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)(Citation: Symantec Frutas Feb 2013)

jRAT.name: Screen Capture
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) has the capability to take screenshots of the victim’s machine.(Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Keylogging
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) has the capability to log keystrokes from the victim’s machine, both offline and online.(Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) uses WMIC to identify anti-virus products installed on the victim’s machine and to obtain firewall details.(Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)

jRAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can browse file systems.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)(Citation: Symantec Frutas Feb 2013)

jRAT.name: Process Discovery
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can query and kill system processes.(Citation: Symantec Frutas Feb 2013)

jRAT.name: System Information Discovery
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) collects information about the OS (version, build type, install date) as well as system up-time upon receiving a connection from a backdoor.(Citation: Symantec Frutas Feb 2013)

jRAT.name: System Network Connections Discovery
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can list network connections.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Software Packing
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) payloads have been packed.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Windows Command Shell
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) has command line access.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Startup Items
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can list and manage startup entries.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: System Service Discovery
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can list local services.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Audio Capture
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can capture microphone recordings.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Private Keys
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can steal keys for VPNs and cryptocurrency wallets.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Clipboard Data
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can capture clipboard data.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can support RDP control.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Proxy
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can serve as a SOCKS proxy server.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can map UPnP ports.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can gather victim internal and external IPs.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Scheduled Transfer
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can be configured to reconnect at certain intervals.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Credentials In Files
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can capture passwords from common chat applications such as MSN Messenger, AOL, Instant Messenger, and and Google Talk.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can capture passwords from common web browsers such as Internet Explorer, Google Chrome, and Firefox.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: JavaScript/JScript
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) has been distributed as HTA files with JScript.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

jRAT.name: Visual Basic
jRAT.description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) has been distributed as HTA files with VBScript.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016)

Proxysvc.name: Commonly Used Port
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) uses port 443 for the control server communications.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: System Time Discovery
Proxysvc.description: As part of the data reconnaissance phase, [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) grabs the system time to send back to the control server.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: Web Protocols
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) uses HTTP over SSL to communicate commands with the control server.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: Automated Collection
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) automatically collects data about the victim and sends it to the control server.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) collects the network adapter information and domain/username information based on current remote sessions.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: Data from Local System
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) searches the local system and gathers data.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: Service Execution
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) registers itself as a service on the victim’s machine to run as a standalone process.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: Process Discovery
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) lists processes running on the system.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: Windows Command Shell
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) executes a binary on the system and logs the results into a temp file by using: cmd.exe /c " > %temp%\PM* .tmp 2>&1".(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: System Information Discovery
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) collects the OS version, country name, MAC address, computer name, physical memory statistics, and volume information for all drives on the system.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) performs data exfiltration over the control server channel using a custom protocol.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: Query Registry
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) gathers product names from the Registry key: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion ProductName and the processor description from the Registry key HKLM\HARDWARE\DESCRIPTION\System\CentralProcessor\0 ProcessorNameString.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: File Deletion
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) can delete files indicated by the attacker and remove itself from disk using a batch file.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: File and Directory Discovery
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) lists files in directories.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

Proxysvc.name: Data Destruction
Proxysvc.description: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) can overwrite files indicated by the attacker before deleting them.(Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)

T9000.name: Audio Capture
T9000.description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) uses the Skype API to record audio and video calls. It writes encrypted data to %APPDATA%\Intel\Skype.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

T9000.name: System Time Discovery
T9000.description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) gathers and beacons the system time during installation.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

T9000.name: System Owner/User Discovery
T9000.description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) gathers and beacons the username of the logged in account during installation. It will also gather the username of running processes to determine if it is running as SYSTEM.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

T9000.name: Archive via Custom Method
T9000.description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) encrypts collected data using a single byte XOR key.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

T9000.name: Video Capture
T9000.description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) uses the Skype API to record audio and video calls. It writes encrypted data to %APPDATA%\Intel\Skype.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

T9000.name: Screen Capture
T9000.description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) can take screenshots of the desktop and target application windows, saving them to user directories as one byte XOR encrypted .dat files.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

T9000.name: Security Software Discovery
T9000.description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) performs checks for various antivirus and security products during installation.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

T9000.name: AppInit DLLs
T9000.description: If a victim meets certain criteria, [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) uses the AppInit_DLL functionality to achieve persistence by ensuring that every user mode process that is spawned will load its malicious DLL, ResN32.dll. It does this by creating the following Registry keys: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\AppInit_DLLs – %APPDATA%\Intel\ResN32.dll and HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\LoadAppInit_DLLs – 0x1.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

T9000.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
T9000.description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) searches through connected drives for removable storage devices.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

T9000.name: DLL Side-Loading
T9000.description: During the [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) installation process, it drops a copy of the legitimate Microsoft binary igfxtray.exe. The executable contains a side-loading weakness which is used to load a portion of the malware.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

T9000.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
T9000.description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) gathers and beacons the MAC and IP addresses during installation.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

T9000.name: Automated Collection
T9000.description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) searches removable storage devices for files with a pre-defined list of file extensions (e.g. * .doc, *.ppt, *.xls, *.docx, *.pptx, *.xlsx). Any matching files are encrypted and written to a local user directory.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

T9000.name: System Information Discovery
T9000.description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) gathers and beacons the operating system build number and CPU Architecture (32-bit/64-bit) during installation.(Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)

SeaDuke.name: Archive via Library
SeaDuke.description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) compressed data with zlib prior to sending it over C2.(Citation: Mandiant No Easy Breach)

SeaDuke.name: PowerShell
SeaDuke.description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) uses a module to execute Mimikatz with PowerShell to perform [Pass the Ticket](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1097).(Citation: Symantec Seaduke 2015)

SeaDuke.name: Pass the Ticket
SeaDuke.description: Some [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) samples have a module to use pass the ticket with Kerberos for authentication.(Citation: Symantec Seaduke 2015)

SeaDuke.name: Shortcut Modification
SeaDuke.description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) is capable of persisting via a .lnk file stored in the Startup directory.(Citation: Unit 42 SeaDuke 2015)

SeaDuke.name: Symmetric Cryptography
SeaDuke.description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) C2 traffic has been encrypted with RC4 and AES.(Citation: Mandiant No Easy Breach)(Citation: Unit 42 SeaDuke 2015)

SeaDuke.name: Software Packing
SeaDuke.description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) has been packed with the UPX packer.(Citation: Unit 42 SeaDuke 2015)

SeaDuke.name: Valid Accounts
SeaDuke.description: Some [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) samples have a module to extract email from Microsoft Exchange servers using compromised credentials.(Citation: Symantec Seaduke 2015)

SeaDuke.name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
SeaDuke.description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) uses an event filter in WMI code to execute a previously dropped executable shortly after system startup.(Citation: FireEye WMI 2015)

SeaDuke.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
SeaDuke.description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) is capable of uploading and downloading files.(Citation: Unit 42 SeaDuke 2015)

SeaDuke.name: Standard Encoding
SeaDuke.description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) C2 traffic is base64-encoded.(Citation: Unit 42 SeaDuke 2015)

SeaDuke.name: File Deletion
SeaDuke.description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) can securely delete files, including deleting itself from the victim.(Citation: Symantec Seaduke 2015)

SeaDuke.name: Web Protocols
SeaDuke.description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2.(Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)

SeaDuke.name: Remote Email Collection
SeaDuke.description: Some [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) samples have a module to extract email from Microsoft Exchange servers using compromised credentials.(Citation: Symantec Seaduke 2015)

SeaDuke.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
SeaDuke.description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) is capable of persisting via the Registry Run key or a .lnk file stored in the Startup directory.(Citation: Unit 42 SeaDuke 2015)

SeaDuke.name: Windows Command Shell
SeaDuke.description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) is capable of executing commands.(Citation: Unit 42 SeaDuke 2015)

RogueRobin.name: Shortcut Modification
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) establishes persistence by creating a shortcut (.LNK file) in the Windows startup folder to run a script each time the user logs in.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)

RogueRobin.name: Standard Encoding
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) base64 encodes strings that are sent to the C2 over its DNS tunnel.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)

RogueRobin.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
RogueRobin.description: The PowerShell script with the [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) payload was obfuscated using the COMPRESS technique in Invoke-Obfuscation.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)(Citation: GitHub Invoke-Obfuscation)

RogueRobin.name: PowerShell
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) uses a command prompt to run a PowerShell script from Excel.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018) To assist in establishing persistence, [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) creates %APPDATA%\OneDrive.bat and saves the following string to it:powershell.exe -WindowStyle Hidden -exec bypass -File “%APPDATA%\OneDrive.ps1”.(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)

RogueRobin.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) can save a new file to the system from the C2 server.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)

RogueRobin.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) uses various WMI queries to check if the sample is running in a sandbox.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)

RogueRobin.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) created a shortcut in the Windows startup folder to launch a PowerShell script each time the user logs in to establish persistence.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)

RogueRobin.name: Windows Command Shell
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) uses Windows Script Components.(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)

RogueRobin.name: Security Software Discovery
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) enumerates running processes to search for Wireshark and Windows Sysinternals suite.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)

RogueRobin.name: Screen Capture
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) has a command named $screenshot that may be responsible for taking screenshots of the victim machine.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)

RogueRobin.name: System Information Discovery
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) gathers BIOS versions and manufacturers, the number of CPU cores, the total physical memory, and the computer name.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)

RogueRobin.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) gathers the IP address and domain from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)

RogueRobin.name: Process Discovery
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) checks the running processes for evidence it may be running in a sandbox environment. It specifically enumerates processes for Wireshark and Sysinternals.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)

RogueRobin.name: System Owner/User Discovery
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) collects the victim’s username and whether that user is an admin.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)

RogueRobin.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) uses a custom DNS tunneling protocol for C2.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)

RogueRobin.name: Bidirectional Communication
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) has used Google Drive as a Command and Control channel. (Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)

RogueRobin.name: System Checks
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) uses WMI to check BIOS version for VBOX, bochs, qemu, virtualbox, and vm to check for evidence that the script might be executing within an analysis environment. (Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)

RogueRobin.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) decodes an embedded executable using base64 and decompresses it.(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)

RogueRobin.name: Regsvr32
RogueRobin.description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) uses regsvr32.exe to run a .sct file for execution.(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)

Gazer.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) can establish persistence by creating a .lnk file in the Start menu.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) obtains the current user's security identifier.(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) can establish persistence by setting the value “Shell” with “explorer.exe, %malware_pathfile%” under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Thread Execution Hijacking
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) performs thread execution hijacking to inject its orchestrator into a running thread from a remote process.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Timestomp
Gazer.description: For early [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) versions, the compilation timestamp was faked.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Screensaver
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) can establish persistence through the system screensaver by configuring it to execute the malware.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) logs its actions into files that are encrypted with 3DES. It also uses RSA to encrypt resources.(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Web Protocols
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) communicates with its C2 servers over HTTP.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Code Signing
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) versions are signed with various valid certificates; one was likely faked and issued by Comodo for "Solid Loop Ltd," and another was issued for "Ultimate Computer Support Ltd."(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) can execute a task to download a file.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Shortcut Modification
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) can establish persistence by creating a .lnk file in the Start menu or by modifying existing .lnk files to execute the malware through cmd.exe.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: File Deletion
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) has commands to delete files and persistence mechanisms from the victim.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: NTFS File Attributes
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) stores configuration items in alternate data streams (ADSs) if the Registry is not accessible.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Scheduled Task
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) can establish persistence by creating a scheduled task.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Process Injection
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) injects its communication module into an Internet accessible process through which it performs C2.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) uses custom encryption for C2 that uses RSA.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)

Gazer.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Gazer.description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) uses custom encryption for C2 that uses 3DES.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)

KEYMARBLE.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
KEYMARBLE.description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) can upload files to the victim’s machine and can download additional payloads.(Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)

KEYMARBLE.name: Process Discovery
KEYMARBLE.description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) can obtain a list of running processes on the system.(Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)

KEYMARBLE.name: File Deletion
KEYMARBLE.description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) has the capability to delete files off the victim’s machine.(Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)

KEYMARBLE.name: Screen Capture
KEYMARBLE.description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) can capture screenshots of the victim’s machine.(Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)

KEYMARBLE.name: Windows Command Shell
KEYMARBLE.description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) can execute shell commands using cmd.exe.(Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)

KEYMARBLE.name: Symmetric Cryptography
KEYMARBLE.description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) uses a customized XOR algorithm to encrypt C2 communications.(Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)

KEYMARBLE.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
KEYMARBLE.description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) gathers the MAC address of the victim’s machine.(Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)

KEYMARBLE.name: System Information Discovery
KEYMARBLE.description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) has the capability to collect the computer name, language settings, the OS version, CPU information, disk devices, and time elapsed since system start.(Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)

KEYMARBLE.name: File and Directory Discovery
KEYMARBLE.description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) has a command to search for files on the victim’s machine.(Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)

KEYMARBLE.name: Modify Registry
KEYMARBLE.description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) has a command to create Registry entries for storing data under HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\WABE\DataPath.(Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)

KEYMARBLE.name: Commonly Used Port
KEYMARBLE.description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) uses port 443 for C2.(Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)

Zeus Panda.name: PowerShell
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) uses PowerShell to download and execute the payload.(Citation: Talos Zeus Panda Nov 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Security Software Discovery
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) checks to see if anti-virus, anti-spyware, or firewall products are installed in the victim’s environment.(Citation: Talos Zeus Panda Nov 2017)(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: System Information Discovery
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) collects the OS version, system architecture, computer name, product ID, install date, and information on the keyboard mapping to determine the language used on the system.(Citation: Talos Zeus Panda Nov 2017)(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) can download additional malware plug-in modules and execute them on the victim’s machine.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) encrypts strings with XOR and obfuscates the macro code from the initial payload. [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) also encrypts all configuration and settings in AES and RC4.(Citation: Talos Zeus Panda Nov 2017)(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Portable Executable Injection
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) checks processes on the system and if they meet the necessary requirements, it injects into that process.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: System Time Discovery
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) collects the current system time (UTC) and sends it back to the C2 server.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Web Protocols
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) uses HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: Talos Zeus Panda Nov 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Screen Capture
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) can take screenshots of the victim’s machine.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Credential API Hooking
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) hooks processes by leveraging its own IAT hooked functions.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: File Deletion
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) has a command to delete a file. It also can uninstall scripts and delete files to cover its track.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) adds persistence by creating Registry Run keys.(Citation: Talos Zeus Panda Nov 2017)(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Keylogging
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) can perform keylogging on the victim’s machine by hooking the functions TranslateMessage and WM_KEYDOWN.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Clipboard Data
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) can hook GetClipboardData function to watch for clipboard pastes to collect.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) decrypts strings in the code during the execution process.(Citation: Talos Zeus Panda Nov 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Windows Command Shell
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) can launch an interface where it can execute several commands on the victim’s PC.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Modify Registry
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) modifies several Registry keys under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Internet Explorer\ PhishingFilter\ to disable phishing filters.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: File and Directory Discovery
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) searches for specific directories on the victim’s machine.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Process Discovery
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) checks for running processes on the victim’s machine.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Query Registry
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) checks for the existence of a Registry key and if it contains certain values.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

Zeus Panda.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
Zeus Panda.description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) can launch remote scripts on the victim’s machine.(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)

DarkComet.name: System Owner/User Discovery
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) gathers the username from the victim’s machine.(Citation: TrendMicro DarkComet Sept 2014)

DarkComet.name: Keylogging
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) has a keylogging capability.(Citation: TrendMicro DarkComet Sept 2014)

DarkComet.name: System Information Discovery
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can collect the computer name, RAM used, and operating system version from the victim’s machine.(Citation: TrendMicro DarkComet Sept 2014)(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Web Protocols
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can use HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) adds several Registry entries to enable automatic execution at every system startup.(Citation: TrendMicro DarkComet Sept 2014)(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Video Capture
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can access the victim’s webcam to take pictures.(Citation: TrendMicro DarkComet Sept 2014)(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can execute various types of scripts on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Process Discovery
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can list active processes running on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Modify Registry
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) adds a Registry value for its installation routine to the Registry Key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System Enable LUA=”0” and HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\DC3_FEXEC.(Citation: TrendMicro DarkComet Sept 2014)(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Disable or Modify Tools
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can disable Security Center functions like anti-virus.(Citation: TrendMicro DarkComet Sept 2014)(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can open an active screen of the victim’s machine and take control of the mouse and keyboard.(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Audio Capture
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can listen in to victims' conversations through the system’s microphone.(Citation: TrendMicro DarkComet Sept 2014)(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can load any files onto the infected machine to execute.(Citation: TrendMicro DarkComet Sept 2014)(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Software Packing
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) has the option to compress its payload using UPX or MPRESS.(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Clipboard Data
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can steal data from the clipboard.(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) has dropped itself onto victim machines with file names such as WinDefender.Exe and winupdate.exe in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate file.(Citation: TrendMicro DarkComet Sept 2014)

DarkComet.name: Windows Command Shell
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can launch a remote shell to execute commands on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

DarkComet.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
DarkComet.description: [DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can disable Security Center functions like the Windows Firewall.(Citation: TrendMicro DarkComet Sept 2014)(Citation: Malwarebytes DarkComet March 2018)

Carbon.name: Commonly Used Port
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) uses port 80 for C2 communications.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)

Carbon.name: Scheduled Task
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) creates several tasks for later execution to continue persistence on the victim’s machine.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)

Carbon.name: Local Account
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) runs the net group command to list accounts on the system.(Citation: GovCERT Carbon May 2016)

Carbon.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) uses TCP and UDP for C2.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)

Carbon.name: Remote System Discovery
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) uses the net view command.(Citation: GovCERT Carbon May 2016)

Carbon.name: System Time Discovery
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) uses the command net time \\127.0.0.1 to get information the system’s time.(Citation: GovCERT Carbon May 2016)

Carbon.name: Process Discovery
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) can list the processes on the victim’s machine.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)

Carbon.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) encrypts configuration files and tasks for the malware to complete using CAST-128 algorithm.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)

Carbon.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) uses the netstat -r and netstat -an commands.(Citation: GovCERT Carbon May 2016)

Carbon.name: Windows Service
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) establishes persistence by creating a service and naming it based off the operating system version running on the current machine.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)

Carbon.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) decrypts task and configuration files for execution.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)

Carbon.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) has a command to inject code into a process.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)

Carbon.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) can collect the IP address of the victims and other computers on the network using the commands: ipconfig -all nbtstat -n, and nbtstat -s.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)(Citation: GovCERT Carbon May 2016)

Carbon.name: Local Data Staging
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) creates a base directory that contains the files and folders that are collected.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)

Carbon.name: Query Registry
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) enumerates values in the Registry.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)

Carbon.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted/Obfuscated Non-C2 Protocol
Carbon.description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) uses HTTP to send data to the C2 server.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)

Epic.name: Archive via Library
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) compresses the collected data with bzip2 before sending it to the C2 server.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Aug 2014)

Epic.name: System Service Discovery
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) uses the tasklist /svc command to list the services on the system.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

Epic.name: Remote System Discovery
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) uses the net view command on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

Epic.name: System Time Discovery
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) uses the net time command to get the system time from the machine and collect the current date and time zone information.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

Epic.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) uses the net use, net session, and netstat commands to gather information on network connections.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Aug 2014)

Epic.name: File Deletion
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) has a command to delete a file from the machine.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Aug 2014)

Epic.name: Query Registry
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) uses the rem reg query command to obtain values from Registry keys.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

Epic.name: Web Protocols
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2 communications.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Aug 2014)

Epic.name: File and Directory Discovery
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) recursively searches for all .doc files on the system and collects a directory listing of the Desktop, %TEMP%, and %WINDOWS%\Temp directories.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Aug 2014)

Epic.name: Local Account
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) gathers a list of all user accounts, privilege classes, and time of last logon.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Aug 2014)

Epic.name: Security Software Discovery
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) searches for anti-malware services running on the victim’s machine and terminates itself if it finds them.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

Epic.name: Process Discovery
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) uses the tasklist /v command to obtain a list of processes.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Aug 2014)

Epic.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) encrypts commands from the C2 server using a hardcoded key.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

Epic.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) collects the user name from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Aug 2014)

Epic.name: Archive Collected Data
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) encrypts collected data using a public key framework before sending it over the C2 channel.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla) Some variants encrypt the collected data with AES and encode it with base64 before transmitting it to the C2 server.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Aug 2014)

Epic.name: Local Groups
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) gathers information on local group names.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Aug 2014)

Epic.name: System Information Discovery
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) collects the OS version, hardware information, computer name, available system memory status, disk space information, and system and user language settings.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Aug 2014)

Epic.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) heavily obfuscates its code to make analysis more difficult.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

Epic.name: Code Signing
Epic.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used valid digital certificates from Sysprint AG to sign its [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) dropper.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

Epic.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) uses the nbtstat -n and nbtstat -s commands on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

Epic.name: Extra Window Memory Injection
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) has overwritten the function pointer in the extra window memory of Explorer's Shell_TrayWnd in order to execute malicious code in the context of the explorer.exe process.(Citation: ESET Recon Snake Nest)

TinyZBot.name: Windows Service
TinyZBot.description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) can install as a Windows service for persistence.(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

TinyZBot.name: Screen Capture
TinyZBot.description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) contains screen capture functionality.(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

TinyZBot.name: Windows Command Shell
TinyZBot.description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) supports execution from the command-line.(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

TinyZBot.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
TinyZBot.description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) can create a shortcut in the Windows startup folder for persistence.(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

TinyZBot.name: Shortcut Modification
TinyZBot.description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) can create a shortcut in the Windows startup folder for persistence.(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

TinyZBot.name: Disable or Modify Tools
TinyZBot.description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) can disable Avira anti-virus.(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

TinyZBot.name: Clipboard Data
TinyZBot.description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) contains functionality to collect information from the clipboard.(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

Sakula.name: Windows Command Shell
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) calls cmd.exe to run various DLL files via rundll32 and also to perform file cleanup. [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) also has the capability to invoke a reverse shell.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

Sakula.name: File Deletion
Sakula.description: Some [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) samples use cmd.exe to delete temporary files.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

Sakula.name: Windows Service
Sakula.description: Some [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) samples install themselves as services for persistence by calling WinExec with the net start argument.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

Sakula.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) has the capability to download files.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

Sakula.name: DLL Side-Loading
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) uses DLL side-loading, typically using a digitally signed sample of Kaspersky Anti-Virus (AV) 6.0 for Windows Workstations or McAfee's Outlook Scan About Box to load malicious DLL files.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

Sakula.name: Rundll32
