Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) calls cmd.exe to run various DLL files via rundll32.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

Sakula.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Sakula.description: Most [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) samples maintain persistence by setting the Registry Run key SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ in the HKLM or HKCU hive, with the Registry value and file name varying by sample.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

Sakula.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) uses single-byte XOR obfuscation to obfuscate many of its files.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

Sakula.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) encodes C2 traffic with single-byte XOR keys.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

Sakula.name: Web Protocols
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) uses HTTP for C2.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

Sakula.name: Bypass User Access Control
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) contains UAC bypass code for both 32- and 64-bit systems.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

Micropsia.name: File and Directory Discovery
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) can perform a recursive directory listing for all volume drives available on the victim's machine and can also fetch specific files by their paths.(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: Automated Collection
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) executes an RAR tool to recursively archive files based on a predefined list of file extensions (*.xls, *.xlsx, *.csv, *.odt, *.doc, *.docx, *.ppt, *.pptx, *.pdf, *.mdb, *.accdb, *.accde, *.txt).(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: Security Software Discovery
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) searches for anti-virus software and firewall products installed on the victim’s machine using WMI.(Citation: Talos Micropsia June 2017)(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) collects the username from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Talos Micropsia June 2017)

Micropsia.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) obfuscates the configuration with a custom Base64 and XOR.(Citation: Talos Micropsia June 2017)(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: Audio Capture
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) can perform microphone recording.(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: Archive via Utility
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) creates a RAR archive based on collected files on the victim's machine.(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: Screen Capture
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) takes screenshots every 90 seconds by calling the Gdi32.BitBlt API.(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: System Information Discovery
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) gathers the hostname and OS version from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Talos Micropsia June 2017)(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: Hidden Files and Directories
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) creates a new hidden directory to store all components' outputs in a dedicated sub-folder for each.(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) can download and execute an executable from the C2 server.(Citation: Talos Micropsia June 2017)(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: Keylogging
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) has keylogging capabilities.(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: Web Protocols
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2 network communications.(Citation: Talos Micropsia June 2017)(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: Shortcut Modification
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) creates a shortcut to maintain persistence.(Citation: Talos Micropsia June 2017)

Micropsia.name: Windows Command Shell
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) creates a command-line shell using cmd.exe.(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Micropsia.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) searches for anti-virus software and firewall products installed on the victim’s machine using WMI.(Citation: Talos Micropsia June 2017)(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)

Octopus.name: Web Protocols
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) uses HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)

Octopus.name: System Information Discovery
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) collects system drive information, the computer name, and the size of the disk.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)

Octopus.name: Standard Encoding
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) encodes C2 communications in Base64.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)

Octopus.name: Screen Capture
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) can capture screenshots of the victims’ machine.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)

Octopus.name: File and Directory Discovery
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) collects information on the Windows directory and searches for compressed RAR files on the host.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)

Octopus.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) collects the host IP address from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)

Octopus.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) uses wmic.exe for local discovery information.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)

Octopus.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) can upload and download files to and from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)

Octopus.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) collects the username from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)

Zeroaccess.name: NTFS File Attributes
Zeroaccess.description: Some variants of the [Zeroaccess](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0027) Trojan have been known to store data in Extended Attributes.(Citation: Ciubotariu 2014)

Zeroaccess.name: Rootkit
Zeroaccess.description: [Zeroaccess](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0027) is a kernel-mode rootkit.(Citation: Sophos ZeroAccess)

Azorult.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can collect host IP information from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)

Azorult.name: Credentials In Files
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can steal credentials in files belonging to common software such as Skype, Telegram, and Steam.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)

Azorult.name: Process Discovery
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can collect a list of running processes by calling CreateToolhelp32Snapshot.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)(Citation: Proofpoint Azorult July 2018)

Azorult.name: Query Registry
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can check for installed software on the system under the Registry key Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)

Azorult.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can collect the username from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)

Azorult.name: System Information Discovery
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can collect the machine information, system architecture, the OS version, computer name, Windows product name, the number of CPU cores, video card information, and the system language.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)(Citation: Proofpoint Azorult July 2018)

Azorult.name: Create Process with Token
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can call WTSQueryUserToken and CreateProcessAsUser to start a new process with local system privileges.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)

Azorult.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can encrypt C2 traffic using XOR.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)(Citation: Proofpoint Azorult July 2018)

Azorult.name: Process Hollowing
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can decrypt the payload into memory, create a new suspended process of itself, then inject a decrypted payload to the new process and resume new process execution.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)

Azorult.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) uses an XOR key to decrypt content and uses Base64 to decode the C2 address.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)(Citation: Proofpoint Azorult July 2018)

Azorult.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can download and execute additional files. [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) has also downloaded a ransomware payload called Hermes.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)(Citation: Proofpoint Azorult July 2018)

Azorult.name: File and Directory Discovery
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can recursively search for files in folders and collects files from the desktop with certain extensions.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)

Azorult.name: Screen Capture
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can capture screenshots of the victim’s machines.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)

Azorult.name: System Time Discovery
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can collect the time zone information from the system.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)(Citation: Proofpoint Azorult July 2018)

Azorult.name: File Deletion
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can delete files from victim machines.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)

Azorult.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can steal credentials from the victim's browser.(Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)

OceanSalt.name: Non-Standard Encoding
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can encode data with a NOT operation before sending the data to the control server.(Citation: McAfee Oceansalt Oct 2018)

OceanSalt.name: Windows Command Shell
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can create a reverse shell on the infected endpoint using cmd.exe.(Citation: McAfee Oceansalt Oct 2018) [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) has been executed via malicious macros.(Citation: McAfee Oceansalt Oct 2018)

OceanSalt.name: Process Discovery
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can collect the name and ID for every process running on the system.(Citation: McAfee Oceansalt Oct 2018)

OceanSalt.name: File and Directory Discovery
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can extract drive information from the endpoint and search files on the system.(Citation: McAfee Oceansalt Oct 2018)

OceanSalt.name: File Deletion
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can delete files from the system.(Citation: McAfee Oceansalt Oct 2018)

OceanSalt.name: Commonly Used Port
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) uses Port Number 8080 for C2.(Citation: McAfee Oceansalt Oct 2018)

OceanSalt.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can collect the victim’s IP address.(Citation: McAfee Oceansalt Oct 2018)

OceanSalt.name: System Information Discovery
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can collect the computer name from the system.(Citation: McAfee Oceansalt Oct 2018)

OceanSalt.name: Spearphishing Attachment
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) has been delivered via spearphishing emails with Microsoft Office attachments.(Citation: McAfee Oceansalt Oct 2018)

Cardinal RAT.name: Windows Command Shell
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can execute commands.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Process Injection
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) injects into a newly spawned process created from a native Windows executable.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) establishes Persistence by setting the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\Load Registry key to point to its executable.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Commonly Used Port
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) is downloaded using HTTP over port 443.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: System Information Discovery
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can collect the hostname, Microsoft Windows version, and processor architecture from a victim machine.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Fallback Channels
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can communicate over multiple C2 host and port combinations.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) encodes many of its artifacts and is encrypted (AES-128) when downloaded.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can download and execute additional payloads.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Malicious File
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) lures victims into executing malicious macros embedded within Microsoft Excel documents.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Query Registry
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) contains watchdog functionality that periodically ensures HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\Load is set to point to its executable.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Proxy
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can act as a reverse proxy.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: File Deletion
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can uninstall itself, including deleting its executable.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can collect the username from a victim machine.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) checks its current working directory upon execution and also contains watchdog functionality that ensures its executable is located in the correct path (else it will rewrite the payload).(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Process Discovery
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) contains watchdog functionality that ensures its process is always running, else spawns a new instance.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Web Protocols
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) is downloaded using HTTP over port 443.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) uses a secret key with a series of XOR and addition operations to encrypt C2 traffic.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Modify Registry
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) sets HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\Load to point to its executable.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Archive via Library
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) applies compression to C2 traffic using the ZLIB library.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Keylogging
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can log keystrokes.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Screen Capture
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can capture screenshots.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) decodes many of its artifacts and is decrypted (AES-128) after being downloaded.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cardinal RAT.name: Compile After Delivery
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) and its watchdog component are compiled and executed after being delivered to victims as embedded, uncompiled source code.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)

Cannon.name: System Time Discovery
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can collect the current time zone information from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)

Cannon.name: Mail Protocols
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) uses SMTP/S and POP3/S for C2 communications by sending and receiving emails.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)

Cannon.name: File and Directory Discovery
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can obtain victim drive information as well as a list of folders in C:\Program Files.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)

Cannon.name: Screen Capture
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can take a screenshot of the desktop.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)

Cannon.name: Process Discovery
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can obtain a list of processes running on the system.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)

Cannon.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) adds the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon to establish persistence.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)

Cannon.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can gather the username from the system.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)

Cannon.name: System Information Discovery
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can gather system information from the victim’s machine such as the OS version, machine name, and drive information.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)

Cannon.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) exfiltrates collected data over email via SMTP/S and POP3/S C2 channels.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)

Cannon.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can download a payload for execution.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)

Cannon.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) uses port 587 for C2.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)

Agent.btz.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Agent.btz.description: [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) attempts to download an encrypted binary from a specified domain.(Citation: ThreatExpert Agent.btz)

Agent.btz.name: Archive via Custom Method
Agent.btz.description: [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) saves system information into an XML file that is then XOR-encoded.(Citation: ThreatExpert Agent.btz)

Agent.btz.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Agent.btz.description: [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) collects the network adapter’s IP and MAC address as well as IP addresses of the network adapter’s default gateway, primary/secondary WINS, DHCP, and DNS servers, and saves them into a log file.(Citation: ThreatExpert Agent.btz)

Agent.btz.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Agent.btz.description: [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) obtains the victim username and saves it to a file.(Citation: ThreatExpert Agent.btz)

Agent.btz.name: Replication Through Removable Media
Agent.btz.description: [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) drops itself onto removable media devices and creates an autorun.inf file with an instruction to run that file. When the device is inserted into another system, it opens autorun.inf and loads the malware.(Citation: ThreatExpert Agent.btz)

Agent.btz.name: Exfiltration over USB
Agent.btz.description: [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) creates a file named thumb.dd on all USB flash drives connected to the victim. This file contains information about the infected system and activity logs.(Citation: Securelist Agent.btz)

pngdowner.name: Web Protocols
pngdowner.description: [pngdowner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0067) uses HTTP for command and control.(Citation: CrowdStrike Putter Panda)

pngdowner.name: File Deletion
pngdowner.description: [pngdowner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0067) deletes content from C2 communications that was saved to the user's temporary directory.(Citation: CrowdStrike Putter Panda)

pngdowner.name: Credentials In Files
pngdowner.description: If an initial connectivity check fails, [pngdowner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0067) attempts to extract proxy details and credentials from Windows Protected Storage and from the IE Credentials Store. This allows the adversary to use the proxy credentials for subsequent requests if they enable outbound HTTP access.(Citation: CrowdStrike Putter Panda)

OopsIE.name: System Information Discovery
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) checks for information on the CPU fan, temperature, mouse, hard disk, and motherboard as part of its anti-VM checks.(Citation: Unit 42 OilRig Sept 2018)

OopsIE.name: File Deletion
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) has the capability to delete files and scripts from the victim's machine.(Citation: Unit 42 OilRig Sept 2018)

OopsIE.name: Archive via Utility
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) compresses collected files with GZipStream before sending them to its C2 server.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)

OopsIE.name: Web Protocols
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) uses HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)(Citation: Unit 42 OilRig Sept 2018)

OopsIE.name: Local Data Staging
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) stages the output from command execution and collected files in specific folders before exfiltration.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)

OopsIE.name: Software Packing
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) uses the SmartAssembly obfuscator to pack an embedded .Net Framework assembly used for C2.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)

OopsIE.name: Standard Encoding
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) encodes data in hexadecimal format over the C2 channel.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)

OopsIE.name: Windows Command Shell
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) uses the command prompt to execute commands on the victim's machine.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)(Citation: Unit 42 OilRig Sept 2018)

OopsIE.name: Scheduled Task
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) creates a scheduled task to run itself every three minutes.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)(Citation: Unit 42 OilRig Sept 2018)

OopsIE.name: Visual Basic
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) creates and uses a VBScript as part of its persistent execution.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)(Citation: Unit 42 OilRig Sept 2018)

OopsIE.name: Data Transfer Size Limits
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) exfiltrates command output and collected files to its C2 server in 1500-byte blocks.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)

OopsIE.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) uses WMI to perform discovery techniques.(Citation: Unit 42 OilRig Sept 2018)

OopsIE.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) can download files from its C2 server to the victim's machine.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)(Citation: Unit 42 OilRig Sept 2018)

OopsIE.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) concatenates then decompresses multiple resources to load an embedded .Net Framework assembly.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)

OopsIE.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) uses the Confuser protector to obfuscate an embedded .Net Framework assembly used for C2. [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) also encodes collected data in hexadecimal format before writing to files on disk and obfuscates strings.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)(Citation: Unit 42 OilRig Sept 2018)

OopsIE.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) can upload files from the victim's machine to its C2 server.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)

OopsIE.name: System Time Discovery
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) checks to see if the system is configured with "Daylight" time and checks for a specific region to be set for the timezone.(Citation: Unit 42 OilRig Sept 2018)

OopsIE.name: System Checks
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) performs several anti-VM and sandbox checks on the victim's machine. One technique the group has used was to perform a WMI query SELECT * FROM MSAcpi_ThermalZoneTemperature to check the temperature to see if it’s running in a virtual environment.(Citation: Unit 42 OilRig Sept 2018)

OopsIE.name: Archive via Custom Method
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) compresses collected files with a simple character replacement scheme before sending them to its C2 server.(Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)

Mis-Type.name: Commonly Used Port
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) communicates over common ports such as TCP 80, 443, and 25.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Mis-Type.name: Local Account
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) may create a file containing the results of the command cmd.exe /c net user {Username}.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Mis-Type.name: Fallback Channels
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) first attempts to use a Base64-encoded network protocol over a raw TCP socket for C2, and if that method fails, falls back to a secondary HTTP-based protocol to communicate to an alternate C2 server.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Mis-Type.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) runs tests to determine the privilege level of the compromised user.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Mis-Type.name: Local Account
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) may create a temporary user on the system named “Lost_{Unique Identifier}.”(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Mis-Type.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) network traffic can communicate over a raw socket.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Mis-Type.name: Web Protocols
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) network traffic can communicate over HTTP.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Mis-Type.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) network traffic can communicate over a raw socket.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Mis-Type.name: Windows Command Shell
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) uses cmd.exe to run commands for enumerating the host.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Mis-Type.name: Standard Encoding
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) uses Base64 encoding for C2 traffic.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Mis-Type.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) saves itself as a file named msdtc.exe, which is also the name of the legitimate Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator service binary.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)(Citation: Microsoft DTC)

Mis-Type.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) may create a file containing the results of the command cmd.exe /c ipconfig /all.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Mis-Type.name: System Information Discovery
Mis-Type.description: The initial beacon packet for [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) contains the operating system version and file system of the victim.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

FruitFly.name: File and Directory Discovery
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) looks for specific files and file types.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

FruitFly.name: Hidden Files and Directories
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) saves itself with a leading "." to make it a hidden file.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

FruitFly.name: File Deletion
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) will delete files on the system.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

FruitFly.name: Screen Capture
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) takes screenshots of the user's desktop.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

FruitFly.name: Process Discovery
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) has the ability to list processes on the system.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

FruitFly.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) executes and stores obfuscated Perl scripts.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

FruitFly.name: Launch Agent
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) persists via a Launch Agent.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

CORESHELL.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) obfuscates strings using a custom stream cipher.(Citation: FireEye APT28)

CORESHELL.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) downloads another dropper from its C2 server.(Citation: FireEye APT28)

CORESHELL.name: Web Protocols
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) can communicate over HTTP for C2.(Citation: FireEye APT28)(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 19)

CORESHELL.name: System Information Discovery
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) collects hostname, volume serial number and OS version data from the victim and sends the information to its C2 server.(Citation: FireEye APT28)

CORESHELL.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) has established persistence by creating autostart extensibility point (ASEP) Registry entries in the Run key and other Registry keys, as well as by creating shortcuts in the Internet Explorer Quick Start folder.(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 19)

CORESHELL.name: Symmetric Cryptography
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) C2 messages are encrypted with custom stream ciphers using six-byte or eight-byte keys.(Citation: FireEye APT28)

CORESHELL.name: Binary Padding
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) contains unused machine instructions in a likely attempt to hinder analysis.(Citation: FireEye APT28)

CORESHELL.name: Standard Encoding
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) C2 messages are Base64-encoded.(Citation: FireEye APT28)

CORESHELL.name: Rundll32
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) is installed via execution of rundll32 with an export named "init" or "InitW."(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 19)

CORESHELL.name: Mail Protocols
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) can communicate over SMTP and POP3 for C2.(Citation: FireEye APT28)(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 19)

httpclient.name: Windows Command Shell
httpclient.description: [httpclient](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0068) opens cmd.exe on the victim.(Citation: CrowdStrike Putter Panda)

httpclient.name: Symmetric Cryptography
httpclient.description: [httpclient](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0068) encrypts C2 content with XOR using a single byte, 0x12.(Citation: CrowdStrike Putter Panda)

httpclient.name: Web Protocols
httpclient.description: [httpclient](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0068) uses HTTP for command and control.(Citation: CrowdStrike Putter Panda)

Final1stspy.name: System Information Discovery
Final1stspy.description: [Final1stspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0355) obtains victim Microsoft Windows version information and CPU architecture.(Citation: Unit 42 Nokki Oct 2018)

Final1stspy.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Final1stspy.description: [Final1stspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0355) creates a Registry Run key to establish persistence.(Citation: Unit 42 Nokki Oct 2018)

Final1stspy.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Final1stspy.description: [Final1stspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0355) uses Python code to deobfuscate base64-encoded strings.(Citation: Unit 42 Nokki Oct 2018)

Final1stspy.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Final1stspy.description: [Final1stspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0355) obfuscates strings with base64 encoding.(Citation: Unit 42 Nokki Oct 2018)

Final1stspy.name: Process Discovery
Final1stspy.description: [Final1stspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0355) obtains a list of running processes.(Citation: Unit 42 Nokki Oct 2018)

Final1stspy.name: Web Protocols
Final1stspy.description: [Final1stspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0355) uses HTTP for C2.(Citation: Unit 42 Nokki Oct 2018)

ELMER.name: Process Discovery
ELMER.description: [ELMER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0064) is capable of performing process listings.(Citation: FireEye EPS Awakens Part 2)

ELMER.name: Commonly Used Port
ELMER.description: [ELMER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0064) uses HTTP over port 443 for command and control.(Citation: FireEye EPS Awakens Part 2)

ELMER.name: Web Protocols
ELMER.description: [ELMER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0064) uses HTTP for command and control.(Citation: FireEye EPS Awakens Part 2)

ELMER.name: File and Directory Discovery
ELMER.description: [ELMER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0064) is capable of performing directory listings.(Citation: FireEye EPS Awakens Part 2)

Shamoon.name: Bypass User Access Control
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) attempts to disable UAC remote restrictions by modifying the Registry.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)

Shamoon.name: Domain Accounts
Shamoon.description: If [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) cannot access shares using current privileges, it attempts access using hard coded, domain-specific credentials gathered earlier in the intrusion.(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)

Shamoon.name: Scheduled Task
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) copies an executable payload to the target system by using [Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1077) and then scheduling an unnamed task to execute the malware.(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)

Shamoon.name: System Information Discovery
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) obtains the victim's operating system version and keyboard layout and sends the information to the C2 server.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)

Shamoon.name: Windows Service
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) creates a new service named “ntssrv” to execute the payload. Newer versions create the "MaintenaceSrv" and "hdv_725x" services.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)

Shamoon.name: Masquerade Task or Service
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) creates a new service named “ntssrv” that attempts to appear legitimate; the service's display name is “Microsoft Network Realtime Inspection Service” and its description is “Helps guard against time change attempts targeting known and newly discovered vulnerabilities in network time protocols.” Newer versions create the "MaintenaceSrv" service, which misspells the word "maintenance."(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: McAfee Shamoon December 2018)

Shamoon.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) obtains the target's IP address and local network segment.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: McAfee Shamoon December 2018)

Shamoon.name: Remote System Discovery
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) scans the C-class subnet of the IPs on the victim's interfaces.(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)

Shamoon.name: System Time Discovery
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) obtains the system time and will only activate if it is greater than a preset date.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)

Shamoon.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) accesses network share(s), enables share access to the target device, copies an executable payload to the target system, and uses a [Scheduled Task/Job](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053) to execute the malware.(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)

Shamoon.name: Web Protocols
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has used HTTP for C2.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)

Shamoon.name: Query Registry
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) queries several Registry keys to identify hard disk partitions to overwrite.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)

Shamoon.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) contains base64-encoded strings.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)

Shamoon.name: Service Execution
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) creates a new service named “ntssrv” to execute the payload. [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) can also spread via [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029).(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: McAfee Shamoon December19 2018)

Shamoon.name: Modify Registry
Shamoon.description: Once [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has access to a network share, it enables the RemoteRegistry service on the target system. It will then connect to the system with RegConnectRegistryW and modify the Registry to disable UAC remote restrictions by setting SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System\LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy to 1.(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: McAfee Shamoon December 2018)

Shamoon.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) can download an executable to run on the victim.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)

Shamoon.name: Data Destruction
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) attempts to overwrite operating system files and disk structures with image files.(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016) In a later variant, randomly generated data was used for data overwrites.(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)(Citation: McAfee Shamoon December 2018)

Shamoon.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has an operational mode for encrypting data instead of overwriting it.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)

Shamoon.name: Disk Structure Wipe
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has been seen overwriting features of disk structure such as the MBR.(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)

Shamoon.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) attempts to copy itself to remote machines on the network.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)

Shamoon.name: Token Impersonation/Theft
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) can impersonate tokens using LogonUser, ImpersonateLoggedOnUser, and ImpersonateNamedPipeClient.(Citation: McAfee Shamoon December 2018)

Shamoon.name: System Shutdown/Reboot
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) will reboot the infected system once the wiping functionality has been completed.(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)(Citation: McAfee Shamoon December 2018)

Shamoon.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) decrypts ciphertext using an XOR cipher and a base64-encoded string.(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)

Shamoon.name: Timestomp
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) can change the modified time for files to evade forensic detection.(Citation: McAfee Shamoon December 2018)

Kwampirs.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects network adapter and interface information by using the commands ipconfig /all, arp -a and route print. It also collects the system's MAC address with getmac and domain configuration with net config workstation.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Local Groups
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of users belonging to the local users and administrators groups with the commands net localgroup administrators and net localgroup users.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Binary Padding
Kwampirs.description: Before writing to disk, [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) inserts a randomly generated string into the middle of the decrypted payload in an attempt to evade hash-based detections.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Masquerade Task or Service
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) establishes persistence by adding a new service with the display name "WMI Performance Adapter Extension" in an attempt to masquerade as a legitimate WMI service.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Windows Service
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) creates a new service named WmiApSrvEx to establish persistence.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) downloads additional files that are base64-encoded and encrypted with another cipher.(Citation: Symantec Security Center Trojan.Kwampirs)

Kwampirs.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) downloads additional files from C2 servers.(Citation: Symantec Security Center Trojan.Kwampirs)

Kwampirs.name: System Information Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects OS version information such as registered owner details, manufacturer details, processor type, available storage, installed patches, hostname, version info, system date, and other system information by using the commands systeminfo, net config workstation, hostname, ver, set, and date /t.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Remote System Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of available servers with the command net view.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of active and listening connections by using the command netstat -nao as well as a list of available network mappings with net use.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Process Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of running services with the command tasklist /v.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Password Policy Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects password policy information with the command net accounts.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Local Account
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of accounts with the command net users.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Network Share Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of network shares with the command net share.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) decrypts and extracts a copy of its main DLL payload when executing.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects registered owner details by using the commands systeminfo and net config workstation.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: File and Directory Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of files and directories in C:\ with the command dir /s /a c:\ >> "C:\windows\TEMP\[RANDOM].tmp".(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) copies itself over network shares to move laterally on a victim network.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Rundll32
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) uses rundll32.exe in a Registry value added to establish persistence.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Fallback Channels
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) uses a large list of C2 servers that it cycles through until a successful connection is established.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: System Service Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of running services with the command tasklist /svc.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

Kwampirs.name: Domain Groups
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of domain groups with the command net localgroup /domain.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018)

FLASHFLOOD.name: Local Data Staging
FLASHFLOOD.description: [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) stages data it copies from the local system or removable drives in the "%WINDIR%\$NtUninstallKB885884$\" directory.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

FLASHFLOOD.name: Data from Removable Media
FLASHFLOOD.description: [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on removable media and copies them to a staging area. The default file types copied would include data copied to the drive by [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035).(Citation: FireEye APT30)

FLASHFLOOD.name: Archive via Custom Method
FLASHFLOOD.description: [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) employs the same encoding scheme as [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) for data it stages. Data is compressed with zlib, and bytes are rotated four times before being XOR'ed with 0x23.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

FLASHFLOOD.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
FLASHFLOOD.description: [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) achieves persistence by making an entry in the Registry's Run key.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

FLASHFLOOD.name: Data from Local System
FLASHFLOOD.description: [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on the local system. [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) will scan the My Recent Documents, Desktop, Temporary Internet Files, and TEMP directories. [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) also collects information stored in the Windows Address Book.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

FLASHFLOOD.name: File and Directory Discovery
FLASHFLOOD.description: [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on the local system and removable media.(Citation: FireEye APT30)

Miner-C.name: Taint Shared Content
Miner-C.description: [Miner-C](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0133) copies itself into the public folder of Network Attached Storage (NAS) devices and infects new victims who open the file.(Citation: Softpedia MinerC)

RATANKBA.name: System Network Connections Discovery
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) uses netstat -ano to search for specific IP address ranges.(Citation: RATANKBA)

RATANKBA.name: System Owner/User Discovery
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) runs the whoami and query user commands.(Citation: RATANKBA)

RATANKBA.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) performs a reflective DLL injection using a given pid.(Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA)(Citation: RATANKBA)

RATANKBA.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) uses WMI to perform process monitoring.(Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA)(Citation: RATANKBA)

RATANKBA.name: Remote System Discovery
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) runs the net view /domain and net view commands.(Citation: RATANKBA)

RATANKBA.name: System Information Discovery
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) gathers information about the OS architecture, OS name, and OS version/Service pack.(Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA)(Citation: RATANKBA)

RATANKBA.name: Process Discovery
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) lists the system’s processes.(Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA)(Citation: RATANKBA)

RATANKBA.name: PowerShell
RATANKBA.description: There is a variant of [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) that uses a PowerShell script instead of the traditional PE form.(Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA)(Citation: RATANKBA)

RATANKBA.name: Windows Command Shell
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) uses cmd.exe to execute commands.(Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA)(Citation: RATANKBA)

RATANKBA.name: System Service Discovery
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) uses tasklist /svc to display running tasks.(Citation: RATANKBA)

RATANKBA.name: Web Protocols
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) uses HTTP/HTTPS for command and control communication.(Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA)(Citation: RATANKBA)

RATANKBA.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) uploads and downloads information.(Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA)(Citation: RATANKBA)

RATANKBA.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) gathers the victim’s IP address via the ipconfig -all command.(Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA)(Citation: RATANKBA)

XAgentOSX.name: File and Directory Discovery
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the readFiles function to return a detailed listing (sometimes recursive) of a specified directory.(Citation: XAgentOSX 2017) [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the showBackupIosFolder function to check for IOS device backups by running ls -la ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup/.(Citation: XAgentOSX 2017)

XAgentOSX.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the getFirefoxPassword function to attempt to locate Firefox passwords.(Citation: XAgentOSX 2017)

XAgentOSX.name: Screen Capture
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the takeScreenShot (along with startTakeScreenShot and stopTakeScreenShot) functions to take screenshots using the CGGetActiveDisplayList, CGDisplayCreateImage, and NSImage:initWithCGImage methods.(Citation: XAgentOSX 2017)

XAgentOSX.name: System Information Discovery
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the getInstalledAPP function to run ls -la /Applications to gather what applications are installed.(Citation: XAgentOSX 2017)

XAgentOSX.name: File Transfer Protocols
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the ftpUpload function to use the FTPManager:uploadFile method to upload files from the target system.(Citation: XAgentOSX 2017)

XAgentOSX.name: Process Discovery
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the getProcessList function to run ps aux to get running processes.(Citation: XAgentOSX 2017)

XAgentOSX.name: Keylogging
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains keylogging functionality that will monitor for active application windows and write them to the log, it can handle special characters, and it will buffer by default 50 characters before sending them out over the C2 infrastructure.(Citation: XAgentOSX 2017)

XAgentOSX.name: File Deletion
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the deletFileFromPath function to delete a specified file using the NSFileManager:removeFileAtPath method.(Citation: XAgentOSX 2017)

XAgentOSX.name: Native API
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the execFile function to execute a specified file on the system using the NSTask:launch method.(Citation: XAgentOSX 2017)

XAgentOSX.name: System Owner/User Discovery
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the getInfoOSX function to return the OS X version as well as the current user.(Citation: XAgentOSX 2017)

Winnti for Windows.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Winnti for Windows.description: A [Winnti for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) implant file was named ASPNET_FILTER.DLL, mimicking the legitimate ASP.NET ISAPI filter DLL with the same name.(Citation: Microsoft Winnti Jan 2017)

Winnti for Windows.name: Rundll32
Winnti for Windows.description: The [Winnti for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) installer loads a DLL using rundll32.(Citation: Microsoft Winnti Jan 2017)

Winnti for Windows.name: Windows Service
Winnti for Windows.description: [Winnti for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) sets its DLL file as a new service in the Registry to establish persistence.(Citation: Microsoft Winnti Jan 2017)

Wingbird.name: Security Software Discovery
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) checks for the presence of Bitdefender security software.(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21)

Wingbird.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) exploits CVE-2016-4117 to allow an executable to gain escalated privileges.(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21)

Wingbird.name: LSASS Driver
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) drops a malicious file (sspisrv.dll) alongside a copy of lsass.exe, which is used to register a service that loads sspisrv.dll as a driver. The payload of the malicious driver (located in its entry-point function) is executed when loaded by lsass.exe before the spoofed service becomes unstable and crashes.(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21)(Citation: Microsoft Wingbird Nov 2017)

Wingbird.name: Windows Service
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) uses services.exe to register a new autostart service named "Audit Service" using a copy of the local lsass.exe file.(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21)(Citation: Microsoft Wingbird Nov 2017)

Wingbird.name: Process Injection
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) performs multiple process injections to hijack system processes and execute malicious code.(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21)

Wingbird.name: DLL Side-Loading
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) side loads a malicious file, sspisrv.dll, in part of a spoofed lssas.exe service.(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21)(Citation: Microsoft Wingbird Nov 2017)

Wingbird.name: Service Execution
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) uses services.exe to register a new autostart service named "Audit Service" using a copy of the local lsass.exe file.(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21)(Citation: Microsoft Wingbird Nov 2017)

Wingbird.name: File Deletion
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) deletes its payload along with the payload's parent process after it finishes copying files.(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21)

Wingbird.name: System Information Discovery
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) checks the victim OS version after executing to determine where to drop files based on whether the victim is 32-bit or 64-bit.(Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21)

gh0st RAT.name: DLL Side-Loading
gh0st RAT.description: A [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) variant has used DLL side-loading.(Citation: Arbor Musical Chairs Feb 2018)

gh0st RAT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) can download files to the victim’s machine.(Citation: Nccgroup Gh0st April 2018)

gh0st RAT.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) is able to open a remote shell to execute commands.(Citation: FireEye Hacking Team)(Citation: Nccgroup Gh0st April 2018)

gh0st RAT.name: Screen Capture
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) can capture the victim’s screen remotely.(Citation: Nccgroup Gh0st April 2018)

gh0st RAT.name: Clear Windows Event Logs
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) is able to wipe event logs.(Citation: FireEye Hacking Team)

gh0st RAT.name: Symmetric Cryptography
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) uses RC4 and XOR to encrypt C2 traffic.(Citation: Nccgroup Gh0st April 2018)

gh0st RAT.name: Commonly Used Port
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) uses port 443 for C2 communications.(Citation: Nccgroup Gh0st April 2018)

gh0st RAT.name: File Deletion
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) has the capability to to delete files.(Citation: FireEye Hacking Team)

gh0st RAT.name: Windows Service
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) can create a new service to establish persistence.(Citation: Nccgroup Gh0st April 2018)

gh0st RAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) adds a Registry Run key to establish persistence.(Citation: Nccgroup Gh0st April 2018)

gh0st RAT.name: Process Discovery
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) has the capability to list processes.(Citation: FireEye Hacking Team)

gh0st RAT.name: Rundll32
gh0st RAT.description: A [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) variant has used rundll32 for execution.(Citation: Arbor Musical Chairs Feb 2018)

Komplex.name: File Deletion
Komplex.description: The [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) trojan supports file deletion.(Citation: Sofacy Komplex Trojan)

Komplex.name: Web Protocols
Komplex.description: The [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) C2 channel uses HTTP POST requests.(Citation: Sofacy Komplex Trojan)

Komplex.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Komplex.description: The [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) C2 channel uses an 11-byte XOR algorithm to hide data.(Citation: Sofacy Komplex Trojan)

Komplex.name: Process Discovery
Komplex.description: The OsInfo function in [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) collects a running process list.(Citation: Sofacy Komplex Trojan)

Komplex.name: Hidden Files and Directories
Komplex.description: The [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) payload is stored in a hidden directory at /Users/Shared/.local/kextd.(Citation: Sofacy Komplex Trojan)

Komplex.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Komplex.description: The OsInfo function in [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) collects the current running username.(Citation: Sofacy Komplex Trojan)

Komplex.name: Launch Agent
Komplex.description: The [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) trojan creates a persistent launch agent called with $HOME/Library/LaunchAgents/com.apple.updates.plist with launchctl load -w ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.apple.updates.plist.(Citation: Sofacy Komplex Trojan)

TINYTYPHON.name: Automated Exfiltration
TINYTYPHON.description: When a document is found matching one of the extensions in the configuration, [TINYTYPHON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0131) uploads it to the C2 server.(Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon)

TINYTYPHON.name: File and Directory Discovery
TINYTYPHON.description: [TINYTYPHON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0131) searches through the drive containing the OS, then all drive letters C through to Z, for documents matching certain extensions.(Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon)

TINYTYPHON.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
TINYTYPHON.description: [TINYTYPHON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0131) has used XOR with 0x90 to obfuscate its configuration file.(Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon)

TINYTYPHON.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
TINYTYPHON.description: [TINYTYPHON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0131) installs itself under Registry Run key to establish persistence.(Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon)

UPPERCUT.name: System Time Discovery
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has the capability to obtain the time zone information and current timestamp of the victim’s machine.(Citation: FireEye APT10 Sept 2018)

UPPERCUT.name: Screen Capture
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) can capture desktop screenshots in the PNG format and send them to the C2 server.(Citation: FireEye APT10 Sept 2018)

UPPERCUT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has the capability to gather the victim's proxy information.(Citation: FireEye APT10 Sept 2018)

UPPERCUT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has the capability to collect the current logged on user’s username from a machine.(Citation: FireEye APT10 Sept 2018)

UPPERCUT.name: Windows Command Shell
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) uses cmd.exe to execute commands on the victim’s machine.(Citation: FireEye APT10 Sept 2018)

UPPERCUT.name: Web Protocols
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has used HTTP for C2, including sending error codes in Cookie headers.(Citation: FireEye APT10 Sept 2018)

UPPERCUT.name: File and Directory Discovery
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has the capability to gather the victim's current directory.(Citation: FireEye APT10 Sept 2018)

UPPERCUT.name: System Information Discovery
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has the capability to gather the system’s hostname and OS version.(Citation: FireEye APT10 Sept 2018)

UPPERCUT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) can download and upload files to and from the victim’s machine.(Citation: FireEye APT10 Sept 2018)

UPPERCUT.name: Symmetric Cryptography
UPPERCUT.description: Some versions of [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) have used the hard-coded string “this is the encrypt key” for Blowfish encryption when communicating with a C2. Later versions have hard-coded keys uniquely for each C2 address.(Citation: FireEye APT10 Sept 2018)

iKitten.name: Process Discovery
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) lists the current processes running.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

iKitten.name: GUI Input Capture
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) prompts the user for their credentials.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

iKitten.name: Hidden Files and Directories
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) saves itself with a leading "." so that it's hidden from users by default.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

iKitten.name: Archive via Utility
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) will zip up the /Library/Keychains directory before exfiltrating it.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

iKitten.name: Rc.common
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) adds an entry to the rc.common file for persistence.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

iKitten.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) will look for the current IP address.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

iKitten.name: Keychain
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) collects the keychains on the system.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)

Emissary.name: Binary Padding
Emissary.description: A variant of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) appends junk data to the end of its DLL file to create a large file that may exceed the maximum size that anti-virus programs can scan.(Citation: Emissary Trojan Feb 2016)

Emissary.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Emissary.description: Variants of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) encrypt payloads using various XOR ciphers, as well as a custom algorithm that uses the "srand" and "rand" functions.(Citation: Lotus Blossom Dec 2015)(Citation: Emissary Trojan Feb 2016)

Emissary.name: Windows Command Shell
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to create a remote shell and execute specified commands.(Citation: Lotus Blossom Dec 2015)

Emissary.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Emissary.description: Variants of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) have added Run Registry keys to establish persistence.(Citation: Emissary Trojan Feb 2016)

Emissary.name: System Information Discovery
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to execute ver, systeminfo, and gpresult commands.(Citation: Emissary Trojan Feb 2016)

Emissary.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to execute the command ipconfig /all.(Citation: Emissary Trojan Feb 2016)

Emissary.name: Rundll32
Emissary.description: Variants of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) have used rundll32.exe in Registry values added to establish persistence.(Citation: Emissary Trojan Feb 2016)

Emissary.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) injects its DLL file into a newly spawned Internet Explorer process.(Citation: Lotus Blossom Dec 2015)

Emissary.name: Windows Service
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) is capable of configuring itself as a service.(Citation: Emissary Trojan Feb 2016)

Emissary.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to download files from the C2 server.(Citation: Lotus Blossom Dec 2015)

Emissary.name: Local Groups
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to execute the command net localgroup administrators.(Citation: Emissary Trojan Feb 2016)

Emissary.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Emissary.description: The C2 server response to a beacon sent by a variant of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) contains a 36-character GUID value that is used as an encryption key for subsequent network communications. Some variants of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) use various XOR operations to encrypt C2 data.(Citation: Lotus Blossom Dec 2015)

Emissary.name: Web Protocols
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) uses HTTP or HTTPS for C2.(Citation: Lotus Blossom Dec 2015)

Emissary.name: System Service Discovery
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to execute the command net start to interact with services.(Citation: Emissary Trojan Feb 2016)

SOUNDBITE.name: DNS
SOUNDBITE.description: [SOUNDBITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0157) communicates via DNS for C2.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

SOUNDBITE.name: Application Window Discovery
SOUNDBITE.description: [SOUNDBITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0157) is capable of enumerating application windows.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

SOUNDBITE.name: Modify Registry
SOUNDBITE.description: [SOUNDBITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0157) is capable of modifying the Registry.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

SOUNDBITE.name: System Information Discovery
SOUNDBITE.description: [SOUNDBITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0157) is capable of gathering system information.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

SOUNDBITE.name: File and Directory Discovery
SOUNDBITE.description: [SOUNDBITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0157) is capable of enumerating and manipulating files and directories.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

POWERSOURCE.name: NTFS File Attributes
POWERSOURCE.description: If the victim is using PowerShell 3.0 or later, [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) writes its decoded payload to an alternate data stream (ADS) named kernel32.dll that is saved in %PROGRAMDATA%\Windows\.(Citation: Cisco DNSMessenger March 2017)

POWERSOURCE.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
POWERSOURCE.description: [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) has been observed being used to download [TEXTMATE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0146) and the Cobalt Strike Beacon payload onto victims.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 March 2017)

POWERSOURCE.name: DNS
POWERSOURCE.description: [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) uses DNS TXT records for C2.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 March 2017)(Citation: Cisco DNSMessenger March 2017)

POWERSOURCE.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
POWERSOURCE.description: [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) achieves persistence by setting a Registry Run key, with the path depending on whether the victim account has user or administrator access.(Citation: Cisco DNSMessenger March 2017)

POWERSOURCE.name: PowerShell
POWERSOURCE.description: [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) is a PowerShell backdoor.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 March 2017)(Citation: Cisco DNSMessenger March 2017)

POWERSOURCE.name: Query Registry
POWERSOURCE.description: [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) queries Registry keys in preparation for setting Run keys to achieve persistence.(Citation: Cisco DNSMessenger March 2017)

KARAE.name: Drive-by Compromise
KARAE.description: [KARAE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0215) was distributed through torrent file-sharing websites to South Korean victims, using a YouTube video downloader application as a lure.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

KARAE.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
KARAE.description: [KARAE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0215) can upload and download files, including second-stage malware.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

KARAE.name: System Information Discovery
KARAE.description: [KARAE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0215) can collect system information.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

KARAE.name: Bidirectional Communication
KARAE.description: [KARAE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0215) can use public cloud-based storage providers for command and control.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

HALFBAKED.name: PowerShell
HALFBAKED.description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) can execute PowerShell scripts.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)

HALFBAKED.name: System Information Discovery
HALFBAKED.description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) can obtain information about the OS, processor, and BIOS.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)

HALFBAKED.name: Screen Capture
HALFBAKED.description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) can obtain screenshots from the victim.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)

HALFBAKED.name: File Deletion
HALFBAKED.description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) can delete a specified file.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)

HALFBAKED.name: Process Discovery
HALFBAKED.description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) can obtain information about running processes on the victim.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)

HALFBAKED.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
HALFBAKED.description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) can use WMI queries to gather system information.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)

OwaAuth.name: Archive via Custom Method
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) DES-encrypts captured credentials using the key 12345678 before writing the credentials to a log file.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

OwaAuth.name: Web Protocols
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) uses incoming HTTP requests with a username keyword and commands and handles them as instructions to perform actions.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

OwaAuth.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) uses the filename owaauth.dll, which is a legitimate file that normally resides in %ProgramFiles%\Microsoft\Exchange Server\ClientAccess\Owa\Auth\; the malicious file by the same name is saved in %ProgramFiles%\Microsoft\Exchange Server\ClientAccess\Owa\bin\.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

OwaAuth.name: File and Directory Discovery
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) has a command to list its directory and logical drives.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

OwaAuth.name: Timestomp
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) has a command to timestop a file or directory.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

OwaAuth.name: Keylogging
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) captures and DES-encrypts credentials before writing the username and password to a log file, C:\log.txt.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

OwaAuth.name: DLL Side-Loading
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) has been loaded onto Exchange servers and disguised as an ISAPI filter (DLL file). The IIS w3wp.exe process then loads the malicious DLL.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

OwaAuth.name: Web Shell
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) is a Web shell that appears to be exclusively used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027).
