It is installed as an ISAPI filter on Exchange servers and shares characteristics with the [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020) Web shell.(Citation: Dell TG-3390)

Agent Tesla.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can download additional files for execution on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Talos Agent Tesla Oct 2018)(Citation: DigiTrust Agent Tesla Jan 2017)

Agent Tesla.name: System Time Discovery
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can collect the timestamp from the victim’s machine.(Citation: DigiTrust Agent Tesla Jan 2017)

Agent Tesla.name: Clipboard Data
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can steal data from the victim’s clipboard.(Citation: Talos Agent Tesla Oct 2018)(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla April 2018)(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla June 2017)(Citation: Bitdefender Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Web Protocols
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has used HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: DigiTrust Agent Tesla Jan 2017)(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla June 2017)

Agent Tesla.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has had its code obfuscated in an apparent attempt to make analysis difficult.(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla April 2018) [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has used the Rijndael symmetric encryption algorithm to encrypt strings.(Citation: Malwarebytes Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Process Discovery
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can list the current running processes on the system.(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla June 2017)

Agent Tesla.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can collect the username from the victim’s machine.(Citation: DigiTrust Agent Tesla Jan 2017)(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla April 2018)(Citation: Malwarebytes Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Keylogging
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can log keystrokes on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Talos Agent Tesla Oct 2018)(Citation: DigiTrust Agent Tesla Jan 2017)(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla June 2017)(Citation: Bitdefender Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has enabled TCP on port 587 for C2 communications.(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla April 2018)(Citation: Talos Agent Tesla Oct 2018)

Agent Tesla.name: Disable or Modify Tools
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has the capability to kill any running analysis processes and AV software.(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla June 2017)

Agent Tesla.name: Local Account
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can collect account information from the victim’s machine.(Citation: DigiTrust Agent Tesla Jan 2017)

Agent Tesla.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted/Obfuscated Non-C2 Protocol
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has routines for exfiltration over SMTP, FTP, and HTTP.(Citation: Talos Agent Tesla Oct 2018)(Citation: Bitdefender Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Archive Collected Data
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can encrypt data with 3DES before sending it over to a C2 server.(Citation: Talos Agent Tesla Oct 2018)

Agent Tesla.name: Screen Capture
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can capture screenshots of the victim’s desktop.(Citation: Talos Agent Tesla Oct 2018)(Citation: DigiTrust Agent Tesla Jan 2017)(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla April 2018)(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla June 2017)(Citation: Bitdefender Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can add itself to the Registry as a startup program to establish persistence.(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla April 2018)

Agent Tesla.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can collect the IP address of the victim machine.(Citation: DigiTrust Agent Tesla Jan 2017)

Agent Tesla.name: System Information Discovery
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can collect the system's computer name and also has the capability to collect information on the processor, memory, OS, and video card from the system.(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla April 2018)(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla June 2017)(Citation: Malwarebytes Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Video Capture
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can access the victim’s webcam and record video.(Citation: DigiTrust Agent Tesla Jan 2017)(Citation: Talos Agent Tesla Oct 2018)

Agent Tesla.name: Mail Protocols
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has used SMTP for C2 communications.(Citation: DigiTrust Agent Tesla Jan 2017)(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla June 2017)(Citation: Bitdefender Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Credentials from Password Stores
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has the ability to steal credentials from FTP clients and wireless profiles.(Citation: Malwarebytes Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Hidden Window
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has used ProcessWindowStyle.Hidden to hide windows.(Citation: Malwarebytes Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has the ability to decrypt strings encrypted with the Rijndael symmetric encryption algorithm.(Citation: Malwarebytes Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has he ability to perform anti-sandboxing and anti-virtualization checks.(Citation: Malwarebytes Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Man in the Browser
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has the ability to use form-grabbing to extract data from web data forms.(Citation: Bitdefender Agent Tesla April 2020)

Agent Tesla.name: Malicious File
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has been executed through malicious e-mail attachments (Citation: Bitdefender Agent Tesla April 2020)

UBoatRAT.name: Process Discovery
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) can list running processes on the system.(Citation: PaloAlto UBoatRAT Nov 2017)

UBoatRAT.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) has used a custom command and control protocol to communicate with C2. The string ‘488’ is placed at the top of the payload and encrypts the entre buffer with a static key using a simple XOR cipher.(Citation: PaloAlto UBoatRAT Nov 2017)

UBoatRAT.name: BITS Jobs
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) takes advantage of the /SetNotifyCmdLine option in [BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190) to ensure it stays running on a system to maintain persistence.(Citation: PaloAlto UBoatRAT Nov 2017)

UBoatRAT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) encrypts instructions in the payload using a simple XOR cipher.(Citation: PaloAlto UBoatRAT Nov 2017)

UBoatRAT.name: Bidirectional Communication
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) has used GitHub and a public blog service in Hong Kong for C2 communications.(Citation: PaloAlto UBoatRAT Nov 2017)

UBoatRAT.name: Web Protocols
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) has used HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: PaloAlto UBoatRAT Nov 2017)

UBoatRAT.name: Commonly Used Port
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) uses ports 80 and 443 for C2 communications.(Citation: PaloAlto UBoatRAT Nov 2017)

UBoatRAT.name: Windows Command Shell
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) can start a command shell.(Citation: PaloAlto UBoatRAT Nov 2017)

UBoatRAT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) can upload and download files to the victim’s machine.(Citation: PaloAlto UBoatRAT Nov 2017)

UBoatRAT.name: System Checks
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) checks for virtualization software such as VMWare, VirtualBox, or QEmu on the compromised machine.(Citation: PaloAlto UBoatRAT Nov 2017)

FakeM.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
FakeM.description: Some variants of [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) use SSL to communicate with C2 servers.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

FakeM.name: Symmetric Cryptography
FakeM.description: The original variant of [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) encrypts C2 traffic using a custom encryption cipher that uses an XOR key of “YHCRA” and bit rotation between each XOR operation. Some variants of [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) use RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

FakeM.name: Protocol Impersonation
FakeM.description: [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) C2 traffic attempts to evade detection by resembling data generated by legitimate messenger applications, such as MSN and Yahoo! messengers. Additionally, some variants of [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) use modified SSL code for communications back to C2 servers, making SSL decryption ineffective.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

FakeM.name: Keylogging
FakeM.description: [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) contains a keylogger module.(Citation: Scarlet Mimic Jan 2016)

Power Loader.name: Extra Window Memory Injection
Power Loader.description: [Power Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0177) overwrites Explorer’s Shell_TrayWnd extra window memory to redirect execution to a NTDLL function that is abused to assemble and execute a return-oriented programming (ROP) chain and create a malicious thread within Explorer.exe.(Citation: MalwareTech Power Loader Aug 2013)(Citation: WeLiveSecurity Gapz and Redyms Mar 2013)

TrickBot.name: File and Directory Discovery
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) searches the system for all of the following file extensions: .avi, .mov, .mkv, .mpeg, .mpeg4, .mp4, .mp3, .wav, .ogg, .jpeg, .jpg, .png, .bmp, .gif, .tiff, .ico, .xlsx, and .zip. It can also obtain browsing history, cookies, and plug-in information.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Trend Micro Trickbot Nov 2018)

TrickBot.name: Web Protocols
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses HTTPS to communicate with its C2 servers, to get malware updates, modules that perform most of the malware logic and various configuration files.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)

TrickBot.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) establishes persistence in the Startup folder.(Citation: Trend Micro Trickbot Nov 2018)

TrickBot.name: Commonly Used Port
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses port 443 for C2 communications.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Trend Micro Totbrick Oct 2016)

TrickBot.name: Symmetric Cryptography
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses a custom crypter leveraging Microsoft’s CryptoAPI to encrypt C2 traffic.(Citation: Fidelis TrickBot Oct 2016)

TrickBot.name: Man in the Browser
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses web injects and browser redirection to trick the user into providing their login credentials on a fake or modified web page.(Citation: Fidelis TrickBot Oct 2016)(Citation: IBM TrickBot Nov 2016)(Citation: Microsoft Totbrick Oct 2017)(Citation: Trend Micro Trickbot Nov 2018)

TrickBot.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) downloads several additional files and saves them to the victim's machine.(Citation: Trend Micro Totbrick Oct 2016)

TrickBot.name: System Service Discovery
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) collects a list of install programs and services on the system’s machine.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)

TrickBot.name: System Information Discovery
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) gathers the OS version, CPU type, amount of RAM available from the victim’s machine.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Fidelis TrickBot Oct 2016)

TrickBot.name: Modify Registry
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) can modify registry entries.(Citation: Trend Micro Trickbot Nov 2018)

TrickBot.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses non-descriptive names to hide functionality and uses an AES CBC (256 bits) encryption algorithm for its loader and configuration files.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)

TrickBot.name: Software Packing
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) leverages a custom packer to obfuscate its functionality.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)

TrickBot.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) obtains the IP address and other relevant network information from the victim’s machine.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Trend Micro Trickbot Nov 2018)

TrickBot.name: Disable or Modify Tools
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) can disable Windows Defender.(Citation: Trend Micro Trickbot Nov 2018)

TrickBot.name: Native API
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses the Windows API call, CreateProcessW(), to manage execution flow.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)

TrickBot.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) decodes the configuration data and modules.(Citation: Fidelis TrickBot Oct 2016)

TrickBot.name: Email Account
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) collects email addresses from Outlook.(Citation: Trend Micro Trickbot Nov 2018)

TrickBot.name: Credentials In Files
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) can obtain passwords stored in files from several applications such as Outlook, Filezilla, and WinSCP.(Citation: Trend Micro Trickbot Nov 2018) Additionally, it searches for the ".vnc.lnk" affix to steal VNC credentials.(Citation: TrendMicro Trickbot Feb 2019)

TrickBot.name: Data from Local System
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) collects local files and information from the victim’s local machine.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)

TrickBot.name: Local Account
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) collects the users of the system.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Trend Micro Trickbot Nov 2018)

TrickBot.name: Uncommonly Used Port
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses ports 447 and 8082 for C2 communications.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Fidelis TrickBot Oct 2016)(Citation: Trend Micro Totbrick Oct 2016)

TrickBot.name: Process Hollowing
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) injects into the svchost.exe process.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Trend Micro Totbrick Oct 2016)(Citation: Microsoft Totbrick Oct 2017)

TrickBot.name: Scheduled Task
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) creates a scheduled task on the system that provides persistence.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Trend Micro Totbrick Oct 2016)(Citation: Microsoft Totbrick Oct 2017)

TrickBot.name: Domain Trust Discovery
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) can gather information about domain trusts by utilizing [Nltest](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0359).(Citation: Fortinet TrickBot)

TrickBot.name: Spearphishing Attachment
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) has used an email with an Excel sheet containing a malicious macro to deploy the malware(Citation: TrendMicro Trickbot Feb 2019)

TrickBot.name: Credential API Hooking
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) has the ability to capture RDP credentials by capturing the CredEnumerateA API(Citation: TrendMicro Trickbot Feb 2019)

TrickBot.name: Credentials in Registry
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) has retrieved PuTTY credentials by querying the Software\SimonTatham\Putty\Sessions registry key (Citation: TrendMicro Trickbot Feb 2019)

TrickBot.name: Windows Command Shell
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) has used macros in Excel documents to download and deploy the malware on the user’s machine.(Citation: TrendMicro Trickbot Feb 2019)

TrickBot.name: Malicious File
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) has attempted to get users to launch a malicious Excel attachment to deliver its payload. (Citation: TrendMicro Trickbot Feb 2019)

TrickBot.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) can obtain passwords stored in files from web browsers such as Chrome, Firefox, Internet Explorer, and Microsoft Edge.(Citation: Trend Micro Trickbot Nov 2018)

TrickBot.name: Non-Standard Port
TrickBot.description: Some [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) samples have used HTTP over ports 447 and 8082 for C2.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Fidelis TrickBot Oct 2016)(Citation: Trend Micro Totbrick Oct 2016)

ISMInjector.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
ISMInjector.description: [ISMInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0189) is obfuscated with the off-the-shelf SmartAssembly .NET obfuscator created by red-gate.com.(Citation: OilRig New Delivery Oct 2017)

ISMInjector.name: Process Hollowing
ISMInjector.description: [ISMInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0189) hollows out a newly created process RegASM.exe and injects its payload into the hollowed process.(Citation: OilRig New Delivery Oct 2017)

ISMInjector.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
ISMInjector.description: [ISMInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0189) uses the certutil command to decode a payload file.(Citation: OilRig New Delivery Oct 2017)

ISMInjector.name: Scheduled Task
ISMInjector.description: [ISMInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0189) creates scheduled tasks to establish persistence.(Citation: OilRig New Delivery Oct 2017)

NanoCore.name: Audio Capture
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) can capture audio feeds from the system.(Citation: DigiTrust NanoCore Jan 2017)(Citation: PaloAlto NanoCore Feb 2016)

NanoCore.name: Keylogging
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) can perform keylogging on the victim’s machine.(Citation: PaloAlto NanoCore Feb 2016)

NanoCore.name: Disable or Modify Tools
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) can modify the victim's anti-virus.(Citation: DigiTrust NanoCore Jan 2017)(Citation: PaloAlto NanoCore Feb 2016)

NanoCore.name: Modify Registry
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) has the capability to edit the Registry.(Citation: DigiTrust NanoCore Jan 2017)(Citation: PaloAlto NanoCore Feb 2016)

NanoCore.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) has the capability to download and activate additional modules for execution.(Citation: DigiTrust NanoCore Jan 2017)(Citation: PaloAlto NanoCore Feb 2016)

NanoCore.name: Visual Basic
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) uses VBS files.(Citation: Cofense NanoCore Mar 2018)

NanoCore.name: Symmetric Cryptography
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) uses DES to encrypt the C2 traffic.(Citation: PaloAlto NanoCore Feb 2016)

NanoCore.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) creates a RunOnce key in the Registry to execute its VBS scripts each time the user logs on to the machine.(Citation: Cofense NanoCore Mar 2018)

NanoCore.name: Uncommonly Used Port
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) communicates to its C2 over ports 6666 and 4782.(Citation: Unit 42 Gorgon Group Aug 2018)(Citation: PaloAlto NanoCore Feb 2016)

NanoCore.name: Video Capture
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) can access the victim's webcam and capture data.(Citation: DigiTrust NanoCore Jan 2017)(Citation: PaloAlto NanoCore Feb 2016)

NanoCore.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336)’s plugins were obfuscated with Eazfuscater.NET 3.3.(Citation: PaloAlto NanoCore Feb 2016)

NanoCore.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) gathers the IP address from the victim’s machine.(Citation: DigiTrust NanoCore Jan 2017)

NanoCore.name: Windows Command Shell
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) can open a remote command-line interface and execute commands.(Citation: PaloAlto NanoCore Feb 2016) [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) uses JavaScript files.(Citation: Cofense NanoCore Mar 2018)

NanoCore.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
NanoCore.description: [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) can modify the victim's firewall.(Citation: DigiTrust NanoCore Jan 2017)(Citation: PaloAlto NanoCore Feb 2016)

Seasalt.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Seasalt.description: [Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) has a command to download additional files.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

Seasalt.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Seasalt.description: [Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) creates a Registry entry to ensure infection after reboot under HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\currentVersion\Run.(Citation: McAfee Oceansalt Oct 2018)

Seasalt.name: Web Protocols
Seasalt.description: [Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) uses HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

Seasalt.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Seasalt.description: [Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) obfuscates configuration data.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

Seasalt.name: Windows Service
Seasalt.description: [Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) is capable of installing itself as a service.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

Seasalt.name: Windows Command Shell
Seasalt.description: [Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) uses cmd.exe to create a reverse shell on the infected endpoint.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

Seasalt.name: Process Discovery
Seasalt.description: [Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) has a command to perform a process listing.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

Seasalt.name: File Deletion
Seasalt.description: [Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) has a command to delete a specified file.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

Seasalt.name: Masquerade Task or Service
Seasalt.description: [Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) has masqueraded as a service called "SaSaut" with a display name of "System Authorization Service" in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate service.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

Seasalt.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Seasalt.description: [Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) uses a custom binary protocol for C2.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

Seasalt.name: File and Directory Discovery
Seasalt.description: [Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) has the capability to identify the drive type on a victim.(Citation: McAfee Oceansalt Oct 2018)

zwShell.name: Modify Registry
zwShell.description: [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) can modify the Registry.(Citation: McAfee Night Dragon)

zwShell.name: Scheduled Task
zwShell.description: [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) has used SchTasks for execution.(Citation: McAfee Night Dragon)

zwShell.name: File and Directory Discovery
zwShell.description: [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) can browse the file system.(Citation: McAfee Night Dragon)

zwShell.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
zwShell.description: [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) has used RDP for lateral movement.(Citation: McAfee Night Dragon)

zwShell.name: System Owner/User Discovery
zwShell.description: [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) can obtain the name of the logged-in user on the victim.(Citation: McAfee Night Dragon)

zwShell.name: System Information Discovery
zwShell.description: [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) can obtain the victim PC name and OS version.(Citation: McAfee Night Dragon)

zwShell.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
zwShell.description: [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) has been copied over network shares to move laterally.(Citation: McAfee Night Dragon)

zwShell.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
zwShell.description: [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) can obtain the victim IP address.(Citation: McAfee Night Dragon)

zwShell.name: Windows Command Shell
zwShell.description: [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) can launch command-line shells.(Citation: McAfee Night Dragon)

zwShell.name: File Deletion
zwShell.description: [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) has deleted itself after creating a service as well as deleted a temporary file when the system reboots.(Citation: McAfee Night Dragon)

zwShell.name: Windows Service
zwShell.description: [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) has established persistence by adding itself as a new service.(Citation: McAfee Night Dragon)

NOKKI.name: Credential API Hooking
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) uses the Windows call SetWindowsHookEx and begins injecting it into every GUI process running on the victim's machine.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) uses a unique, custom de-obfuscation technique.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: File Deletion
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) can delete files to cover tracks.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) can gather information on the victim IP address.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) uses Base64 encoding for strings.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: System Time Discovery
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) can collect the current timestamp of the victim's machine.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: System Information Discovery
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) can gather information on drives and the operating system on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) has downloaded a remote module for execution.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: File Transfer Protocols
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) has used FTP for C2 communications.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: System Owner/User Discovery
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) can collect the username from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: Rundll32
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) has used rundll32 for execution.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) is written to %LOCALAPPDATA%\MicroSoft Updatea\svServiceUpdate.exe prior being executed in a new process in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate folder and file.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: Local Data Staging
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) can collect data from the victim and stage it in LOCALAPPDATA%\MicroSoft Updatea\uplog.tmp.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) has established persistence by writing the payload to the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

NOKKI.name: Web Protocols
NOKKI.description: [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) has used HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)

KONNI.name: System Owner/User Discovery
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) can collect the username from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: Windows Command Shell
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has used cmd.exe execute arbitrary commands on the infected host across different stages of the infection change.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)

KONNI.name: PowerShell
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) used PowerShell to download and execute a specific 64-bit version of the malware.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: Keylogging
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has the capability to perform keylogging.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) can steal profiles (containing credential information) from Firefox, Chrome, and Opera.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
KONNI.description: A version of [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) drops a Windows shortcut into the Startup folder to establish persistence.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: Web Protocols
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has used HTTP for C2.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: Shortcut Modification
KONNI.description: A version of [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) drops a Windows shortcut on the victim’s machine to establish persistence.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) can download files and execute them on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: File and Directory Discovery
KONNI.description: A version of [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) searches for filenames created with a previous version of the malware, suggesting different versions targeted the same victims and the versions may work together.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: File Deletion
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) can delete files.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: Screen Capture
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) can take screenshots of the victim’s machine.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) creates a shortcut called "Anti virus service.lnk" in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate file.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) can collect the IP address from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: System Information Discovery
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) can gather the OS version, architecture information, connected drives, hostname, and computer name from the victim’s machine and has used systeminfo.exe to get a snapshot of the current system state of the target machine.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)

KONNI.name: Clipboard Data
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) had a feature to steal data from the clipboard.(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)

KONNI.name: Standard Encoding
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has used a custom base64 key to encode stolen data before exfiltration.(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)

KONNI.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted/Obfuscated Non-C2 Protocol
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has used FTP to exfiltrate reconnaissance data out.(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)

KONNI.name: Process Discovery
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has used tasklist.exe to get a snapshot of the current processes’ state of the target machine.(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)

KONNI.name: Modify Registry
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has modified registry keys of ComSysApp service and Svchost on the machine to gain persistence.(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)

KONNI.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has used certutil to download and decode base64 encoded strings.(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)

KONNI.name: Bypass User Access Control
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) bypassed UAC with the “AlwaysNotify” settings.(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)

KONNI.name: Component Object Model Hijacking
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has modified ComSysApp service to load the malicious DLL payload.(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)

KONNI.name: Create Process with Token
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has duplicated the token of a high integrity process to spawn an instance of cmd.exe under an impersonated user.(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)

KONNI.name: Rundll32
KONNI.description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has used Rundll32 to execute its loader for privilege escalation purposes.(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)

BadPatch.name: Keylogging
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) has a keylogging capability.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

BadPatch.name: File and Directory Discovery
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) searches for files with specific file extensions.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

BadPatch.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) establishes a foothold by adding a link to the malware executable in the startup folder.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

BadPatch.name: Local Data Staging
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) stores collected data in log files before exfiltration.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

BadPatch.name: Web Protocols
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) uses HTTP for C2.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

BadPatch.name: Commonly Used Port
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) uses port 26 for C2 communications.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

BadPatch.name: Screen Capture
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) captures screenshots in .jpg format and then exfiltrates them.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

BadPatch.name: Data from Local System
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) collects files from the local system that have the following extensions, then prepares them for exfiltration: .xls, .xlsx, .pdf, .mdb, .rar, .zip, .doc, .docx.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

BadPatch.name: System Information Discovery
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) collects the OS system, OS version, MAC address, and the computer name from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

BadPatch.name: Security Software Discovery
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) uses WMI to enumerate installed security products in the victim’s environment.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

BadPatch.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) can download and execute or update malware.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

BadPatch.name: System Checks
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) attempts to detect if it is being run in a Virtual Machine (VM) using a WMI query for disk drive name, BIOS, and motherboard information. (Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

BadPatch.name: Mail Protocols
BadPatch.description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) uses SMTP for C2.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)

Xbash.name: Web Protocols
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) uses HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: Network Service Scanning
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can perform port scanning of TCP and UDP ports.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: Visual Basic
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can execute malicious VBScript payloads on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: PowerShell
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can use scripts to invoke PowerShell to download a malicious PE executable or PE DLL for execution.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can collect IP addresses and local intranet information from a victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: Mshta
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can use mshta for executing scripts.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: Password Guessing
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can obtain a list of weak passwords from the C2 server to use for brute forcing as well as attempt to brute force services with open ports.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)(Citation: Trend Micro Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: Regsvr32
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can use regsvr32 for executing scripts.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can download additional malicious files from its C2 server.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can create a Startup item for persistence if it determines it is on a Windows system.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: Cron
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can create a cronjob for persistence if it determines it is on a Linux system.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can attempt to exploit known vulnerabilities in Hadoop, Redis, or ActiveMQ when it finds those services running in order to conduct further execution.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)(Citation: Trend Micro Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: Dead Drop Resolver
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can obtain a webpage hosted on Pastebin to update its C2 domain list.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) has maliciously encrypted victim's database systems and demanded a cryptocurrency ransom be paid.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: Data Destruction
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) has destroyed Linux-based databases as part of its ransomware capabilities.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

Xbash.name: JavaScript/JScript
Xbash.description: [Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can execute malicious JavaScript payloads on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit42 Xbash Sept 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Web Protocols
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2 communications.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Windows Service
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) chooses a service, drops a DLL file, and writes it to that serviceDLL Registry key.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Portable Executable Injection
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) has a module to inject a PE binary into a remote process.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Multi-hop Proxy
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) has used Tor relays for Command and Control servers.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Software Packing
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) is packed for obfuscation.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) can download additional modules and payloads.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Keylogging
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) has a module to harvest pressed keystrokes.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Symmetric Cryptography
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) encrypts communications using AES256.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: System Service Discovery
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) enumerates all Windows services.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: File Deletion
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) can securely delete a file by hooking into the DeleteFileA and DeleteFileW functions in the Windows API.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: LSASS Memory
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) has a module for [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to collect Windows credentials from the victim’s machine.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Code Signing
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) digitally signs the malware with a code-signing certificate.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Windows Command Shell
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) uses cmd.exe to execute itself in-memory.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Rundll32
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) uses PsExec locally in order to execute rundll32.exe at the highest privileges (NTAUTHORITY\SYSTEM).(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Modify Registry
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) modifies conditions in the Registry and adds keys.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) encrypts its configuration files with AES-256 and also encrypts its strings.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

GreyEnergy.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
GreyEnergy.description: [GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) encrypts communications using RSA-2048.(Citation: ESET GreyEnergy Oct 2018)

BISCUIT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
BISCUIT.description: [BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) has a command to download a file from the C2 server.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

BISCUIT.name: Fallback Channels
BISCUIT.description: [BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) malware contains a secondary fallback command and control server that is contacted after the primary command and control server.(Citation: Mandiant APT1)(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

BISCUIT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
BISCUIT.description: [BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) has a command to gather the username from the system.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

BISCUIT.name: System Information Discovery
BISCUIT.description: [BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) has a command to collect the processor type, operation system, computer name, uptime, and whether the system is a laptop or PC.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

BISCUIT.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
BISCUIT.description: [BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) uses SSL for encrypting C2 communications.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

BISCUIT.name: Windows Command Shell
BISCUIT.description: [BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) has a command to launch a command shell on the system.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

BISCUIT.name: Keylogging
BISCUIT.description: [BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) can capture keystrokes.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

BISCUIT.name: Screen Capture
BISCUIT.description: [BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) has a command to periodically take screenshots of the system.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

BISCUIT.name: Process Discovery
BISCUIT.description: [BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) has a command to enumerate running processes and identify their owners.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

BISCUIT.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
BISCUIT.description: [BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) communicates to the C2 server using a custom protocol.(Citation: Mandiant APT1 Appendix)

hcdLoader.name: Windows Service
hcdLoader.description: [hcdLoader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0071) installs itself as a service for persistence.(Citation: Dell Lateral Movement)(Citation: ThreatStream Evasion Analysis)

hcdLoader.name: Windows Command Shell
hcdLoader.description: [hcdLoader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0071) provides command-line access to the compromised system.(Citation: Dell Lateral Movement)

TEXTMATE.name: Windows Command Shell
TEXTMATE.description: [TEXTMATE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0146) executes cmd.exe to provide a reverse shell to adversaries.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 March 2017)(Citation: Cisco DNSMessenger March 2017)

TEXTMATE.name: DNS
TEXTMATE.description: [TEXTMATE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0146) uses DNS TXT records for C2.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 March 2017)

S-Type.name: Shortcut Modification
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) may create the file %HOMEPATH%\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\Realtek {Unique Identifier}.lnk, which points to the malicious msdtc.exe file already created in the %CommonFiles% directory.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

S-Type.name: Commonly Used Port
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) uses ports 80, 443, and 8080 for C2.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

S-Type.name: Standard Encoding
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) uses Base64 encoding for C2 traffic.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

S-Type.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) may save itself as a file named msdtc.exe, which is also the name of the legitimate Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator service binary.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)(Citation: Microsoft DTC)

S-Type.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) may create a .lnk file to itself that is saved in the Start menu folder. It may also create the Registry key HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ IMJPMIJ8.1{3 characters of Unique Identifier}.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

S-Type.name: Web Protocols
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) uses HTTP for C2.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

S-Type.name: Local Account
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) may create a temporary user on the system named “Lost_{Unique Identifier}” with the password “pond~!@6”{Unique Identifier}.”(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

S-Type.name: System Information Discovery
S-Type.description: The initial beacon packet for [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) contains the operating system version and file system of the victim.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

S-Type.name: Local Account
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) runs the command net user on a victim. [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) also runs tests to determine the privilege level of the compromised user.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

S-Type.name: System Service Discovery
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) runs the command net start on a victim.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

S-Type.name: Fallback Channels
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) primarily uses port 80 for C2, but falls back to ports 443 or 8080 if initial communication fails.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)

Sys10.name: Local Groups
Sys10.description: [Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060) collects the group name of the logged-in user and sends it to the C2.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

Sys10.name: System Information Discovery
Sys10.description: [Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060) collects the computer name, OS versioning information, and OS install date and sends the information to the C2.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

Sys10.name: Web Protocols
Sys10.description: [Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060) uses HTTP for C2.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

Sys10.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Sys10.description: [Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060) uses an XOR 0x1 loop to encrypt its C2 domain.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

Sys10.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Sys10.description: [Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060) collects the account name of the logged-in user and sends it to the C2.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

Sys10.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Sys10.description: [Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060) collects the local IP address of the victim and sends it to the C2.(Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)

OSInfo.name: System Network Connections Discovery
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) enumerates the current network connections similar to net use .(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

OSInfo.name: Domain Account
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) enumerates local and domain users(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

OSInfo.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) discovers the current domain information.(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

OSInfo.name: Local Groups
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) has enumerated the local administrators group.(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

OSInfo.name: Network Share Discovery
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) discovers shares on the network(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

OSInfo.name: Query Registry
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) queries the registry to look for information about Terminal Services.(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

OSInfo.name: Remote System Discovery
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) performs a connection test to discover remote systems in the network(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

OSInfo.name: System Information Discovery
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) discovers information about the infected machine.(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

OSInfo.name: Local Account
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) enumerates local and domain users(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

OSInfo.name: Domain Groups
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) specifically looks for Domain Admins and power users within the domain.(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)

Chaos.name: Brute Force
Chaos.description: [Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220) conducts brute force attacks against SSH services to gain initial access.(Citation: Chaos Stolen Backdoor)

Chaos.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Chaos.description: [Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220) provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.(Citation: Chaos Stolen Backdoor)

Chaos.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Chaos.description: [Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220) provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.(Citation: Chaos Stolen Backdoor)

Chaos.name: Unix Shell
Chaos.description: [Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220) provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.(Citation: Chaos Stolen Backdoor)

Chaos.name: Multi-Stage Channels
Chaos.description: After initial compromise, [Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220) will download a second stage to establish a more permanent presence on the affected system.(Citation: Chaos Stolen Backdoor)

Chaos.name: Traffic Signaling
Chaos.description: [Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220) provides a reverse shell is triggered upon receipt of a packet with a special string, sent to any port.(Citation: Chaos Stolen Backdoor)

PUNCHTRACK.name: Data from Local System
PUNCHTRACK.description: [PUNCHTRACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0197) scrapes memory for properly formatted payment card data.(Citation: FireEye Fin8 May 2016)(Citation: FireEye Know Your Enemy FIN8 Aug 2016)

PUNCHTRACK.name: Local Data Staging
PUNCHTRACK.description: [PUNCHTRACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0197) aggregates collected data in a tmp file.(Citation: FireEye Know Your Enemy FIN8 Aug 2016)

PUNCHTRACK.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
PUNCHTRACK.description: [PUNCHTRACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0197) is loaded and executed by a highly obfuscated launcher.(Citation: FireEye Fin8 May 2016)

POORAIM.name: Drive-by Compromise
POORAIM.description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) has been delivered through compromised sites acting as watering holes.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

POORAIM.name: Bidirectional Communication
POORAIM.description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) has used AOL Instant Messenger for C2.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

POORAIM.name: Process Discovery
POORAIM.description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) can enumerate processes.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

POORAIM.name: Screen Capture
POORAIM.description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) can perform screen capturing.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

POORAIM.name: System Information Discovery
POORAIM.description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) can identify system information, including battery status.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

POORAIM.name: File and Directory Discovery
POORAIM.description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) can conduct file browsing.(Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)

Regin.name: Modify Registry
Regin.description: [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) appears to have functionality to modify remote Registry information.(Citation: Kaspersky Regin)

Regin.name: NTFS File Attributes
Regin.description: The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform uses Extended Attributes to store encrypted executables.(Citation: Kaspersky Regin)

Regin.name: Network Sniffing
Regin.description: [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) appears to have functionality to sniff for credentials passed over HTTP, SMTP, and SMB.(Citation: Kaspersky Regin)

Regin.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Regin.description: The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform can use ICMP to communicate between infected computers.(Citation: Kaspersky Regin)

Regin.name: External Proxy
Regin.description: [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) leveraged several compromised universities as proxies to obscure its origin.(Citation: Kaspersky Regin)

Regin.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
Regin.description: The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform can use ICMP to communicate between infected computers.(Citation: Kaspersky Regin)

Regin.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
Regin.description: The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform can use Windows admin shares to move laterally.(Citation: Kaspersky Regin)

Regin.name: Web Protocols
Regin.description: The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform supports many standard protocols, including HTTP and HTTPS.(Citation: Kaspersky Regin)

Regin.name: Invalid Code Signature
Regin.description: [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) stage 1 modules for 64-bit systems have been found to be signed with fake certificates masquerading as originating from Microsoft Corporation and Broadcom Corporation.(Citation: Kaspersky Regin)

Regin.name: Application Layer Protocol
Regin.description: The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform supports many standard protocols, including SMB.(Citation: Kaspersky Regin)

Regin.name: Hidden File System
Regin.description: [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) has used a hidden file system to store some of its components.(Citation: Kaspersky Regin)

Umbreon.name: Local Accounts
Umbreon.description: [Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221) creates valid local users to provide access to the system.(Citation: Umbreon Trend Micro)

Umbreon.name: Rootkit
Umbreon.description: [Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221) hides from defenders by hooking libc function calls, hiding artifacts that would reveal its presence, such as the user account it creates to provide access and undermining strace, a tool often used to identify malware.(Citation: Umbreon Trend Micro)

Umbreon.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
Umbreon.description: [Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221) provides access to the system via SSH or any other protocol that uses PAM to authenticate.(Citation: Umbreon Trend Micro)

Umbreon.name: Windows Command Shell
Umbreon.description: [Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221) provides access using both standard facilities like SSH and additional access using its backdoor Espeon, providing a reverse shell upon receipt of a special packet(Citation: Umbreon Trend Micro)

Umbreon.name: Traffic Signaling
Umbreon.description: [Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221) provides additional access using its backdoor Espeon, providing a reverse shell upon receipt of a special packet.(Citation: Umbreon Trend Micro)

SNUGRIDE.name: Symmetric Cryptography
SNUGRIDE.description: [SNUGRIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0159) encrypts C2 traffic using AES with a static key.(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)

SNUGRIDE.name: Web Protocols
SNUGRIDE.description: [SNUGRIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0159) communicates with its C2 server over HTTP.(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)

SNUGRIDE.name: Windows Command Shell
SNUGRIDE.description: [SNUGRIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0159) is capable of executing commands and spawning a reverse shell.(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)

SNUGRIDE.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
SNUGRIDE.description: [SNUGRIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0159) establishes persistence through a Registry Run key.(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)

Downdelph.name: Bypass User Access Control
Downdelph.description: [Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) bypasses UAC to escalate privileges by using a custom “RedirectEXE” shim database.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 3)

Downdelph.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Downdelph.description: [Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) uses search order hijacking of the Windows executable sysprep.exe to escalate privileges.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 3)

Downdelph.name: Junk Data
Downdelph.description: [Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) inserts pseudo-random characters between each original character during encoding of C2 network requests, making it difficult to write signatures on them.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 3)

Downdelph.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Downdelph.description: After downloading its main config file, [Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) downloads multiple payloads from C2 servers.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 3)

Downdelph.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Downdelph.description: [Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) uses RC4 to encrypt C2 responses.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 3)

RGDoor.name: Web Protocols
RGDoor.description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) uses HTTP for C2 communications.(Citation: Unit 42 RGDoor Jan 2018)

RGDoor.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
RGDoor.description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) uploads and downloads files to and from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 RGDoor Jan 2018)

RGDoor.name: Archive via Custom Method
RGDoor.description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) encrypts files with XOR before sending them back to the C2 server.(Citation: Unit 42 RGDoor Jan 2018)

RGDoor.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
RGDoor.description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) decodes Base64 strings and decrypts strings using a custom XOR algorithm.(Citation: Unit 42 RGDoor Jan 2018)

RGDoor.name: Windows Command Shell
RGDoor.description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) uses cmd.exe to execute commands on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 RGDoor Jan 2018)

RGDoor.name: System Owner/User Discovery
RGDoor.description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) executes the whoami on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Unit 42 RGDoor Jan 2018)

Nerex.name: Code Signing
Nerex.description: [Nerex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0210) drops a signed Microsoft DLL to disk.(Citation: Symantec Nerex May 2012)

Nerex.name: Windows Service
Nerex.description: [Nerex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0210) creates a Registry subkey that registers a new service.(Citation: Symantec Nerex May 2012)

Nerex.name: Modify Registry
Nerex.description: [Nerex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0210) creates a Registry subkey that registers a new service.(Citation: Symantec Nerex May 2012)

Nerex.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Nerex.description: [Nerex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0210) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can download files onto a compromised host.(Citation: Symantec Ristol May 2012)

MURKYTOP.name: Local Account
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to retrieve information about users on remote hosts.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

MURKYTOP.name: File Deletion
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to delete local files.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

MURKYTOP.name: Remote System Discovery
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to identify remote hosts on connected networks.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

MURKYTOP.name: Network Share Discovery
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to retrieve information about shares on remote hosts.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

MURKYTOP.name: System Information Discovery
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to retrieve information about the OS.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

MURKYTOP.name: At (Windows)
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to schedule remote AT jobs.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

MURKYTOP.name: Network Service Scanning
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to scan for open ports on hosts in a connected network.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

MURKYTOP.name: Windows Command Shell
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) uses the command-line interface.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

MURKYTOP.name: Permission Groups Discovery
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to retrieve information about groups.(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

WINDSHIELD.name: Query Registry
WINDSHIELD.description: [WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) can gather Registry values.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

WINDSHIELD.name: System Information Discovery
WINDSHIELD.description: [WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) can gather the victim computer name.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

WINDSHIELD.name: File Deletion
WINDSHIELD.description: [WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) is capable of file deletion along with other file system interaction.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

WINDSHIELD.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
WINDSHIELD.description: [WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) C2 traffic can communicate via TCP raw sockets.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

WINDSHIELD.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
WINDSHIELD.description: [WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) C2 traffic can communicate via TCP raw sockets.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

WINDSHIELD.name: System Owner/User Discovery
WINDSHIELD.description: [WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) can gather the victim user name.(Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)

BUBBLEWRAP.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
BUBBLEWRAP.description: [BUBBLEWRAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0043) can communicate using SOCKS.(Citation: FireEye admin@338)

BUBBLEWRAP.name: System Information Discovery
BUBBLEWRAP.description: [BUBBLEWRAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0043) collects system information, including the operating system version and hostname.(Citation: FireEye admin@338)

BUBBLEWRAP.name: Web Protocols
BUBBLEWRAP.description: [BUBBLEWRAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0043) can communicate using HTTP or HTTPS.(Citation: FireEye admin@338)

FLIPSIDE.name: Protocol Tunneling
FLIPSIDE.description: [FLIPSIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0173) uses RDP to tunnel traffic from a victim environment.(Citation: Mandiant FIN5 GrrCON Oct 2016)

BLACKCOFFEE.name: Windows Command Shell
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) has the capability to create a reverse shell.(Citation: FireEye APT17)

BLACKCOFFEE.name: File Deletion
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) has the capability to delete files.(Citation: FireEye APT17)

BLACKCOFFEE.name: Dead Drop Resolver
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) uses Microsoft’s TechNet Web portal to obtain a dead drop resolver containing an encoded tag with the IP address of a command and control server.(Citation: FireEye APT17)(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

BLACKCOFFEE.name: Process Discovery
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) has the capability to discover processes.(Citation: FireEye APT17)

BLACKCOFFEE.name: File and Directory Discovery
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) has the capability to enumerate files.(Citation: FireEye APT17)

BLACKCOFFEE.name: Multi-Stage Channels
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) uses Microsoft’s TechNet Web portal to obtain an encoded tag containing the IP address of a command and control server and then communicates separately with that IP address for C2. If the C2 server is discovered or shut down, the threat actors can update the encoded IP address on TechNet to maintain control of the victims’ machines.(Citation: FireEye APT17)

BLACKCOFFEE.name: Bidirectional Communication
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) has also obfuscated its C2 traffic as normal traffic to sites such as Github.(Citation: FireEye APT17)(Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)

FALLCHILL.name: System Information Discovery
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) can collect operating system (OS) version information, processor information, system name, and information about installed disks from the victim.(Citation: US-CERT FALLCHILL Nov 2017)

FALLCHILL.name: Symmetric Cryptography
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) encrypts C2 data with RC4 encryption.(Citation: US-CERT FALLCHILL Nov 2017)

FALLCHILL.name: File and Directory Discovery
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) can search files on a victim.(Citation: US-CERT FALLCHILL Nov 2017)

FALLCHILL.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) collects MAC address and local IP address information from the victim.(Citation: US-CERT FALLCHILL Nov 2017)

FALLCHILL.name: File Deletion
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) can delete malware and associated artifacts from the victim.(Citation: US-CERT FALLCHILL Nov 2017)

FALLCHILL.name: Timestomp
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) can modify file or directory timestamps.(Citation: US-CERT FALLCHILL Nov 2017)

FALLCHILL.name: Protocol Impersonation
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) uses fake Transport Layer Security (TLS) to communicate with its C2 server.(Citation: US-CERT FALLCHILL Nov 2017)

NavRAT.name: Process Discovery
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) uses tasklist /v to check running processes.(Citation: Talos NavRAT May 2018)

NavRAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) creates a Registry key to ensure a file gets executed upon reboot in order to establish persistence.(Citation: Talos NavRAT May 2018)

NavRAT.name: Windows Command Shell
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) leverages cmd.exe to perform discovery techniques.(Citation: Talos NavRAT May 2018) [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) loads malicious shellcode and executes it in memory.(Citation: Talos NavRAT May 2018)

NavRAT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) can download files remotely.(Citation: Talos NavRAT May 2018)

NavRAT.name: Local Data Staging
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) writes multiple outputs to a TMP file using the >> method.(Citation: Talos NavRAT May 2018)

NavRAT.name: Keylogging
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) logs the keystrokes on the targeted system.(Citation: Talos NavRAT May 2018)

NavRAT.name: System Information Discovery
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) uses systeminfo on a victim’s machine.(Citation: Talos NavRAT May 2018)

NavRAT.name: Process Injection
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) copies itself into a running Internet Explorer process to evade detection.(Citation: Talos NavRAT May 2018)

NavRAT.name: Mail Protocols
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) uses the email platform, Naver, for C2 communications, leveraging SMTP.(Citation: Talos NavRAT May 2018)

DealersChoice.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
DealersChoice.description: [DealersChoice](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0243) leverages vulnerable versions of Flash to perform execution.(Citation: Sofacy DealersChoice)

DealersChoice.name: Windows Command Shell
DealersChoice.description: [DealersChoice](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0243) makes modifications to open-source scripts from GitHub and executes them on the victim’s machine.(Citation: Sofacy DealersChoice)

DealersChoice.name: Web Protocols
DealersChoice.description: [DealersChoice](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0243) uses HTTP for communication with the C2 server.(Citation: Sofacy DealersChoice)

Zebrocy.name: System Information Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) collects the OS version, computer name and serial number for the storage volume C:\. [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) also runs the systeminfo command to gather system information. (Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)(Citation: Accenture SNAKEMACKEREL Nov 2018)

Zebrocy.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses raw sockets to communicate with its C2 server.(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)

Zebrocy.name: Archive Collected Data
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses an encryption method similar to RC4 as well as AES to encrypt data before exfiltration. (Citation: Securelist Sofacy Feb 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy Nov 2018)

Zebrocy.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) obtains additional code to execute on the victim's machine, including the downloading of a secondary payload.(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)(Citation: Accenture SNAKEMACKEREL Nov 2018)

Zebrocy.name: Credential API Hooking
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) installs an application-defined Windows hook to get notified when a network drive has been attached, so it can then use the hook to call its RecordToFile file stealing method.(Citation: Securelist Sofacy Feb 2018)

Zebrocy.name: Web Protocols
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses HTTP for C2.(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)(Citation: Accenture SNAKEMACKEREL Nov 2018)

Zebrocy.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) enumerates information about connected storage devices.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)

Zebrocy.name: Network Share Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) identifies network drives when they are added to victim systems.(Citation: Securelist Sofacy Feb 2018)

Zebrocy.name: File and Directory Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) searches for files that are 60mb and less and contain the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .ppt, .pptx, .exe, .zip, and .rar. [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) also runs the echo %APPDATA% command to list the contents of the directory.(Citation: Securelist Sofacy Feb 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy Nov 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019) [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) can obtain the current execution path as well as perform drive enumeration.(Citation: Accenture SNAKEMACKEREL Nov 2018)

Zebrocy.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) decodes its secondary payload and writes it to the victim’s machine. [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) also uses AES and XOR to decrypt strings and payloads.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy Nov 2018)

Zebrocy.name: Screen Capture
Zebrocy.description: A variant of [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) captures screenshots of the victim’s machine in JPEG and BMP format.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)(Citation: Accenture SNAKEMACKEREL Nov 2018)

Zebrocy.name: Process Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses the tasklist and wmic process get Capture, ExecutablePath commands to gather the processes running on the system.(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)(Citation: Accenture SNAKEMACKEREL Nov 2018)

Zebrocy.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) creates an entry in a Registry Run key for the malware to execute on startup.(Citation: ESET Zebrocy Nov 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)(Citation: Accenture SNAKEMACKEREL Nov 2018)

Zebrocy.name: File Deletion
