WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) enumerates current remote desktop sessions and tries to execute the malware on each session.(Citation: LogRhythm WannaCry)

WannaCry.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) encrypts user files and demands that a ransom be paid in Bitcoin to decrypt those files.(Citation: LogRhythm WannaCry)(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017)(Citation: SecureWorks WannaCry Analysis)

WannaCry.name: Windows Service
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) creates the service "mssecsvc2.0" with the display name "Microsoft Security Center (2.0) Service."(Citation: LogRhythm WannaCry)(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017)

WannaCry.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) attempts to copy itself to remote computers after gaining access via an SMB exploit.(Citation: LogRhythm WannaCry)

WannaCry.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) utilizes wmic to delete shadow copies.(Citation: LogRhythm WannaCry)(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017)(Citation: SecureWorks WannaCry Analysis)

WannaCry.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) uses [Tor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0183) for command and control traffic and routes a custom cryptographic protocol over the [Tor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0183) circuit.(Citation: SecureWorks WannaCry Analysis)

WannaCry.name: Multi-hop Proxy
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) uses [Tor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0183) for command and control traffic.(Citation: SecureWorks WannaCry Analysis)

WannaCry.name: Inhibit System Recovery
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) uses vssadmin, wbadmin, bcdedit, and wmic to delete and disable operating system recovery features.(Citation: LogRhythm WannaCry)(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017)(Citation: SecureWorks WannaCry Analysis)

WannaCry.name: Service Stop
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) attempts to kill processes associated with Exchange, Microsoft SQL Server, and MySQL to make it possible to encrypt their data stores.(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017)(Citation: SecureWorks WannaCry Analysis)

WannaCry.name: Hidden Files and Directories
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) uses attrib +h to make some of its files hidden.(Citation: LogRhythm WannaCry)

WannaCry.name: File and Directory Discovery
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) searches for variety of user files by file extension before encrypting them using RSA and AES, including Office, PDF, image, audio, video, source code, archive/compression format, and key and certificate files.(Citation: LogRhythm WannaCry)(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017)

NotPetya.name: Scheduled Task
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) creates a task to reboot the system one hour after infection.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)

NotPetya.name: Clear Windows Event Logs
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) uses wevtutil to clear the Windows event logs.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)

NotPetya.name: Rundll32
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) uses rundll32.exe to install itself on remote systems when accessed via [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) or wmic.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)

NotPetya.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) encrypts user files and disk structures like the MBR with 2048-bit RSA.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)(Citation: US-CERT NotPetya 2017)

NotPetya.name: LSASS Memory
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) contains a modified version of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to help gather credentials that are later used for lateral movement.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)(Citation: US-CERT NotPetya 2017)(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)

NotPetya.name: Local Accounts
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) can use valid credentials with [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) or wmic to spread itself to remote systems.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)(Citation: US-CERT NotPetya 2017)

NotPetya.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) can use [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029), which interacts with the ADMIN$ network share to execute commands on remote systems.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)(Citation: US-CERT NotPetya 2017)(Citation: PsExec Russinovich)

NotPetya.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) can use wmic to help propagate itself across a network.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)(Citation: US-CERT NotPetya 2017)

NotPetya.name: Service Execution
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) can use [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to help propagate itself across a network.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)(Citation: US-CERT NotPetya 2017)

NotPetya.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) can use two exploits in SMBv1, EternalBlue and EternalRomance, to spread itself to other remote systems on the network.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)(Citation: US-CERT NotPetya 2017)

NotPetya.name: Rename System Utilities
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) drops [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) with the filename dllhost.dat.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)

NotPetya.name: System Shutdown/Reboot
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) will reboot the system one hour after infection.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)

SamSam.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
SamSam.description: [SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370) has been seen using AES or DES to encrypt payloads and payload components.(Citation: Sophos SamSam Apr 2018)(Citation: Talos SamSam Jan 2018)

SamSam.name: Binary Padding
SamSam.description: [SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370) has used garbage code to pad some of its malware components.(Citation: Sophos SamSam Apr 2018)

SamSam.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
SamSam.description: [SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370) encrypts victim files using RSA-2048 encryption and demands a ransom be paid in Bitcoin to decrypt those files.(Citation: Sophos SamSam Apr 2018)

SamSam.name: File Deletion
SamSam.description: [SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370) has been seen deleting its own files and payloads to make analysis of the attack more difficult.(Citation: Sophos SamSam Apr 2018)

SamSam.name: Windows Command Shell
SamSam.description: [SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370) uses custom batch scripts to execute some of its components.(Citation: Sophos SamSam Apr 2018)

POWERTON.name: Security Account Manager
POWERTON.description: [POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) has the ability to dump password hashes.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Guardrail)

POWERTON.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
POWERTON.description: [POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) can install a Registry Run key for persistence.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Guardrail)

POWERTON.name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
POWERTON.description: [POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) can use WMI for persistence.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Guardrail)

POWERTON.name: PowerShell
POWERTON.description: [POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) is written in PowerShell.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Guardrail)

POWERTON.name: Symmetric Cryptography
POWERTON.description: [POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) has used AES for encrypting C2 traffic.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Guardrail)

POWERTON.name: Web Protocols
POWERTON.description: [POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) has used HTTP/HTTPS for C2 traffic.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Guardrail)

POWERTON.name: Commonly Used Port
POWERTON.description: [POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) has used port 443 for C2 traffic.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Guardrail)

LockerGoga.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
LockerGoga.description: [LockerGoga](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) has been observed moving around the victim network via SMB, indicating the actors behind this ransomware are manually copying files form computer to computer instead of self-propagating.(Citation: Unit42 LockerGoga 2019)

LockerGoga.name: File Deletion
LockerGoga.description: [LockerGoga](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) has been observed deleting its original launcher after execution.(Citation: CarbonBlack LockerGoga 2019)

LockerGoga.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
LockerGoga.description: [LockerGoga](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) has encrypted files, including core Windows OS files, using RSA-OAEP MGF1 and then demanded Bitcoin be paid for the decryption key.(Citation: CarbonBlack LockerGoga 2019)(Citation: Unit42 LockerGoga 2019)(Citation: Wired Lockergoga 2019)

LockerGoga.name: Disable or Modify Tools
LockerGoga.description: [LockerGoga](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) installation has been immediately preceded by a "task kill" command in order to disable anti-virus.(Citation: Wired Lockergoga 2019)

LockerGoga.name: Code Signing
LockerGoga.description: [LockerGoga](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) has been signed with stolen certificates in order to make it look more legitimate.(Citation: Wired Lockergoga 2019)

LockerGoga.name: System Shutdown/Reboot
LockerGoga.description: [LockerGoga](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) has been observed shutting down infected systems.(Citation: Wired Lockergoga 2019)

LockerGoga.name: Account Access Removal
LockerGoga.description: [LockerGoga](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) has been observed changing account passwords and logging off current users.(Citation: CarbonBlack LockerGoga 2019)(Citation: Unit42 LockerGoga 2019)

Astaroth.name: Process Discovery
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) searches for different processes on the system. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Software Packing
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses a software packer called Pe123\RPolyCryptor.(Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) obfuscates its JScript code.(Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: XSL Script Processing
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) executes embedded JScript or VBScript in an XSL stylesheet located on a remote domain. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses a fromCharCode() deobfuscation method to avoid explicitly writing execution commands and to hide its code. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Clipboard Data
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects information from the clipboard by using the OpenClipboard() and GetClipboardData() libraries. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Compiled HTML File
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses ActiveX objects for file execution and manipulation. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)

Astaroth.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses WMIC to execute payloads. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)

Astaroth.name: JavaScript/JScript
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses JavaScript to perform its core functionalities. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)

Astaroth.name: System Information Discovery
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects the machine name and keyboard language from the system. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)(Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160) and [BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190) to download additional malware. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)(Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Keylogging
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) logs keystrokes from the victim's machine. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)

Astaroth.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects the external IP address from the system. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)

Astaroth.name: Shortcut Modification
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373)'s initial payload is a malicious .LNK file. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)(Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Security Software Discovery
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) checks for the presence of Avast antivirus in the C:\Program\Files\ folder. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)

Astaroth.name: System Time Discovery
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects the timestamp from the infected machine. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)

Astaroth.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) exfiltrates collected information from its r1.log file to the external C2 server. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Local Data Staging
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects data in a plaintext file named r1.log before exfiltration. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)

Astaroth.name: Credentials from Password Stores
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses an external software known as NetPass to recover passwords. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) creates a startup item for persistence. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)

Astaroth.name: Standard Encoding
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) encodes data using Base64 before sending it to the C2 server. (Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)

Astaroth.name: Shared Modules
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses the LoadLibraryExW() function to load additional modules. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Regsvr32
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) can be loaded through regsvr32.exe.(Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Process Hollowing
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) searches for unins000.exe (GAS Tecnologia software), Syswow64\userinit.exe or System32\userinit.exe to evasively create a new process in suspended state. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Hidden Window
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) loads its module with the XSL script parameter vShow set to zero, which opens the application with a hidden window. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Windows Command Shell
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) spawns a CMD process to execute commands. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Unsecured Credentials
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses an external software known as NetPass to recover passwords. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: Network Service Scanning
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) checks for availability of specific ports on servers.(Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: Password Guessing
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) can perform brute forcing using a pre-defined list of usernames and passwords in an attempt to log in to administrative panels. (Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: Standard Encoding
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) encodes C&C communication using Base64. (Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) attempts to exploit the following vulnerabilities in order to execute its malicious script: CVE-2012-0874, CVE-2010-1871, CVE-2017-10271, CVE-2018-2894, CVE-2016-3088, JBoss AS 3/4/5/6, and the Hadoop YARN ResourceManager. (Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) encodes its second-stage payload with Base64. (Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: Cron
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) uses cron tasks to ensure persistence. (Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: System Network Connections Discovery
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) uses the arp -a command. (Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) uses the ifconfig -a command. (Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: System Information Discovery
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) uses the cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep -c “cpu family” 2>&1 command to gather system information. (Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: Web Protocols
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) uses POST and GET requests over HTTP to communicate with its main C&C server. (Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: System Owner/User Discovery
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) uses the whoami command. (Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: File Deletion
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) deletes files to remove evidence on the machine. (Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: Python
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) uses Python scripts.(Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) downloads and executes additional files from a remote server. (Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

SpeakUp.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) uses Perl scripts.(Citation: CheckPoint SpeakUp Feb 2019)

Remexi.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) decrypts the configuration data using XOR with 25-character keys.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Archive Collected Data
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) encrypts and adds all gathered browser data into files for upload to C2.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Windows Command Shell
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) silently executes received commands with cmd.exe.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) executes received commands with wmic.exe (for WMI commands). (Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: File and Directory Discovery
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) searches for files on the system. (Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Visual Basic
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) uses AutoIt and VBS scripts throughout its execution process.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) achieves persistence using Userinit by adding the Registry key HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Userinit.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Web Protocols
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) uses [BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190) to communicate with the C2 server over HTTP.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) obfuscates its configuration data with XOR.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) utilizes Run Registry keys in the HKLM hive as a persistence mechanism.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Scheduled Task
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) utilizes scheduled tasks as a persistence mechanism.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Screen Capture
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) takes screenshots of windows of interest.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Keylogging
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) gathers and exfiltrates keystrokes from the machine.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Application Window Discovery
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) has a command to capture active windows on the machine and retrieve window titles.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) performs exfiltration over [BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190), which is also used for the C2 channel.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

Remexi.name: Clipboard Data
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) collects text from the clipboard.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Windows Command Shell
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) can launch cmd.exe to execute commands on the system.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has modified the firewall using [netsh](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0108).(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Service Execution
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has used svchost.exe to execute a malicious DLL .(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has used WMI to recompile the Managed Object Format (MOF) files in the WMI repository.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Security Account Manager
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has the capability to harvest credentials and passwords from the SAM database.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Pass the Hash
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has been observed loading several APIs associated with Pass the Hash.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Uncommonly Used Port
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has used uncommon TCP "high port" to "high port" communication.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Commonly Used Port
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has connected outbound over TCP port 443. (Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Standard Encoding
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has utilized Zlib compression to obfuscate the communications payload. (Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has the ability to connect to a remote host in order to upload and download files.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Modify Registry
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has modified Managed Object Format (MOF) files within the Registry to run specific commands and create persistence on the system.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: System Information Discovery
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has been observed collecting victim machine information like OS version, drivers, volume information and more.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: System Time Discovery
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has been observed collecting system time from victim machines.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Process Injection
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has injected into running processes.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: File and Directory Discovery
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has been observed enumerating system drives and partitions.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Proxy
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has multiple proxy options that mask traffic between the malware and the remote operators.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Fallback Channels
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has multiple C2 channels in place in case one fails.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has used its C2 channel to exfiltrate data.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Query Registry
HOPLIGHT.description: A variant of [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) hooks lsass.exe, and lsass.exe then checks the Registry for the data value 'rdpproto' under the key SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa Name.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

HOPLIGHT.name: Non-Standard Port
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has connected outbound over TCP port 443 with a FakeTLS method.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)

Ebury.name: Private Keys
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has intercepted unencrypted private keys as well as private key pass-phrases.(Citation: ESET Ebury Feb 2014)

Ebury.name: Standard Encoding
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has encoded C2 traffic in hexadecimal format.(Citation: ESET Ebury Feb 2014)

Ebury.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has encrypted C2 traffic using the client IP address, then encoded it as a hexadecimal string.(Citation: ESET Ebury Feb 2014)

Ebury.name: Code Signing
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has installed a self-signed RPM package mimicking the original system package on RPM based systems.(Citation: ESET Ebury Feb 2014)

Ebury.name: DNS
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has used DNS requests over UDP port 53 for C2.(Citation: ESET Ebury Feb 2014)

Ebury.name: Commonly Used Port
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has used UDP port 53 for C2.(Citation: ESET Ebury Feb 2014)

Ebury.name: Disable Windows Event Logging
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has disabled logging when the backdoor is used.(Citation: ESET Ebury Feb 2014)

Ebury.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has obfuscated its strings with a simple XOR encryption with a static key.(Citation: ESET Ebury Feb 2014)

Ebury.name: Compromise Client Software Binary
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has been embedded into modified OpenSSH binaries to gain persistent access to SSH credential information.(Citation: ESET Ebury Feb 2014)

Ebury.name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has used a DGA to generate a domain name for C2.(Citation: ESET Ebury Feb 2014)

CoinTicker.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) initially downloads a hidden encoded file.(Citation: CoinTicker 2019)

CoinTicker.name: Uncommonly Used Port
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) establishes outbound connections for command and control on ports 2280 and 1339.(Citation: CoinTicker 2019)

CoinTicker.name: Hidden Files and Directories
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) downloads the following hidden files to evade detection and maintain persistence: /private/tmp/.info.enc, /private/tmp/.info.py, /private/tmp/.server.sh, ~/Library/LaunchAgents/.espl.plist, ~/Library/Containers/.[random string]/[random string].(Citation: CoinTicker 2019)

CoinTicker.name: Gatekeeper Bypass
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) downloads the EggShell mach-o binary using curl, which does not set the quarantine flag.(Citation: CoinTicker 2019)

CoinTicker.name: Unix Shell
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) executes a bash script to establish a reverse shell.(Citation: CoinTicker 2019)

CoinTicker.name: Windows Command Shell
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) executes a bash script to establish a reverse shell.(Citation: CoinTicker 2019)

CoinTicker.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) executes a Python script to download its second stage.(Citation: CoinTicker 2019)

CoinTicker.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) decodes the initially-downloaded hidden encoded file using OpenSSL.(Citation: CoinTicker 2019)

CoinTicker.name: Launch Agent
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) creates user launch agents named .espl.plist and com.apple.[random string].plist to establish persistence.(Citation: CoinTicker 2019)

CoinTicker.name: Python
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) executes a Python script to download its second stage.(Citation: CoinTicker 2019)

Revenge RAT.name: Video Capture
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has the ability to access the webcam.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)

Revenge RAT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has the ability to upload and download files.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)

Revenge RAT.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has a plugin to perform RDP access.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)

Revenge RAT.name: Screen Capture
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has a plugin for screen capture.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)

Revenge RAT.name: Audio Capture
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has a plugin for microphone interception.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)

Revenge RAT.name: Keylogging
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has a plugin for keylogging.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)

Revenge RAT.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has communicated over TCP port 3333.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)

Revenge RAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) creates a Registry key at HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Shell to survive a system reboot.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)

Revenge RAT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) collects the IP address and MAC address from the system.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)

Revenge RAT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) gathers the username from the system.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)

Revenge RAT.name: OS Credential Dumping
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has a plugin for credential harvesting.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)

Revenge RAT.name: System Information Discovery
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) collects the CPU information, OS information, and system language.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)

Revenge RAT.name: Standard Encoding
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) uses Base64 to encode information sent to the C2 server.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)

Revenge RAT.name: Indirect Command Execution
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) uses the [Forfiles](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0193) utility to execute commands on the system.(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)

Revenge RAT.name: PowerShell
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) uses the PowerShell command Reflection.Assembly to load itself into memory to aid in execution.(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)

Revenge RAT.name: Windows Command Shell
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) uses cmd.exe to execute commands and run scripts on the victim's machine.(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)

Revenge RAT.name: Mshta
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) uses mshta.exe to run malicious scripts on the system.(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)

Revenge RAT.name: Scheduled Task
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) schedules tasks to run malicious scripts at different intervals.(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)

Revenge RAT.name: Bidirectional Communication
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) used blogpost.com as its primary command and control server during a campaign.(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)

StoneDrill.name: File Deletion
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has been observed deleting the temporary files once they fulfill their task.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)

StoneDrill.name: Visual Basic
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has several VBS scripts used throughout the malware's lifecycle.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)

StoneDrill.name: Query Registry
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has looked in the registry to find the default browser path.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)

StoneDrill.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has downloaded and dropped temporary files containing scripts; it additionally has a function to upload files from the victims machine.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)

StoneDrill.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has used several anti-emulation techniques to prevent automated analysis by emulators or sandboxes.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)

StoneDrill.name: Process Injection
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has relied on injecting its payload directly into the process memory of the victim's preferred browser.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)

StoneDrill.name: Security Software Discovery
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) can check for antivirus and antimalware programs.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)

StoneDrill.name: System Time Discovery
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) can obtain the current date and time of the victim machine.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)

StoneDrill.name: System Information Discovery
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has the capability to discover the system OS, Windows version, architecture and environment.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)

StoneDrill.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has used the WMI command-line (WMIC) utility to run tasks.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)

StoneDrill.name: Data Destruction
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has a disk wiper module that targets files other than those in the Windows directory.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)

StoneDrill.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has obfuscated its module with an alphabet-based table or XOR encryption.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)

StoneDrill.name: Disk Content Wipe
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) can wipe the accessible physical or logical drives of the infected machine.(Citation: Symantec Elfin Mar 2019)

StoneDrill.name: Disk Structure Wipe
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) can wipe the master boot record of an infected computer.(Citation: Symantec Elfin Mar 2019)

FlawedAmmyy.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) will attempt to detect if a usable smart card is current inserted into a card reader.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)

FlawedAmmyy.name: System Owner/User Discovery
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) enumerates the current user during the initial infection.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)

FlawedAmmyy.name: System Information Discovery
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) beacons out the victim operating system and computer name during the initial infection.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)

FlawedAmmyy.name: Security Software Discovery
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) will attempt to detect anti-virus products during the initial infection.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)

FlawedAmmyy.name: Symmetric Cryptography
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) has used SEAL encryption during the initial C2 handshake.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)

FlawedAmmyy.name: Data Obfuscation
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) may obfuscate portions of the initial C2 handshake.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)

FlawedAmmyy.name: Web Protocols
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) has used HTTP for C2.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)

FlawedAmmyy.name: Commonly Used Port
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) has used port 443 for C2.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)

FlawedAmmyy.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) leverages WMI to enumerate anti-virus on the victim.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)

FlawedAmmyy.name: Local Groups
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) enumerates the privilege level of the victim during the initial infection.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)

ServHelper.name: System Owner/User Discovery
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) will attempt to enumerate the username of the victim.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)

ServHelper.name: System Information Discovery
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) will attempt to enumerate Windows version and system architecture.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)

ServHelper.name: Web Protocols
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) uses HTTP for C2.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)

ServHelper.name: Commonly Used Port
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) has used port 80 and 443 for C2.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)

ServHelper.name: File Deletion
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) has a module to delete itself from the infected machine.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)(Citation: Deep Instinct TA505 Apr 2019)

ServHelper.name: Rundll32
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) contains a module for downloading and executing DLLs that leverages rundll32.exe.(Citation: Deep Instinct TA505 Apr 2019)

ServHelper.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) may download additional files to execute.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)(Citation: Deep Instinct TA505 Apr 2019)

ServHelper.name: Windows Command Shell
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) can execute shell commands against [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106).(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)(Citation: Deep Instinct TA505 Apr 2019)

ServHelper.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) has commands for adding a remote desktop user and sending RDP traffic to the attacker through a reverse SSH tunnel.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)

ServHelper.name: Local Account
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) has created a new user and added it to the "Remote Desktop Users" and "Administrators" groups.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)

ServHelper.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) may set up a reverse SSH tunnel to give the attacker access to services running on the victim, such as RDP.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)

ServHelper.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) may attempt to establish persistence via the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ run key.(Citation: Deep Instinct TA505 Apr 2019)

ServHelper.name: Scheduled Task
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) contains modules that will use [schtasks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0111) to carry out malicious operations.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)

ServHelper.name: PowerShell
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) has the ability to execute a PowerShell script to get information from the infected host.(Citation: Trend Micro TA505 June 2019)

FlawedGrace.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
FlawedGrace.description: [FlawedGrace](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0383) uses a custom binary protocol for its C2 communications.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)

FlawedGrace.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
FlawedGrace.description: [FlawedGrace](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0383) encrypts its C2 configuration files with AES in CBC mode.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)

FlawedGrace.name: Commonly Used Port
FlawedGrace.description: [FlawedGrace](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0383) has used port 443 for C2 communications.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)

Dridex.name: Proxy
Dridex.description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) contains a backconnect module for tunneling network traffic through a victim's computer. Infected computers become part of a P2P botnet that can relay C2 traffic to other infected peers.(Citation: Dell Dridex Oct 2015)

Dridex.name: Man in the Browser
Dridex.description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) can perform browser attacks via web injects to steal information such as credentials, certificates, and cookies.(Citation: Dell Dridex Oct 2015)

Dridex.name: Remote Access Software
Dridex.description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) contains a module for VNC.(Citation: Dell Dridex Oct 2015)

Dridex.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Dridex.description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) has encrypted traffic with RC4.(Citation: Kaspersky Dridex May 2017)

Dridex.name: Web Protocols
Dridex.description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) has used HTTPS for C2 communications.(Citation: Kaspersky Dridex May 2017)

Dridex.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
Dridex.description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) has encrypted traffic with RSA.(Citation: Kaspersky Dridex May 2017)

njRAT.name: Video Capture
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can access the victim's webcam.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)(Citation: Citizen Lab Group5)

njRAT.name: Keylogging
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) is capable of logging keystrokes.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)(Citation: Trend Micro njRAT 2018)(Citation: Citizen Lab Group5)

njRAT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can upload and download files to and from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: Windows Command Shell
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can launch a command shell interface for executing commands.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: File Deletion
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) is capable of deleting files on the victim.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: Replication Through Removable Media
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can be configured to spread via removable drives.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: Modify Registry
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can create, delete, or modify a specified Registry key or value.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)(Citation: Trend Micro njRAT 2018)

njRAT.name: Screen Capture
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can capture screenshots of the victim’s machines.(Citation: Trend Micro njRAT 2018)

njRAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) has added persistence via the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)(Citation: Trend Micro njRAT 2018)

njRAT.name: Uncommonly Used Port
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) has been observed communicating over uncommon TCP ports, including 1177 and 8282.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)(Citation: Trend Micro njRAT 2018)(Citation: Citizen Lab Group5)

njRAT.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) has a module for performing remote desktop access.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) has modified the Windows firewall to allow itself to communicate through the firewall.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: Standard Encoding
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) uses Base64 encoding for C2 traffic.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) communicates to the C2 server using a custom protocol over TCP.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) enumerates the current user during the initial infection.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: System Information Discovery
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) enumerates the victim operating system and computer name during the initial infection.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: Application Window Discovery
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) gathers information about opened windows during the initial infection.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) will attempt to detect if the victim system has a camera during the initial infection.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: Remote System Discovery
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can identify remote hosts on connected networks.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: Data from Local System
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can collect data from a local system.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can browse file systems using a file manager module.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)

njRAT.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) has a module that steals passwords saved in victim web browsers.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)(Citation: Trend Micro njRAT 2018)(Citation: Citizen Lab Group5)

Ursnif.name: Proxy
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used a peer-to-peer (P2P) network for C2.(Citation: NJCCIC Ursnif Sept 2016)(Citation: ProofPoint Ursnif Aug 2016)

Ursnif.name: Multi-hop Proxy
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used [Tor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0183) for C2.(Citation: NJCCIC Ursnif Sept 2016)(Citation: ProofPoint Ursnif Aug 2016)

Ursnif.name: File Deletion
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has deleted data staged in tmp files after exfiltration.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)

Ursnif.name: Local Data Staging
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used tmp files to stage gathered information.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)

Ursnif.name: Query Registry
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075) to query the Registry for installed programs.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)(Citation: TrendMicro BKDR_URSNIF.SM)

Ursnif.name: Taint Shared Content
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has copied itself to and infected files in network drives for propagation.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif File Dec 2014)

Ursnif.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has dropped payload and configuration files to disk. [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has also been used to download and execute additional payloads.(Citation: TrendMicro PE_URSNIF.A2)(Citation: TrendMicro BKDR_URSNIF.SM)

Ursnif.name: System Information Discovery
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used [Systeminfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0096) to gather system information.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)

Ursnif.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used Registry Run keys to establish automatic execution at system startup.(Citation: TrendMicro PE_URSNIF.A2)(Citation: TrendMicro BKDR_URSNIF.SM)

Ursnif.name: Windows Service
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has registered itself as a system service in the Registry for automatic execution at system startup.(Citation: TrendMicro PE_URSNIF.A2)

Ursnif.name: Replication Through Removable Media
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has copied itself to and infected removable drives for propagation.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif File Dec 2014)

Ursnif.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used strings from legitimate system files and existing folders for its file, folder, and Registry entry names.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)

Ursnif.name: Process Discovery
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has gathered information about running processes.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)(Citation: TrendMicro BKDR_URSNIF.SM)

Ursnif.name: Thread Local Storage
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has injected code into target processes via thread local storage callbacks.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)(Citation: TrendMicro PE_URSNIF.A2)(Citation: FireEye Ursnif Nov 2017)

Ursnif.name: Web Protocols
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used HTTPS for C2.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)(Citation: FireEye Ursnif Nov 2017)(Citation: ProofPoint Ursnif Aug 2016)

Ursnif.name: System Service Discovery
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has gathered information about running services.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)

Ursnif.name: Credential API Hooking
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has hooked APIs to perform a wide variety of information theft, such as monitoring traffic from browsers.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)

Ursnif.name: Screen Capture
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used hooked APIs to take screenshots.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)(Citation: TrendMicro BKDR_URSNIF.SM)

Ursnif.name: Man in the Browser
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has injected HTML codes into banking sites to steal sensitive online banking information (ex: usernames and passwords).(Citation: TrendMicro BKDR_URSNIF.SM)

Ursnif.name: Data from Local System
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has collected files from victim machines, including certificates and cookies.(Citation: TrendMicro BKDR_URSNIF.SM)

Ursnif.name: Modify Registry
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used Registry modifications as part of its installation routine.(Citation: TrendMicro BKDR_URSNIF.SM)(Citation: ProofPoint Ursnif Aug 2016)

Ursnif.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used a custom packet format over TCP and UDP for a peer-to-peer (P2P) network for C2.(Citation: ProofPoint Ursnif Aug 2016)

Ursnif.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used crypto key information stored in the Registry to decrypt Tor clients dropped to disk.(Citation: ProofPoint Ursnif Aug 2016)

Ursnif.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used an XOR-based algorithm to encrypt Tor clients dropped to disk.(Citation: ProofPoint Ursnif Aug 2016)	[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have also been delivered as password-protected zip files that execute base64 encoded [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) commands.(Citation: Bromium Ursnif Mar 2017)

Ursnif.name: Data Encoding
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used encoded data in HTTP URLs for C2.(Citation: ProofPoint Ursnif Aug 2016)

Ursnif.name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used a DGA to generate domain names for C2.(Citation: ProofPoint Ursnif Aug 2016)

Ursnif.name: Process Hollowing
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used process hollowing to inject into child processes.(Citation: FireEye Ursnif Nov 2017)

Ursnif.name: Native API
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used CreateProcessW to create child processes.(Citation: FireEye Ursnif Nov 2017)

Ursnif.name: Time Based Evasion
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used a 30 minute delay after execution to evade sandbox monitoring tools.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif File Dec 2014)

Ursnif.name: Component Object Model
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have used COM objects to execute the malware's full executable payload.(Citation: Bromium Ursnif Mar 2017)

Ursnif.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have used WMI classes to execute [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) commands.(Citation: Bromium Ursnif Mar 2017)

Ursnif.name: PowerShell
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have used PowerShell in download cradles to download and execute the malware's full executable payload.(Citation: Bromium Ursnif Mar 2017)

Ursnif.name: Visual Basic
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have used VBA macros to download and execute the malware's full executable payload.(Citation: Bromium Ursnif Mar 2017)

Ursnif.name: Hidden Window
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have used COM properties to execute malware in hidden windows.(Citation: Bromium Ursnif Mar 2017)

Ursnif.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used HTTP POSTs to exfil gathered information.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)(Citation: FireEye Ursnif Nov 2017)(Citation: ProofPoint Ursnif Aug 2016)

KeyBoy.name: Keylogging
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) installs a keylogger for intercepting credentials and keystrokes.(Citation: Rapid7 KeyBoy Jun 2013)

KeyBoy.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) attempts to collect passwords from browsers.(Citation: Rapid7 KeyBoy Jun 2013)

KeyBoy.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) can determine the public or WAN IP address for the system.(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)

KeyBoy.name: System Information Discovery
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) can gather extended system information, such as information about the operating system, disks, and memory.(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)(Citation: Rapid7 KeyBoy Jun 2013)

KeyBoy.name: Commonly Used Port
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) calls back to the C2 server over ports 53, 80, and 443.(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)(Citation: Rapid7 KeyBoy Jun 2013)

KeyBoy.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) issues the command reg add “HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon” to achieve persistence.(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017) (Citation: CitizenLab KeyBoy Nov 2016)

KeyBoy.name: Screen Capture
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) has a command to perform screen grabbing.(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)

KeyBoy.name: PowerShell
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) uses PowerShell commands to download and execute payloads.(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)

KeyBoy.name: Windows Service
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) installs a service pointing to a malicious DLL dropped to disk.(Citation: Rapid7 KeyBoy Jun 2013)

KeyBoy.name: Timestomp
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) time-stomped its DLL in order to evade detection.(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)

KeyBoy.name: File and Directory Discovery
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) has a command to launch a file browser or explorer on the system.(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)

KeyBoy.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) uses the Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE) protocol to download remote payloads.(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)

KeyBoy.name: Windows Command Shell
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) can launch interactive shells for communicating with the victim machine.(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)(Citation: Rapid7 KeyBoy Jun 2013)

KeyBoy.name: Protocol Impersonation
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) uses custom SSL libraries to impersonate SSL in C2 traffic.(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)

KeyBoy.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) has a download and upload functionality.(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)(Citation: Rapid7 KeyBoy Jun 2013)

KeyBoy.name: Visual Basic
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) uses VBS scripts for installing files and performing execution.(Citation: CitizenLab KeyBoy Nov 2016)

KeyBoy.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
KeyBoy.description: In one version of [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387), string obfuscation routines were used to hide many of the critical values referenced in the malware.(Citation: CitizenLab KeyBoy Nov 2016)

KeyBoy.name: Hidden Window
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) uses -w Hidden to conceal a [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) window that downloads a payload. (Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)

KeyBoy.name: Python
KeyBoy.description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) uses Python scripts for installing files and performing execution.(Citation: CitizenLab KeyBoy Nov 2016)

YAHOYAH.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
YAHOYAH.description: [YAHOYAH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0388) encrypts its configuration file using a simple algorithm.(Citation: TrendMicro TropicTrooper 2015)

YAHOYAH.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
YAHOYAH.description: [YAHOYAH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0388) decrypts downloaded files before execution.(Citation: TrendMicro TropicTrooper 2015)

YAHOYAH.name: System Information Discovery
YAHOYAH.description: [YAHOYAH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0388) checks for the system’s Windows OS version and hostname.(Citation: TrendMicro TropicTrooper 2015)

YAHOYAH.name: Security Software Discovery
YAHOYAH.description: [YAHOYAH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0388) checks for antimalware solution processes on the system.(Citation: TrendMicro TropicTrooper 2015)

YAHOYAH.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
YAHOYAH.description: [YAHOYAH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0388) uses HTTP GET requests to download other files that are executed in memory.(Citation: TrendMicro TropicTrooper 2015)

YAHOYAH.name: Web Protocols
YAHOYAH.description: [YAHOYAH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0388) uses HTTP for C2.(Citation: TrendMicro TropicTrooper 2015)

JCry.name: Inhibit System Recovery
JCry.description: [JCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0389) has been observed deleting shadow copies to ensure that data cannot be restored easily.(Citation: Carbon Black JCry May 2019)

JCry.name: PowerShell
JCry.description: [JCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0389) has used PowerShell to execute payloads.(Citation: Carbon Black JCry May 2019)

JCry.name: Windows Command Shell
JCry.description: [JCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0389) has used cmd.exe to launch PowerShell.(Citation: Carbon Black JCry May 2019)

JCry.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
JCry.description: [JCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0389) has encrypted files and demanded Bitcoin to decrypt those files. (Citation: Carbon Black JCry May 2019)

JCry.name: Visual Basic
JCry.description: [JCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0389) has used VBS scripts. (Citation: Carbon Black JCry May 2019)

JCry.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
JCry.description: [JCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0389) has created payloads in the Startup directory to maintain persistence. (Citation: Carbon Black JCry May 2019)

JCry.name: Malicious File
JCry.description: [JCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0389) has achieved execution by luring users to click on a file that appeared to be an Adobe Flash Player update installer. (Citation: Carbon Black JCry May 2019)

SQLRat.name: PowerShell
SQLRat.description: [SQLRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0390) has used PowerShell to create a Meterpreter session.(Citation: Flashpoint FIN 7 March 2019)

SQLRat.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
SQLRat.description: [SQLRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0390) can make a direct SQL connection to a Microsoft database controlled by the attackers, retrieve an item from the bindata table, then write and execute the file on disk.(Citation: Flashpoint FIN 7 March 2019)

SQLRat.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
SQLRat.description: [SQLRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0390) has scripts that are responsible for deobfuscating additional scripts.(Citation: Flashpoint FIN 7 March 2019)

SQLRat.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
SQLRat.description: [SQLRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0390) has used a character insertion obfuscation technique, making the script appear to contain Chinese characters.(Citation: Flashpoint FIN 7 March 2019)

SQLRat.name: Scheduled Task
SQLRat.description: [SQLRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0390) has created scheduled tasks in %appdata%\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\.(Citation: Flashpoint FIN 7 March 2019)

SQLRat.name: Malicious File
SQLRat.description: [SQLRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0390) relies on users clicking on an embedded image to execute the scripts.(Citation: Flashpoint FIN 7 March 2019)

SQLRat.name: File Deletion
SQLRat.description: [SQLRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0390) has used been observed deleting scripts once used.(Citation: Flashpoint FIN 7 March 2019)

SQLRat.name: Windows Command Shell
SQLRat.description: [SQLRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0390) has used SQL to execute JavaScript and VB scripts on the host system.(Citation: Flashpoint FIN 7 March 2019)

HAWKBALL.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
HAWKBALL.description: [HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) has sent system information and files over the C2 channel.(Citation: FireEye HAWKBALL Jun 2019)

HAWKBALL.name: Archive via Custom Method
HAWKBALL.description: [HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) has encrypted data with XOR before sending it over the C2 channel.(Citation: FireEye HAWKBALL Jun 2019)

HAWKBALL.name: System Information Discovery
HAWKBALL.description: [HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) can collect the OS version, architecture information, and computer name.(Citation: FireEye HAWKBALL Jun 2019)

HAWKBALL.name: System Owner/User Discovery
HAWKBALL.description: [HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) can collect the user name of the system.(Citation: FireEye HAWKBALL Jun 2019)

HAWKBALL.name: File Deletion
HAWKBALL.description: [HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) has the ability to delete files.(Citation: FireEye HAWKBALL Jun 2019)

HAWKBALL.name: Windows Command Shell
HAWKBALL.description: [HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) has created a cmd.exe reverse shell, executed commands, and uploaded output via the command line.(Citation: FireEye HAWKBALL Jun 2019)

HAWKBALL.name: Commonly Used Port
HAWKBALL.description: [HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) has sent HTTP GET requests over port 443 for C2.(Citation: FireEye HAWKBALL Jun 2019)

HAWKBALL.name: Web Protocols
HAWKBALL.description: [HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) has used HTTP to communicate with a single hard-coded C2 server.(Citation: FireEye HAWKBALL Jun 2019)

HAWKBALL.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
HAWKBALL.description: [HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) has encrypted the payload with an XOR-based algorithm.(Citation: FireEye HAWKBALL Jun 2019)

HAWKBALL.name: Native API
HAWKBALL.description: [HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) has leveraged several Windows API calls to create processes, gather disk information, and detect debugger activity.(Citation: FireEye HAWKBALL Jun 2019)

HAWKBALL.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
HAWKBALL.description: [HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) has exploited Microsoft Office vulnerabilities CVE-2017-11882 and CVE-2018-0802 to deliver the payload.(Citation: FireEye HAWKBALL Jun 2019)

HAWKBALL.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
HAWKBALL.description: [HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) has used an OLE object that uses Equation Editor to drop the embedded shellcode.(Citation: FireEye HAWKBALL Jun 2019)

PowerStallion.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
PowerStallion.description: [PowerStallion](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0393) uses a XOR cipher to encrypt command output written to its OneDrive C2 server.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

PowerStallion.name: Bidirectional Communication
PowerStallion.description: [PowerStallion](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0393) uses Microsoft OneDrive as a C2 server via a network drive mapped with net use.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

PowerStallion.name: Timestomp
PowerStallion.description: [PowerStallion](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0393) modifies the MAC times of its local log files to match that of the victim's desktop.ini file.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

PowerStallion.name: Process Discovery
PowerStallion.description: [PowerStallion](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0393) has been used to monitor process lists.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

PowerStallion.name: PowerShell
PowerStallion.description: [PowerStallion](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0393) uses PowerShell loops to iteratively check for available commands in its OneDrive C2 server.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

HiddenWasp.name: .bash_profile and .bashrc
HiddenWasp.description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) installs reboot persistence by adding itself to /etc/rc.local.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)

HiddenWasp.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
HiddenWasp.description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) uses a cipher to implement a decoding function.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)

HiddenWasp.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
HiddenWasp.description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) encrypts its configuration and payload.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)

HiddenWasp.name: Windows Command Shell
HiddenWasp.description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) uses a script to automate tasks on the victim's machine and to assist in execution.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)

HiddenWasp.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
HiddenWasp.description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) communicates with a simple network protocol over TCP.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)

HiddenWasp.name: Local Account
HiddenWasp.description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) creates a user account as a means to provide initial persistence to the compromised machine.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)

HiddenWasp.name: Uncommonly Used Port
HiddenWasp.description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) uses port 61061 to communicate with the C2 server.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)

HiddenWasp.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
HiddenWasp.description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) downloads a tar compressed archive from a download server to the system.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)

HiddenWasp.name: Rootkit
HiddenWasp.description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) uses a rootkit to hook and implement functions on the system.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)

HiddenWasp.name: Symmetric Cryptography
HiddenWasp.description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) uses an RC4-like algorithm with an already computed PRGA generated key-stream for network communication.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)

HiddenWasp.name: LD_PRELOAD
HiddenWasp.description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) adds itself as a shared object to the LD_PRELOAD environment variable.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Remote Email Collection
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) collects Exchange emails matching rules specified in its configuration.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Data from Local System
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) can collect files from a local system.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Automated Collection
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) can be configured to automatically collect files under a specified directory.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: System Information Discovery
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) gathers the victim computer name using the Win32 API call GetComputerName.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) gathers information about network adapters using the Win32 API call GetAdaptersInfo.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Archive Collected Data
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) contains a function to encrypt and store emails that it collects.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Automated Exfiltration
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) can be configured to automatically exfiltrate files under a specified directory.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Mail Protocols
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) uses SMTP for C2.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Symmetric Cryptography
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) uses AES to encrypt C2 traffic.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Steganography
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) is controlled via commands that are embedded into PDFs and JPGs using steganographic methods.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Scheduled Transfer
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) can be configured to exfiltrate data during nighttime or working hours.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) exfiltrates data over its email C2 channel.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) has used AES and XOR to decrypt configuration files and commands.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) has used filenames associated with Exchange and Outlook for binary and configuration files, such as winmail.dat.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Transmitted Data Manipulation
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) is capable of modifying email content, headers, and attachments during transit.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Windows Command Shell
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) is capable of executing commands via cmd.exe.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) has the ability to download and execute additional files.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Native API
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) is capable of starting a process using CreateProcess.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: File Deletion
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) has a function to delete files.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) encrypts its configuration files with AES-256.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Transport Agent
LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) has used a malicious Microsoft Exchange transport agent for persistence.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

LightNeuron.name: Local Data Staging
