LightNeuron.description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) can store email data in files and directories specified in its configuration, such as C:\Windows\ServiceProfiles\NetworkService\appdata\Local\Temp\.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)

EvilBunny.name: System Time Discovery
EvilBunny.description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) has used the API calls NtQuerySystemTime, GetSystemTimeAsFileTime, and GetTickCount to check to see if the malware is running in a sandbox.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)

EvilBunny.name: Scheduled Task
EvilBunny.description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) has executed commands via scheduled tasks.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)

EvilBunny.name: Web Protocols
EvilBunny.description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) has executed C2 commands directly via HTTP.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)

EvilBunny.name: File Deletion
EvilBunny.description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) has deleted the initial dropper after running through the environment checks.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)

EvilBunny.name: Process Discovery
EvilBunny.description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) has used EnumProcesses() to identify how many process are running in the environment.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)

EvilBunny.name: Security Software Discovery
EvilBunny.description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) has been observed querying installed antivirus software.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)

EvilBunny.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
EvilBunny.description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) has downloaded additional Lua scripts from the C2.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)

EvilBunny.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
EvilBunny.description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) has created Registry keys for persistence in [HKLM|HKCU]\…\CurrentVersion\Run.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)

EvilBunny.name: Windows Command Shell
EvilBunny.description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) has an integrated scripting engine to download and execute Lua scripts.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)

EvilBunny.name: System Checks
EvilBunny.description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) for a number of specific processes and the length of its own name to identify if the malware is in a sandbox environment.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)

EvilBunny.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
EvilBunny.description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) has used WMI to gather information about the system.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)

EvilBunny.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
EvilBunny.description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) has exploited CVE-2011-4369, a vulnerability in the PRC component in Adobe Reader.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)

LoJax.name: NTFS File Attributes
LoJax.description: [LoJax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0397) has loaded an embedded NTFS DXE driver to be able to access and write to NTFS partitions.(Citation: ESET LoJax Sept 2018)

LoJax.name: Modify Registry
LoJax.description: [LoJax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0397) has modified the Registry key ‘HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\BootExecute’ from ‘autocheck autochk *’ to ‘autocheck autoche *’.(Citation: ESET LoJax Sept 2018)

LoJax.name: System Firmware
LoJax.description: [LoJax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0397) is a UEFI BIOS rootkit deployed to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.(Citation: ESET LoJax Sept 2018)

LoJax.name: Rootkit
LoJax.description: [LoJax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0397) is a UEFI BIOS rootkit deployed to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.(Citation: ESET LoJax Sept 2018)

LoJax.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
LoJax.description: [LoJax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0397) has modified the Registry key ‘HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\BootExecute’ from ‘autocheck autochk *’ to ‘autocheck autoche *’ in order to execute its payload during Windows startup.(Citation: ESET LoJax Sept 2018)

LoJax.name: System Firmware
LoJax.description: [LoJax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0397) is a UEFI BIOS rootkit deployed to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.(Citation: ESET LoJax Sept 2018)

HyperBro.name: File Deletion
HyperBro.description: [HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) has the ability to delete a specified file.(Citation: Unit42 Emissary Panda May 2019)

HyperBro.name: Service Execution
HyperBro.description: [HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) has the ability to start and stop a specified service.(Citation: Unit42 Emissary Panda May 2019)

HyperBro.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
HyperBro.description: [HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) has the ability to download additional files.(Citation: Unit42 Emissary Panda May 2019)

HyperBro.name: System Service Discovery
HyperBro.description: [HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) can list all services and their configurations.(Citation: Unit42 Emissary Panda May 2019)

HyperBro.name: Process Injection
HyperBro.description: [HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) can run shellcode it injects into a newly created process.(Citation: Unit42 Emissary Panda May 2019)

HyperBro.name: Native API
HyperBro.description: [HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) has the ability to run an application (CreateProcessW) or script/file (ShellExecuteW) via API.(Citation: Unit42 Emissary Panda May 2019)

HyperBro.name: Screen Capture
HyperBro.description: [HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) has the ability to take screenshots.(Citation: Unit42 Emissary Panda May 2019)

HyperBro.name: Web Protocols
HyperBro.description: [HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) has used HTTPS for C2 communications.(Citation: Unit42 Emissary Panda May 2019)

HyperBro.name: DLL Side-Loading
HyperBro.description: [HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) has used a legitimate application to sideload a DLL to decrypt, decompress, and run a payload.(Citation: Unit42 Emissary Panda May 2019)

RobbinHood.name: Network Share Connection Removal
RobbinHood.description: [RobbinHood](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0400) disconnects all network shares from the computer with the command net use * /DELETE /Y.(Citation: CarbonBlack RobbinHood May 2019)

RobbinHood.name: Windows Command Shell
RobbinHood.description: [RobbinHood](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0400) uses cmd.exe on the victim's computer.(Citation: CarbonBlack RobbinHood May 2019)

RobbinHood.name: Disable or Modify Tools
RobbinHood.description: [RobbinHood](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0400) will search for Windows services that are associated with antivirus software on the system and kill the process.(Citation: CarbonBlack RobbinHood May 2019)

RobbinHood.name: Inhibit System Recovery
RobbinHood.description: [RobbinHood](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0400) deletes shadow copies to ensure that all the data cannot be restored easily.(Citation: CarbonBlack RobbinHood May 2019)

RobbinHood.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
RobbinHood.description: [RobbinHood](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0400) will search for an RSA encryption key and then perform its encryption process on the system files.(Citation: CarbonBlack RobbinHood May 2019)

RobbinHood.name: Service Stop
RobbinHood.description: [RobbinHood](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0400) stops 181 Windows services on the system before beginning the encryption process.(Citation: CarbonBlack RobbinHood May 2019)

Exaramel for Linux.name: Unix Shell
Exaramel for Linux.description: [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401) has a command to execute a shell command on the system.(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)

Exaramel for Linux.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Exaramel for Linux.description: [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401) uses RC4 for encrypting the configuration.(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)

Exaramel for Linux.name: Web Protocols
Exaramel for Linux.description: [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401) uses HTTPS for C2 communications.(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)

Exaramel for Linux.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Exaramel for Linux.description: [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401) has a command to download a file from a remote server.(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)

Exaramel for Linux.name: Cron
Exaramel for Linux.description: [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401) uses crontab for persistence if it does not have root privileges.(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)

Exaramel for Linux.name: Systemd Service
Exaramel for Linux.description: [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401) has a hardcoded location under systemd that it uses to achieve persistence if it is running as root.(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)

OSX/Shlayer.name: System Information Discovery
OSX/Shlayer.description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) can collect the macOS version and IOPlatformUUID.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)

OSX/Shlayer.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
OSX/Shlayer.description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) can base64-decode and AES-decrypt downloaded payloads.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)

OSX/Shlayer.name: Disable or Modify Tools
OSX/Shlayer.description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) can disable Gatekeeper using the native spctl application.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)

OSX/Shlayer.name: Unix Shell
OSX/Shlayer.description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) can use bash scripts to check the macOS version and download payloads.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)

OSX/Shlayer.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
OSX/Shlayer.description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) can masquerade as a Flash Player update.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)(Citation: Intego Shlayer Feb 2018)

OSX/Shlayer.name: Malicious File
OSX/Shlayer.description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) relies on users mounting and executing a malicious DMG file.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)(Citation: Intego Shlayer Feb 2018)

OSX/Shlayer.name: Elevated Execution with Prompt
OSX/Shlayer.description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) can escalate privileges to root by asking the user for credentials.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)

OSX/Shlayer.name: Hidden Files and Directories
OSX/Shlayer.description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) executes a .command script from a hidden directory in a mounted DMG.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)

OSX/Shlayer.name: Browser Extensions
OSX/Shlayer.description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) can install malicious Safari browser extensions to serve ads.(Citation: Intego Shlayer Apr 2018)(Citation: Malwarebytes Crossrider Apr 2018)

OSX/Shlayer.name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
OSX/Shlayer.description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) can use the chmod utility to set a .app file as executable.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)

Fysbis.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Fysbis.description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) has masqueraded as trusted software rsyncd and dbus-inotifier.(Citation: Fysbis Dr Web Analysis)

Fysbis.name: Standard Encoding
Fysbis.description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) can use Base64 to encode its C2 traffic.(Citation: Fysbis Dr Web Analysis)

Fysbis.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Fysbis.description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) has been encrypted using XOR and RC4.(Citation: Fysbis Dr Web Analysis)

Fysbis.name: Unix Shell
Fysbis.description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) has the ability to create and execute commands in a remote shell for CLI.(Citation: Fysbis Palo Alto Analysis)

Fysbis.name: System Information Discovery
Fysbis.description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) has used the command ls /etc | egrep -e"fedora\*|debian\*|gentoo\*|mandriva\*|mandrake\*|meego\*|redhat\*|lsb-\*|sun-\*|SUSE\*|release" to determine which Linux OS version is running.(Citation: Fysbis Palo Alto Analysis)

Fysbis.name: Keylogging
Fysbis.description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) can perform keylogging.(Citation: Fysbis Palo Alto Analysis)

Fysbis.name: File Deletion
Fysbis.description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) has the ability to delete files.(Citation: Fysbis Dr Web Analysis)

Fysbis.name: File and Directory Discovery
Fysbis.description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) has the ability to search for files.(Citation: Fysbis Dr Web Analysis)

Fysbis.name: Process Discovery
Fysbis.description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) can collect information about running processes.(Citation: Fysbis Dr Web Analysis)

Fysbis.name: Commonly Used Port
Fysbis.description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) has used port 80 for C2.(Citation: Fysbis Palo Alto Analysis)

Fysbis.name: Systemd Service
Fysbis.description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) has established persistence using a systemd service.(Citation: Fysbis Dr Web Analysis)

Fysbis.name: Masquerade Task or Service
Fysbis.description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) has masqueraded as the rsyncd and dbus-inotifier services.(Citation: Fysbis Dr Web Analysis)

Machete.name: Video Capture
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) takes photos from the computer’s web camera.(Citation: Securelist Machete Aug 2014)

Machete.name: Audio Capture
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) captures audio from the computer’s microphone.(Citation: Securelist Machete Aug 2014)

Machete.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) has used pyobfuscate, zlib compression, and base64 encoding for obfuscation.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409)’s downloaded data is decrypted using AES.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Keylogging
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) logs keystrokes from the victim’s machine.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)(Citation: Securelist Machete Aug 2014)

Machete.name: Scheduled Task
Machete.description: The different components of [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) are executed by Windows Task Scheduler.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Fallback Channels
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) has sent data over HTTP if FTP failed, and has also used a fallback server.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: File Transfer Protocols
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) uses FTP for Command & Control.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Archive via Custom Method
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409)'s collected data is encrypted with AES before exfiltration.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409)'s collected data is exfiltrated over the same channel used for C2.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Clipboard Data
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) hijacks the clipboard data by creating an overlapped window that listens to keyboard events.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)(Citation: Securelist Machete Aug 2014)

Machete.name: Screen Capture
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) captures screenshots.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)(Citation: Securelist Machete Aug 2014)

Machete.name: Process Discovery
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) has a component to check for running processes to look for web browsers.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) can download additional files for execution on the victim’s machine.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: File Deletion
Machete.description: Once a file is uploaded, [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) will delete it from the machine.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: System Information Discovery
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) collects the hostname of the target computer.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) collects the MAC address of the target computer.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Scheduled Transfer
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) sends stolen data to the C2 server every 10 minutes.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Application Window Discovery
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) saves the window names.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Exfiltration over USB
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) has a feature to copy files from every drive onto a removable drive in a hidden folder.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)(Citation: Securelist Machete Aug 2014)

Machete.name: Data from Removable Media
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) copies files from newly inserted drives.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Local Data Staging
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) stores files and logs in a folder on the local drive.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) detects the insertion of new devices by listening for the WM_DEVICECHANGE window message.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Archive Collected Data
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) stores zipped files with profile data from installed web browsers.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Hidden Files and Directories
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) has the capability to exfiltrate stolen data to a hidden folder on a removable drive.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: File and Directory Discovery
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) produces file listings in order to search for files to be exfiltrated.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Data from Local System
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) searches the File system for files of interest.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Automated Exfiltration
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409)’s collected files are exfiltrated automatically to remote servers.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) renamed payloads to masquerade as legitimate Google Chrome, Java, Dropbox, Adobe Reader and Python executables.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) uses the netsh wlan show networks mode=bssid and netsh wlan show interfaces commands to list all nearby WiFi networks and connected interfaces.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Private Keys
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) has scanned and looked for cryptographic keys and certificate file extensions.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Software Packing
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) has been packed with NSIS.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Python
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) uses Python scripts.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)(Citation: Securelist Machete Aug 2014)

Machete.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) collects stored credentials from several web browsers.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Browser Bookmark Discovery
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) retrieves the user profile data (e.g., browsers) from Chrome and Firefox browsers.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Web Protocols
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) uses HTTP for Command & Control.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

Machete.name: Masquerade Task or Service
Machete.description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) renamed task names to masquerade as legitimate Google Chrome, Java, Dropbox, Adobe Reader and Python tasks.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)

ZxShell.name: Endpoint Denial of Service
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has a feature to perform SYN flood attack on a host.(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Screen Capture
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can capture screenshots.(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)

ZxShell.name: Proxy
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can set up an HTTP or SOCKS proxy.(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Windows Command Shell
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can launch a reverse command shell.(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )(Citation: Secureworks BRONZEUNION Feb 2019)

ZxShell.name: Keylogging
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has a feature to capture a remote computer's keystrokes using a keylogger.(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: File Deletion
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can delete files from the system.(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Network Service Scanning
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can launch port scans.(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Disable or Modify Tools
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can kill AV products' processes.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: System Information Discovery
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can collect the local hostname, operating system details, CPU speed, and total physical memory.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: System Owner/User Discovery
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can collect the owner and organization information from the target workstation.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Windows Service
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can create a new service using the service parser function ProcessScCommand.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: System Service Discovery
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can check the services on the system.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Local Account
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has a feature to create local user accounts.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Query Registry
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can query the netsvc group value data located in the svchost group Registry key.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) is injected into a shared SVCHOST process.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Credential API Hooking
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) hooks several API functions to spawn system threads.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Rundll32
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has used rundll32.exe to execute other DLLs and named pipes.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Web Protocols
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has used HTTP for C2 connections.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has remote desktop functionality.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: File and Directory Discovery
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has a command to open a file manager and explorer on the system.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Process Discovery
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has a command, ps, to obtain a listing of processes on the system.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: VNC
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) supports functionality for VNC sessions.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Commonly Used Port
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) uses common ports such as 80 and 443 for C2.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Uncommonly Used Port
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) uses ports 1985 and 1986 for communication.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has a command to transfer files from a remote host.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Create Process with Token
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has a command called RunAs, which creates a new process as another user or process context.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Video Capture
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has a command to perform video device spying.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Clear Windows Event Logs
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has a command to clear system event logs.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: File Transfer Protocols
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has used FTP for C2 connections.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

ZxShell.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
ZxShell.description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can disable the firewall by modifying the registry key HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\SharedAccess\Parameters\FirewallPolicy\StandardProfile.(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014 )

BabyShark.name: File Deletion
BabyShark.description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has cleaned up all files associated with the secondary payload execution.(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Apr 2019)

BabyShark.name: Keylogging
BabyShark.description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has a [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086)-based remote administration ability that can implement a PowerShell or C# based keylogger.(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Apr 2019)

BabyShark.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
BabyShark.description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has downloaded additional files from the C2.(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Apr 2019)

BabyShark.name: Windows Command Shell
BabyShark.description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has used cmd.exe to execute commands.(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)

BabyShark.name: System Information Discovery
BabyShark.description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has executed the ver command.(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)

BabyShark.name: System Owner/User Discovery
BabyShark.description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has executed the whoami command.(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)

BabyShark.name: Standard Encoding
BabyShark.description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has encoded data using [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160) before exfiltration.(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)

BabyShark.name: Process Discovery
BabyShark.description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has executed the tasklist command.(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)

BabyShark.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
BabyShark.description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has added a Registry key to ensure all future macros are enabled for Microsoft Word and Excel as well as for additional persistence.(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)

BabyShark.name: Query Registry
BabyShark.description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has executed the reg query command for HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Default.(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)

BabyShark.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
BabyShark.description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has executed the ipconfig /all command.(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)

BabyShark.name: File and Directory Discovery
BabyShark.description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has used dir to search for "programfiles" and "appdata".(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)

BOOSTWRITE.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
BOOSTWRITE.description: [BOOSTWRITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0415) has used a a 32-byte long multi-XOR key to decode data inside its payload.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 Oct 2019)

BOOSTWRITE.name: Shared Modules
BOOSTWRITE.description: [BOOSTWRITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0415) has used the DWriteCreateFactory() function to load additional modules.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 Oct 2019)

BOOSTWRITE.name: Code Signing
BOOSTWRITE.description: [BOOSTWRITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0415) has been signed by a valid CA.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 Oct 2019)

BOOSTWRITE.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
BOOSTWRITE.description: [BOOSTWRITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0415) has exploited the loading of the legitimate Dwrite.dll file by actually loading the gdi library, which then loads the gdiplus library and ultimately loads the local Dwrite dll.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 Oct 2019)

BOOSTWRITE.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
BOOSTWRITE.description: [BOOSTWRITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0415) has encoded its payloads using a ChaCha stream cipher with a 256-bit key and 64-bit Initialization vector (IV) to evade detection.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 Oct 2019)

RDFSNIFFER.name: Native API
RDFSNIFFER.description: [RDFSNIFFER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0416) has used several Win32 API functions to interact with the victim machine.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 Oct 2019)

RDFSNIFFER.name: File Deletion
RDFSNIFFER.description: [RDFSNIFFER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0416) has the capability of deleting local files.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 Oct 2019)

RDFSNIFFER.name: Credential API Hooking
RDFSNIFFER.description: [RDFSNIFFER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0416) hooks several Win32 API functions to hijack elements of the remote system management user-interface.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 Oct 2019)

GRIFFON.name: PowerShell
GRIFFON.description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) has used PowerShell to execute the Meterpreter downloader TinyMet.(Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)

GRIFFON.name: System Time Discovery
GRIFFON.description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) has used a reconnaissance module that can be used to retrieve the date and time of the system.(Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)

GRIFFON.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
GRIFFON.description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) has used a persistence module that stores the implant inside the Registry, which executes at logon.(Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)

GRIFFON.name: Screen Capture
GRIFFON.description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) has used a screenshot module that can be used to take a screenshot of the remote system.(Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)

GRIFFON.name: Scheduled Task
GRIFFON.description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) has used sctasks for persistence. (Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)

GRIFFON.name: Domain Groups
GRIFFON.description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) has used a reconnaissance module that can be used to retrieve Windows domain membership information.(Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)

GRIFFON.name: System Information Discovery
GRIFFON.description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) has used a reconnaissance module that can be used to retrieve information about a victim's computer, including the resolution of the workstation .(Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)

GRIFFON.name: JavaScript/JScript
GRIFFON.description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) is written in and executed as [JavaScript/JScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/007).(Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)

PoetRAT.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted/Obfuscated Non-C2 Protocol
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has used [FTP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0095) for exfiltration.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Malicious File
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has used spearphishing attachments to infect victims.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Visual Basic
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has used Word documents with VBScripts to execute malicious activities.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has used a Python tool named Browdec.exe to steal browser credentials.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Keylogging
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has used a Python tool named klog.exe for keylogging.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Video Capture
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has used a Python tool named Bewmac to record the webcam on compromised hosts.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has used a .NET tool named dog.exe to exiltrate information over an e-mail account.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Screen Capture
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has the ability to take screen captures.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has added a registry key in the <RUN> hive for persistence.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has the ability to copy files and download/upload files into command and control channels (C2) using [FTP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0095).(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Automated Collection
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) used file system monitoring to track modification and enable automatic exfiltration.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: System Checks
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) checked the size of the hard drive to determine if it was being run in a sandbox environment. In the event of sandbox detection, it would delete itself by overwriting the malware scripts with the contents of "License.txt" and exiting.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Process Discovery
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has the ability to list all running processes.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Hidden Files and Directories
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has the ability to hide and unhide files.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has used a custom encryption scheme for communication between scripts.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Archive via Utility
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has the ability to compress files with zip.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Modify Registry
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has made registry modifications to alter its behavior upon execution.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Python
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) was executed with a Python script and worked in conjunction with additional Python-based post-exploitation tools.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: System Information Discovery
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has the ability to gather information about the compromised host.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) used TLS to encrypt command and control (C2) communications.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Spearphishing Attachment
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) was distributed via malicious Word documents.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) sent username, computer name, and the previously generated UUID in reply to a "who" command from C2.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Non-Standard Port
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) used TLS to encrypt communications over port 143(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Indicator Removal on Host
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has the ability to overwrite scripts and delete itself if a sandbox environment is detected.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) was delivered with documents using DDE to execute malicious code.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: LSASS Memory
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) used voStro.exe, a compiled pypykatz (Python version of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002)), to steal credentials.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: Remote System Discovery
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) used Nmap for remote system discovery.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

PoetRAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
PoetRAT.description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has the ability to list files upon receiving the ls command from C2.(Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)

Winnti for Linux.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Winnti for Linux.description: [Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430) can encode its configuration file with single-byte XOR encoding.(Citation: Chronicle Winnti for Linux May 2019)

Winnti for Linux.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Winnti for Linux.description: [Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430) has decoded XOR encoded strings holding its configuration upon execution.(Citation: Chronicle Winnti for Linux May 2019)

Winnti for Linux.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Winnti for Linux.description: [Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430) has the ability to deploy modules directly from command and control (C2) servers, possibly for remote command execution, file exfiltration, and socks5 proxying on the infected host. (Citation: Chronicle Winnti for Linux May 2019)

Winnti for Linux.name: Rootkit
Winnti for Linux.description: [Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430) has used a modified copy of the open-source userland rootkit Azazel, named libxselinux.so, to hide the malware's operations and network activity.(Citation: Chronicle Winnti for Linux May 2019)

Winnti for Linux.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
Winnti for Linux.description: [Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430) has used ICMP, custom TCP, and UDP in outbound communications.(Citation: Chronicle Winnti for Linux May 2019)

Winnti for Linux.name: Web Protocols
Winnti for Linux.description: [Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430) has used HTTP in outbound communications.(Citation: Chronicle Winnti for Linux May 2019)

Winnti for Linux.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Winnti for Linux.description: [Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430) has used a custom TCP protocol with four-byte XOR for command and control (C2).(Citation: Chronicle Winnti for Linux May 2019)

Winnti for Linux.name: Traffic Signaling
Winnti for Linux.description: [Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430) has used a passive listener, capable of identifying a specific magic value before executing tasking, as a secondary command and control (C2) mechanism.(Citation: Chronicle Winnti for Linux May 2019)

HotCroissant.name: Scheduled Task
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has attempted to install a scheduled task named “Java Maintenance64” on startup to establish persistence.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Software Packing
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has used the open source UPX executable packer.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has encrypted strings with single-byte XOR and base64 encoded RC4.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Symmetric Cryptography
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has compressed network communications and encrypted them with a custom stream cipher.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)(Citation: US-CERT HOTCROISSANT February 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Native API
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) can perform dynamic DLL importing and API lookups using LoadLibrary and GetProcAddress on obfuscated strings.(Citation: US-CERT HOTCROISSANT February 2020)

HotCroissant.name: File Deletion
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to clean up installed files, delete files, and delete itself from the victim’s machine.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Windows Command Shell
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) can remotely open applications on the infected host with the ShellExecuteA command.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Application Window Discovery
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to list the names of all open windows on the infected host.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: System Information Discovery
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to determine if the current user is an administrator, Windows product name, processor name, screen resolution, and physical RAM of the infected host.(Citation: US-CERT HOTCROISSANT February 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Software Discovery
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) can retrieve a list of applications from the SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\App Paths registry key.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Service Stop
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to stop services on the infected host.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to upload a file from the command and control (C2) server to the victim machine.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Process Discovery
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to list running processes on the infected host.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: System Service Discovery
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to retrieve a list of services on the infected host.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to download files from the infected host to the command and control (C2) server.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Screen Capture
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to do real time screen viewing on an infected host.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: Hidden Window
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to hide the window for operations performed on a given file.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: File and Directory Discovery
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to retrieve a list of files in a given directory as well as drives and drive types.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: System Owner/User Discovery
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to collect the username on the infected host.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

HotCroissant.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
HotCroissant.description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to identify the IP address of the compromised machine.(Citation: US-CERT HOTCROISSANT February 2020)

Rifdoor.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Rifdoor.description: [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433) has created a new registry entry at HKEY_CURRENT_USERS\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Graphics with a value of C:\ProgramData\Initech\Initech.exe /run.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

Rifdoor.name: Binary Padding
Rifdoor.description: [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433) has added four additional bytes of data upon launching, then saved the changed version as C:\ProgramData\Initech\Initech.exe.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

Rifdoor.name: Malicious File
Rifdoor.description: [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433) has been executed from malicious Excel or Word documents containing macros.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

Rifdoor.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Rifdoor.description: [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433) has been distributed in e-mails with malicious Excel or Word documents.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

Rifdoor.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Rifdoor.description: [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433) has encrypted command and control (C2) communications with a stream cipher.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

Rifdoor.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Rifdoor.description: [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433) has encrypted strings with a single byte XOR algorithm.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

Rifdoor.name: System Information Discovery
Rifdoor.description: [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433) has the ability to identify the Windows version on the compromised host.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

Rifdoor.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Rifdoor.description: [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433) has the ability to identify the username on the compromised host.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

Rifdoor.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Rifdoor.description: [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433) has the ability to identify the IP address of the compromised host.(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)

PLEAD.name: Proxy
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has the ability to proxy network communications.(Citation: JPCert PLEAD Downloader June 2018)

PLEAD.name: Symmetric Cryptography
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has used RC4 encryption to download modules.(Citation: JPCert PLEAD Downloader June 2018)

PLEAD.name: Application Window Discovery
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has the ability to list open windows on the compromised host.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)

PLEAD.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has the ability to upload and download files to and from an infected host.(Citation: JPCert PLEAD Downloader June 2018)

PLEAD.name: Junk Data
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) samples were found to be highly obfuscated with junk code.(Citation: ESET PLEAD Malware July 2018)

PLEAD.name: Windows Command Shell
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has the ability to execute shell commands on the compromised host.(Citation: JPCert PLEAD Downloader June 2018)

PLEAD.name: File Deletion
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has the ability to delete files on the compromised host.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)

PLEAD.name: Web Protocols
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has used HTTP for communications with command and control (C2) servers.(Citation: JPCert PLEAD Downloader June 2018)

PLEAD.name: Credentials from Password Stores
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has the ability to steal saved passwords from Microsoft Outlook.(Citation: ESET PLEAD Malware July 2018)

PLEAD.name: Malicious File
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has been executed via malicious e-mail attachments.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)

PLEAD.name: File and Directory Discovery
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has the ability to list drives and files on the compromised host.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)(Citation: JPCert PLEAD Downloader June 2018)

PLEAD.name: Process Discovery
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has the ability to list processes on the compromised host.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)

PLEAD.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has the ability to steal saved credentials from web browsers.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)(Citation: ESET PLEAD Malware July 2018)

PLEAD.name: Malicious Link
PLEAD.description: [PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has been executed via malicious links in e-mails.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)

TSCookie.name: Malicious Link
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has been executed via malicious links embedded in e-mails spoofing the Ministries of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology of Japan.(Citation: JPCert TSCookie March 2018)

TSCookie.name: Proxy
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has the ability to proxy communications with command and control (C2) servers.(Citation: JPCert BlackTech Malware September 2019)

TSCookie.name: Process Injection
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has the ability to inject code into the svchost.exe, iexplorer.exe, explorer.exe, and default browser processes.(Citation: JPCert BlackTech Malware September 2019)

TSCookie.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) can use ICMP to receive information on the destination server.(Citation: JPCert BlackTech Malware September 2019)

TSCookie.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has the ability to upload and download files to and from the infected host.(Citation: JPCert TSCookie March 2018)

TSCookie.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has the ability to identify the IP of the infected host.(Citation: JPCert TSCookie March 2018)

TSCookie.name: Symmetric Cryptography
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has encrypted network communications with RC4.(Citation: JPCert TSCookie March 2018)

TSCookie.name: Process Discovery
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has the ability to list processes on the infected host.(Citation: JPCert TSCookie March 2018)

TSCookie.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has the ability to steal saved passwords from the Internet Explorer, Edge, Firefox, and Chrome browsers.(Citation: JPCert TSCookie March 2018)

TSCookie.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has the ability to decrypt, load, and execute a DLL and its resources.(Citation: JPCert TSCookie March 2018)

TSCookie.name: Windows Command Shell
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has the ability to execute shell commands on the infected host.(Citation: JPCert TSCookie March 2018)

TSCookie.name: Web Protocols
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) can multiple protocols including HTTP and HTTPS in communication with command and control (C2) servers.(Citation: JPCert BlackTech Malware September 2019)(Citation: JPCert TSCookie March 2018)

TSCookie.name: File and Directory Discovery
TSCookie.description: [TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has the ability to discover drive information on the infected host.(Citation: JPCert TSCookie March 2018)

Kivars.name: Remote Services
Kivars.description: [Kivars](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0437) has the ability to remotely trigger keyboard input and mouse clicks. (Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)

Kivars.name: Hidden Window
Kivars.description: [Kivars](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0437) has the ability to conceal its activity through hiding active windows.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)

Kivars.name: Screen Capture
Kivars.description: [Kivars](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0437) has the ability to capture screenshots on the infected host.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)

Kivars.name: Keylogging
Kivars.description: [Kivars](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0437) has the ability to initiate keylogging on the infected host.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)

Kivars.name: File Deletion
Kivars.description: [Kivars](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0437) has the ability to uninstall malware from the infected host.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)

Kivars.name: File and Directory Discovery
Kivars.description: [Kivars](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0437) has the ability to list drives on the infected host.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)

Kivars.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Kivars.description: [Kivars](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0437) has the ability to download and execute files.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)

Attor.name: Hidden Files and Directories
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) can set attributes of log files and directories to HIDDEN, SYSTEM, ARCHIVE, or a combination of those.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Automated Collection
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has automatically collected data about the compromised system.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Rundll32
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s installer plugin can schedule rundll32.exe to load the dispatcher.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Service Execution
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s dispatcher can be executed as a service.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Logon Script (Windows)
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s dispatcher can establish persistence via adding a Registry key with a logon script HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Environment "UserInitMprLogonScript" .(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Application Window Discovery
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) can obtain application window titles and then determines which windows to perform Screen Capture on.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Scheduled Task
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s installer plugin can schedule a new task that loads the dispatcher on boot/logon.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) can download additional plugins, updates and other files. (Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Local Data Staging
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has staged collected data in a central upload directory prior to exfiltration.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: System Checks
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) can detect whether it is executed in some virtualized or emulated environment by searching for specific artifacts, such as communication with I/O ports and using VM-specific instructions.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Query Registry
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has opened the registry and performed query searches.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has encrypted data symmetrically using a randomly generated Blowfish (OFB) key which is encrypted with a public RSA key.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Multi-hop Proxy
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has used Tor for C2 communication.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Shared Modules
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s dispatcher can execute additional plugins by loading the respective DLLs.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Native API
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s dispatcher has used CreateProcessW API for execution.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has exfiltrated data over the C2 channel.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Asynchronous Procedure Call
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) performs the injection by attaching its code into the APC queue using NtQueueApcThread API.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: File Transfer Protocols
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has used FTP protocol for C2 communication.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Automated Exfiltration
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has a file uploader plugin that automatically exfiltrates the collected data and log files to the C2 server.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Modify Registry
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s dispatcher can modify the Run registry key.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Process Injection
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s dispatcher can inject itself into running processes to gain higher privileges and to evade detection.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Windows Service
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s dispatcher can establish persistence by registering a new service.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Timestomp
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has manipulated the time of last access to files and registry keys after they have been created or modified.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Keylogging
Attor.description: One of [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s plugins can collect user credentials via capturing keystrokes and can capture keystrokes pressed within the window of the injected process.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Clipboard Data
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has a plugin that collects data stored in the Windows clipboard by using the OpenClipboard and GetClipboardData APIs.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Archive via Custom Method
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) encrypts collected data with a custom implementation of Blowfish and RSA ciphers.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Audio Capture
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s has a plugin that is capable of recording audio using available input sound devices.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Attor.description: Strings in [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s components are encrypted with a XOR cipher, using a hardcoded key and the configuration data, log files and plugins are encrypted using a hybrid encryption scheme of Blowfish-OFB combined with RSA.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Screen Capture
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s has a plugin that captures screenshots of the target applications.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has a plugin that collects information about inserted storage devices, modems, and phone devices.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Masquerade Task or Service
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s dispatcher disguises itself as a legitimate task (i.e., the task name and description appear legitimate).(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: File and Directory Discovery
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has a plugin that enumerates files with specific extensions on all hard disk drives and stores file information in encrypted log files.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: File Deletion
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)’s plugin deletes the collected files and log files after exfiltration.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: System Information Discovery
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) monitors the free disk space on the system.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Attor.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
Attor.description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s Blowfish key is encrypted with a public RSA key.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)

Okrum.name: Windows Command Shell
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)'s backdoor has used cmd.exe to execute arbitrary commands as well as batch scripts to update itself to a newer version.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Shortcut Modification
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) can establish persistence by creating a .lnk shortcut to itself in the Startup folder.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Web Protocols
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) uses HTTP for communication with its C2.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Symmetric Cryptography
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) uses AES to encrypt network traffic. The key can be hardcoded or negotiated with the C2 server in the registration phase. (Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) has built-in commands for uploading, downloading, and executing files to the system.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Protocol Impersonation
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) mimics HTTP protocol for C2 communication, while hiding the actual messages in the Cookie and Set-Cookie headers of the HTTP requests.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Standard Encoding
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) has used base64 to encode C2 communication.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: External Proxy
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) can identify proxy servers configured and used by the victim, and use it to make HTTP requests to C2 its server.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Steganography
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)'s payload is encrypted and embedded within its loader, or within a legitimate PNG file.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Archive via Custom Method
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) has used a custom implementation of AES encryption to encrypt collected data.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Hidden Files and Directories
Okrum.description: Before exfiltration, [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)'s backdoor has used hidden files to store logs and outputs from backdoor commands.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Archive via Utility
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) was seen using a RAR archiver tool to compress/decompress data.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: File Deletion
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)'s backdoor deletes files after they have been successfully uploaded to C2 servers.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Cached Domain Credentials
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) was seen using modified Quarks PwDump to perform credential dumping.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Scheduled Task
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)'s installer can attempt to achieve persistence by creating a scheduled task.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Keylogging
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) was seen using a keylogger tool to capture keystrokes. (Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Windows Service
Okrum.description: To establish persistence, [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) can install itself as a new service named NtmSsvc.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Service Execution
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)'s loader can create a new service named NtmsSvc to execute the payload.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) can collect the victim username.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: LSASS Memory
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) was seen using MimikatzLite to perform credential dumping.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Time Based Evasion
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)'s loader can detect presence of an emulator by using two calls to GetTickCount API, and checking whether the time has been accelerated.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)'s loader can decrypt the backdoor code, embedded within the loader or within a legitimate PNG file. A custom XOR cipher or RC4 is used for decryption.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: System Checks
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)'s loader can check the amount of physical memory and terminates itself if the host has less than 1.5 Gigabytes of physical memory in total.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Okrum.description: Data exfiltration is done by [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) using the already opened channel with the C2 server.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: System Information Discovery
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) can collect computer name, locale information, and information about the OS and architecture.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) was seen using NetSess to discover NetBIOS sessions.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) can collect network information, including the host IP address, DNS, and proxy information.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: File and Directory Discovery
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) has used DriveLetterView to enumerate drive information.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Masquerade Task or Service
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) can establish persistence by adding a new service NtmsSvc with the display name Removable Storage to masquerade as a legitimate Removable Storage Manager.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Token Impersonation/Theft
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) can impersonate a logged-on user's security context using a call to the ImpersonateLoggedOnUser API.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: System Time Discovery
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) can obtain the date and time of the compromised system.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: User Activity Based Checks
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) loader only executes the payload after the left mouse button has been pressed at least three times, in order to avoid being executed within virtualized or emulated environments.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

Okrum.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Okrum.description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) establishes persistence by creating a .lnk shortcut to itself in the Startup folder.(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)

PowerShower.name: PowerShell
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) is a backdoor written in PowerShell.(Citation: Unit 42 Inception November 2018)

PowerShower.name: Visual Basic
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has the ability to save and execute VBScript.(Citation: Unit 42 Inception November 2018)

PowerShower.name: Web Protocols
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has sent HTTP GET and POST requests to C2 servers to send information and receive instructions.(Citation: Unit 42 Inception November 2018)

PowerShower.name: System Information Discovery
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has collected system information on the infected host.(Citation: Unit 42 Inception November 2018)

PowerShower.name: Modify Registry
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has added a registry key so future powershell.exe instances are spawned off-screen by default, and has removed all registry entries that are left behind during the dropper process.(Citation: Unit 42 Inception November 2018)

PowerShower.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) sets up persistence with a Registry run key.(Citation: Unit 42 Inception November 2018)

PowerShower.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has the ability to identify the current Windows domain of the infected host.(Citation: Kaspersky Cloud Atlas August 2019)

PowerShower.name: System Owner/User Discovery
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has the ability to identify the current user on the infected host.(Citation: Kaspersky Cloud Atlas August 2019)

PowerShower.name: File Deletion
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has the ability to remove all files created during the dropper process.(Citation: Unit 42 Inception November 2018)

PowerShower.name: Hidden Window
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has added a registry key so future powershell.exe instances are spawned with coordinates for a window position off-screen by default.(Citation: Unit 42 Inception November 2018)

PowerShower.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has used a PowerShell document stealer module to pack and exfiltrate .txt, .pdf, .xls or .doc files smaller than 5MB that were modified during the past two days.(Citation: Kaspersky Cloud Atlas August 2019)

PowerShower.name: Archive via Utility
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has used 7Zip to compress .txt, .pdf, .xls or .doc files prior to exfiltration.(Citation: Kaspersky Cloud Atlas August 2019)

PowerShower.name: Process Discovery
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has the ability to deploy a reconnaissance module to retrieve a list of the active processes.(Citation: Kaspersky Cloud Atlas August 2019)

PowerShower.name: Standard Encoding
PowerShower.description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has the ability to encode C2 communications with base64 encoding.(Citation: Unit 42 Inception November 2018)(Citation: Kaspersky Cloud Atlas August 2019)

VBShower.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
VBShower.description: [VBShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0442) has the ability to download VBS files to the target computer.(Citation: Kaspersky Cloud Atlas August 2019)

VBShower.name: Web Protocols
VBShower.description: [VBShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0442) has attempted to obtain a VBS script from command and control (C2) nodes over HTTP.(Citation: Kaspersky Cloud Atlas August 2019)

VBShower.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
VBShower.description: [VBShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0442) used HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\\[a-f0-9A-F]{8} to maintain persistence.(Citation: Kaspersky Cloud Atlas August 2019)

VBShower.name: File Deletion
VBShower.description: [VBShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0442) has attempted to complicate forensic analysis by deleting all the files contained in %APPDATA%\..\Local\Temporary Internet Files\Content.Word and %APPDATA%\..\Local Settings\Temporary Internet Files\Content.Word\.(Citation: Kaspersky Cloud Atlas August 2019)

VBShower.name: Visual Basic
VBShower.description: [VBShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0442) has the ability to execute VBScript files.(Citation: Kaspersky Cloud Atlas August 2019)

MESSAGETAP.name: Archive via Custom Method
MESSAGETAP.description: [MESSAGETAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0443) has XOR-encrypted and stored contents of SMS messages that matched its target list. (Citation: FireEye MESSAGETAP October 2019)

MESSAGETAP.name: System Network Connections Discovery
MESSAGETAP.description: After loading the keyword and phone data files, [MESSAGETAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0443) begins monitoring all network connections to and from the victim server. (Citation: FireEye MESSAGETAP October 2019)

MESSAGETAP.name: Network Sniffing
MESSAGETAP.description: [MESSAGETAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0443) uses the libpcap library to listen to all traffic and parses network protocols starting with Ethernet and IP layers. It continues parsing protocol layers including SCTP, SCCP, and TCAP and finally extracts SMS message data and routing metadata.  (Citation: FireEye MESSAGETAP October 2019)

MESSAGETAP.name: File Deletion
MESSAGETAP.description: Once loaded into memory, [MESSAGETAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0443) deletes the keyword_parm.txt and parm.txt configuration files from disk. (Citation: FireEye MESSAGETAP October 2019)

MESSAGETAP.name: Automated Collection
MESSAGETAP.description: [MESSAGETAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0443) checks two files, keyword_parm.txt and parm.txt, for instructions on how to target and save data parsed and extracted from SMS message data from the network traffic. If an SMS message contained either a phone number, IMSI number, or keyword that matched the predefined list, it is saved to a CSV file for later theft by the threat actor.(Citation: FireEye MESSAGETAP October 2019)

MESSAGETAP.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
